subject: Chemistry
title: Energy of Photon
description: Energy of a quantum of light.
derivation:
From Planck's Quantum Theory.
Energy is proportional to frequency: $E \propto \nu$.
$E = h\nu$.
Since speed of light $c = \nu \lambda$, we have $\nu = c/\lambda$.
Substitute: $E = \frac{hc}{\lambda}$.

related_concepts.name: Planck's Constant
related_concepts.definition: $h \approx 6.626 \times 10^{-34} Js$. The fundamental quantum of action.

related_concepts.name: Photoelectric Effect
related_concepts.definition: Ejection of electrons from a metal surface when light of sufficient frequency strikes it.

subject: Chemistry
title: Bohr's Quantization
description: Angular momentum quantization condition.
derivation:
Bohr proposed that electron orbits are stable only if the circumference contains an integer number of de Broglie wavelengths.
$2\pi r = n\lambda$.
Substitute $\lambda = h/p = h/mv$:
$2\pi r = n(h/mv)$.
Rearrange: $mvr = \frac{nh}{2\pi}$.

related_concepts.name: Stationary State
related_concepts.definition: An orbit where the electron does not radiate energy.

subject: Chemistry
title: Radius of Bohr Orbit
description: Radius of nth orbit in hydrogen-like species.
derivation:
1. Force Balance: Electrostatic attraction = Centripetal force.
$\frac{kZe^2}{r^2} = \frac{mv^2}{r} \implies v^2 = \frac{kZe^2}{mr}$.
2. Quantization: $v = \frac{nh}{2\pi mr}$.
Square (2) and equate to (1):
$\frac{n^2 h^2}{4\pi^2 m^2 r^2} = \frac{kZe^2}{mr}$.
Solve for $r$: $r = \frac{n^2 h^2}{4\pi^2 m k Z e^2}$.

related_concepts.name: Bohr Radius (a0)
related_concepts.definition: The radius of the first orbit of Hydrogen ($n=1, Z=1$), approx $0.529 \AA$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Energy of Electron
description: Total energy of electron in nth orbit.
derivation:
Total Energy $E = K + U$.
$U = -\frac{kZe^2}{r}$ (Potential).
$K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{kZe^2}{2r}$ (from Force balance).
$E = \frac{kZe^2}{2r} - \frac{kZe^2}{r} = -\frac{kZe^2}{2r}$.
Substitute formula for $r \propto n^2/Z$:
$E \propto -\frac{Z^2}{n^2}$.

related_concepts.name: Ionization Energy
related_concepts.definition: Energy required to remove an electron from the ground state to infinity ($E_\infty = 0$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Rydberg Equation
description: Wavenumber of emitted photon during transition.
derivation:
Energy difference $\Delta E = E_{n2} - E_{n1}$.
$\Delta E = 13.6 Z^2 (\frac{1}{n_1^2} - \frac{1}{n_2^2})$ eV.
Photon energy $E = hc/\lambda$.
$\frac{1}{\lambda} = \frac{13.6 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{hc} Z^2 (...)$.
The constant term corresponds to Rydberg Constant $R_H$.

related_concepts.name: Spectral Series
related_concepts.definition: Lyman (UV, $n_1=1$), Balmer (Visible, $n_1=2$), Paschen (IR, $n_1=3$).

subject: Chemistry
title: de Broglie Wavelength
description: Wave-particle duality relation.
derivation:
Analogy combining Mass-Energy and Planck Energy.
$E = mc^2$ and $E = h\nu = hc/\lambda$.
$mc^2 = hc/\lambda \implies \lambda = h/mc$.
Replacing $c$ with velocity $v$ for material particles:
$\lambda = h/mv$.

related_concepts.name: Matter Waves
related_concepts.definition: Waves associated with moving particles (electrons, protons, etc.).

subject: Chemistry
title: Wavelength (Charged Particle)
description: Wavelength of particle accelerated by potential V.
derivation:
Kinetic Energy gained by charge $Q$ falling through potential $V$ is $K = QV$.
Also $K = \frac{p^2}{2m} \implies p = \sqrt{2mK} = \sqrt{2mQV}$.
Substitute into de Broglie eq $\lambda = h/p$:
$\lambda = \frac{h}{\sqrt{2mQV}}$.

related_concepts.name: Electron Wavelength
related_concepts.definition: For an electron, $\lambda \approx \sqrt{150/V} \AA$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Heisenberg Uncertainty
description: Fundamental limit of precision. \(\Delta x\): uncertainty in position, \(\Delta p\): uncertainty in momentum.
derivation:
Derived from the wave nature of particles.
To localize a wave packet in space (small \(\Delta x\)), you need a superposition of many wavelengths (large \(\Delta \lambda\)), which implies large uncertainty in momentum (\(\Delta p\)).
Exact limit derived from operators: \(\sigma_x \sigma_p \ge \hbar/2\).

related_concepts.name: Complementary Variables
related_concepts.definition: Pairs of properties (like position/momentum) that cannot be simultaneously measured with arbitrary precision.

subject: Chemistry
title: Spin Magnetic Moment
description: Magnetic moment based on unpaired electrons ($n$).
derivation:
Derived from Quantum Mechanics for spin angular momentum.
Spin angular momentum $S = \sqrt{s(s+1)} (h/2\pi)$.
For $n$ unpaired electrons, total spin $s = n/2$.
Magnetic moment $\mu$ relates to $S$.
Simplified formula gives $\sqrt{n(n+2)}$ Bohr Magnetons.

related_concepts.name: Paramagnetism
related_concepts.definition: Attraction to magnetic fields due to presence of unpaired electrons.

subject: Chemistry
title: Orbital Nodes
description: Regions of zero probability density.
derivation:
Solutions to the radial part of the Schrödinger equation contain polynomials.
The number of roots (zeros) determines the number of radial nodes.
Radial Nodes = $n - l - 1$.
Angular Nodes = $l$ (planes passing through nucleus).
Total = $(n - l - 1) + l = n - 1$.

related_concepts.name: Nodal Plane
related_concepts.definition: A plane where the probability of finding an electron is zero.

subject: Chemistry
title: Rate of Reaction
description: Normalized rate for $aA \rightarrow bB$.
derivation:
Rate is change in concentration per unit time.
Since stoichiometry differs ($a$ moles of A disappear for $b$ moles of B to form), we divide by the coefficient to get a unique rate for the reaction.
Reactants decrease (-ve), Products increase (+ve).

related_concepts.name: Instantaneous Rate
related_concepts.definition: The rate at a specific moment in time ($slope$ of tangent to conc-time curve).

subject: Chemistry
title: Rate Law
description: Experimental relation between rate and concentration.
derivation:
This is an empirical law determined experimentally, not from stoichiometry.
$k$ is the specific rate constant.
$x$ and $y$ are reaction orders with respect to reactants A and B.
Overall order = $x + y$.

related_concepts.name: Order of Reaction
related_concepts.definition: Sum of powers of concentration terms in the rate law expression.

subject: Chemistry
title: Zero Order Integration
description: Concentration vs Time for Zero Order.
derivation:
Rate Law: $-d[A]/dt = k[A]^0 = k$.
$d[A] = -k dt$.
Integrate from $t=0$ ($[A]_0$) to $t$ ($[A]_t$):
$\int_{[A]_0}^{[A]_t} d[A] = -k \int_0^t dt$.
$[A]_t - [A]_0 = -kt$.

related_concepts.name: Linear Decay
related_concepts.definition: For zero order, the concentration decreases at a constant rate independent of concentration.

subject: Chemistry
title: First Order Integration
description: Exponential decay of concentration.
derivation:
Rate Law: $-d[A]/dt = k[A]^1$.
Separate variables: $d[A]/[A] = -k dt$.
Integrate:
$\int \frac{1}{[A]} d[A] = -k \int dt$.
$\ln [A]_t - \ln [A]_0 = -kt$.
$\ln([A]_t/[A]_0) = -kt \implies [A]_t = [A]_0 e^{-kt}$.

related_concepts.name: Natural Log Plot
related_concepts.definition: A plot of $\ln[A]$ vs $t$ gives a straight line with slope $-k$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Second Order Integration
description: Inverse concentration vs Time.
derivation:
Rate Law: $-d[A]/dt = k[A]^2$.
Separate variables: $-[A]^{-2} d[A] = k dt$.
Integrate ($ \int -x^{-2} dx = x^{-1} $):
$[ \frac{1}{[A]} ]_{[A]_0}^{[A]_t} = kt$.
$\frac{1}{[A]_t} - \frac{1}{[A]_0} = kt$.

related_concepts.name: Elementary Reaction
related_concepts.definition: A reaction that occurs in a single step ($2A \to P$ follows 2nd order kinetics).

subject: Chemistry
title: Half-Life (Zero Order)
description: Time for conc to drop to half.

related_concepts.name: Concentration Dependence
related_concepts.definition: Unlike 1st order, zero order half-life decreases as concentration decreases.

subject: Chemistry
title: Half-Life (First Order)
description: Constant half-life.

related_concepts.name: Radioactivity
related_concepts.definition: Nuclear decay follows first-order kinetics; half-life is a characteristic constant.

subject: Chemistry
title: Arrhenius Equation
description: Temperature dependence of rate constant.
derivation:
Based on Collision Theory.
Rate $\propto$ Collision Frequency ($A$) $\times$ Fraction of effective collisions ($e^{-E_a/RT}$).
$E_a$: Activation Energy.
Boltzmann factor $e^{-E_a/RT}$ represents fraction of molecules with $KE \ge E_a$.

related_concepts.name: Activation Energy
related_concepts.definition: Minimum energy barrier that reactants must overcome to form products.

subject: Chemistry
title: Arrhenius (Two Temps)
description: Calculating Activation Energy.
derivation:
Take natural log of Arrhenius Eq: $\ln k = \ln A - \frac{E_a}{RT}$.
Write for $T_1$: $\ln k_1 = \ln A - \frac{E_a}{RT_1}$.
Write for $T_2$: $\ln k_2 = \ln A - \frac{E_a}{RT_2}$.
Subtract (2) - (1):
$\ln k_2 - \ln k_1 = -\frac{E_a}{R} (\frac{1}{T_2} - \frac{1}{T_1}) = \frac{E_a}{R} (\frac{1}{T_1} - \frac{1}{T_2})$.

related_concepts.name: Temperature Coefficient
related_concepts.definition: Ratio of rate constants at temperatures differing by 10°C (usually 2 to 3).

subject: Chemistry
title: First Law (Chemistry)
description: Conservation of Energy (IUPAC Sign Convention).
derivation:
Internal Energy $U$ is a state function.
Change $\Delta U$ equals energy transferred TO the system.
$q$: Heat absorbed BY system (+).
$w$: Work done ON system (+).
Note: Physics often uses $w$ as work BY system (-).

related_concepts.name: State Function
related_concepts.definition: Property depending only on initial and final states, not the path (e.g., U, H, S).

subject: Chemistry
title: Work (Irreversible)
description: Work done against constant external pressure.
derivation:
Work = Force $\times$ Distance.
$F = P_{ext} A$.
$w = - F \Delta x$ (Negative because expansion $\Delta V > 0$ means system loses energy).
$w = - (P_{ext} A) \Delta x = -P_{ext} (A \Delta x)$.
$w = -P_{ext} \Delta V$.

related_concepts.name: Free Expansion
related_concepts.definition: Expansion into a vacuum ($P_{ext}=0$), so work done is zero ($w=0$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Work Done (Reversible Isothermal)
description: Maximum work done during the reversible expansion of an ideal gas. \(n\): moles, \(T\): temperature [K].
derivation:
Work is defined as the integral of external pressure over volume:
\(dw = -P_{ext} dV\)
For a reversible process, \(P_{ext} \approx P_{gas}\).
Using the Ideal Gas Law: \(P = nRT / V\).
Substituting into the integral:
\(w = -\int_{V_1}^{V_2} \frac{nRT}{V} dV\)
Since \(T\) is constant (Isothermal), we integrate \(1/V\):
\(w = -nRT [\ln V]_{V_1}^{V_2}\)
\(w = -nRT \ln(V_2/V_1)\)

related_concepts.name: Reversible Process
related_concepts.definition: A process carried out infinitely slowly so the system remains in equilibrium at every step.

related_concepts.name: Ideal Gas Law
related_concepts.definition: The equation of state \(PV=nRT\) for a hypothetical gas.

subject: Chemistry
title: Adiabatic Relation (Ideal Gas)
description: State variable relationship for reversible adiabatic processes. \(\gamma = C_p / C_v\) (Poisson's ratio).
derivation:
From the First Law of Thermodynamics, for adiabatic process (\(q=0\)):
\(dU = dw\)
Substitute definitions: \(nC_v dT = -P dV\)
Use Ideal Gas Law for P: \(P = nRT/V\)
\(nC_v dT = -\frac{nRT}{V} dV\)
Rearrange variables: \(\frac{dT}{T} = -\frac{R}{C_v} \frac{dV}{V}\)
Since \(R/C_v = \gamma - 1\), integrating both sides yields:
\(\ln T = -(\gamma-1) \ln V + C\)
\(TV^{\gamma-1} = \text{const}\)

related_concepts.name: Adiabatic Process
related_concepts.definition: A process where no heat is exchanged with the surroundings (\(q=0\)).

related_concepts.name: Heat Capacity Ratio
related_concepts.definition: The ratio \(\gamma = C_p/C_v\), always greater than 1.

subject: Chemistry
title: Enthalpy Definition
description: Total heat content of a system at constant pressure. \(\Delta H = q_p\).
derivation:
We define Enthalpy (H) to simplify constant-pressure energy calculations.
Definition: \(H = U + PV\)
Change in Enthalpy: \(\Delta H = \Delta U + \Delta(PV)\)
At constant Pressure (\(P\)):
\(\Delta H = \Delta U + P\Delta V\)
From First Law (\(\Delta U = q + w\)) and expansion work (\(w = -P\Delta V\)):
\(\Delta H = (q_p - P\Delta V) + P\Delta V\)
\(\Delta H = q_p\)

related_concepts.name: Internal Energy (U)
related_concepts.definition: The total kinetic and potential energy of the particles within a system.

related_concepts.name: State Function
related_concepts.definition: A property whose value does not depend on the path taken to reach that specific value.

subject: Chemistry
title: Mayer's Relation
description: Relationship between molar heat capacities for 1 mole of an ideal gas. \(R\): universal gas constant.
derivation:
Start with Enthalpy definition for 1 mole:
\(H = U + PV\)
Since \(PV = RT\) for 1 mole:
\(H = U + RT\)
Differentiate with respect to Temperature (T):
\(\frac{dH}{dT} = \frac{dU}{dT} + \frac{d(RT)}{dT}\)
Substitute heat capacity definitions (\(C_p = dH/dT\) and \(C_v = dU/dT\)):
\(C_p = C_v + R\)
\(C_p - C_v = R\)

related_concepts.name: Molar Heat Capacity
related_concepts.definition: The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of 1 mole of substance by 1 Kelvin.

subject: Chemistry
title: Entropy Change (Definition)
description: Thermodynamic definition of entropy change. Measure of molecular disorder.
derivation:
Clausius defined entropy change based on reversible heat transfer.
For an infinitesimal process:
\(dS = \frac{dq_{rev}}{T}\)
For a finite change from state 1 to 2:
\(\Delta S = \int_{1}^{2} \frac{dq_{rev}}{T}\)
This implies that for an adiabatic reversible process (\(dq=0\)), \(\Delta S = 0\).

related_concepts.name: Second Law of Thermodynamics
related_concepts.definition: Total entropy of an isolated system can never decrease over time.

subject: Chemistry
title: Entropy Change (Ideal Gas)
description: General formula for system entropy change during ideal gas expansion/compression.
derivation:
Start with First Law: \(dq_{rev} = dU - dw_{rev}\)
\(dq_{rev} = nC_v dT + P dV\)
Divide by T to find dS:
\(dS = \frac{dq_{rev}}{T} = nC_v \frac{dT}{T} + \frac{P}{T} dV\)
Substitute \(P/T = nR/V\) (Ideal Gas):
\(dS = nC_v \frac{dT}{T} + nR \frac{dV}{V}\)
Integrate from state 1 to 2:
\(\Delta S = nC_v \ln(T_2/T_1) + nR \ln(V_2/V_1)\)

related_concepts.name: Expansion Entropy
related_concepts.definition: Entropy increases as volume increases (disorder increases with more space).

subject: Chemistry
title: Gibbs Free Energy
description: Thermodynamic potential that predicts spontaneity at constant T and P. \(\Delta G < 0\) is spontaneous.
derivation:
To predict spontaneity for system conditions (const T, P), we introduce G.
Definition:
\(G = H - TS\)
Differentiating:
\(dG = dH - TdS - SdT\)
At constant temperature (\(dT=0\)):
\(dG = dH - TdS\)
This combines the energy factor (H) and entropy factor (S).

related_concepts.name: Spontaneity
related_concepts.definition: The inherent tendency of a process to occur without external work.

related_concepts.name: Exergonic Reaction
related_concepts.definition: A reaction where \(\Delta G\) is negative (releases free energy).

subject: Chemistry
title: Gibbs-Helmholtz Equation
description: Calculates free energy change from enthalpy and entropy changes at constant T.
derivation:
For a finite change at constant temperature:
Start with \(G = H - TS\)
\(\Delta G = \Delta(H - TS)\)
\(\Delta G = \Delta H - \Delta(TS)\)
Since T is constant:
\(\Delta G = \Delta H - T \Delta S\)
This equation determines if enthalpy or entropy dominates the spontaneity.

related_concepts.name: Entropy Driven
related_concepts.definition: A process where \(T\Delta S\) is the dominant term making \(\Delta G\) negative.

subject: Chemistry
title: Standard Free Energy & Equilibrium
description: Relates standard thermodynamics to the equilibrium constant \(K_{eq}\).
derivation:
The relationship between free energy and the reaction quotient Q is:
\(\Delta G = \Delta G^\circ + RT \ln Q\)
At equilibrium, the system does no work, so \(\Delta G = 0\).
Also at equilibrium, \(Q\) becomes \(K_{eq}\).
Substituting:
\(0 = \Delta G^\circ + RT \ln K_{eq}\)
\(\Delta G^\circ = -RT \ln K_{eq}\)

related_concepts.name: Equilibrium Constant
related_concepts.definition: The value of the reaction quotient when the reaction has reached equilibrium.

subject: Chemistry
title: Carnot Engine Efficiency
description: Maximum theoretical efficiency of a heat engine. Temperatures must be in Kelvin.
derivation:
Efficiency (\(\eta\)) is work output divided by heat input.
\(\eta = \frac{W}{Q_{hot}} = \frac{Q_{hot} - Q_{cold}}{Q_{hot}} = 1 - \frac{Q_{cold}}{Q_{hot}}\)
For a Carnot (reversible) cycle, heat is proportional to temperature (\(Q \propto T\)).
Therefore:
\(\eta = 1 - \frac{T_{cold}}{T_{hot}}\)

related_concepts.name: Carnot Cycle
related_concepts.definition: An ideal thermodynamic cycle consisting of two isothermal and two adiabatic processes.

subject: Chemistry
title: Kp and Kc Relation
description: Relationship between equilibrium constants. \(\Delta n_g\): moles gaseous products - reactants.
derivation:
Ideal Gas Law: \(P = (n/V)RT = CRT\).
For reaction \(aA \rightleftharpoons bB\):
\(K_p = \frac{(P_B)^b}{(P_A)^a} = \frac{([B]RT)^b}{([A]RT)^a}\)
Factor out concentrations and RT:
\(K_p = \frac{[B]^b}{[A]^a} (RT)^{b-a}\)
Since \(K_c = \frac{[B]^b}{[A]^a}\) and \(\Delta n_g = b-a\):
\(K_p = K_c (RT)^{\Delta n_g}\)

related_concepts.name: Partial Pressure
related_concepts.definition: The pressure hypothetically exerted if this gas alone occupied the entire volume.

subject: Chemistry
title: Reaction Quotient (Q)
description: Predicts reaction direction. \(Q < K\): forward, \(Q > K\): backward.
derivation:
The expression for Q is identical to the Equilibrium Constant K.
However, K uses concentrations *at equilibrium*.
Q uses concentrations at *any specific instant* in time.
Comparison:
If \(Q < K\), numerator (products) is too small \(\rightarrow\) Shift Right.
If \(Q > K\), numerator is too large \(\rightarrow\) Shift Left.

related_concepts.name: Le Chatelier's Principle
related_concepts.definition: If a constraint is applied to a system in equilibrium, the equilibrium shifts to counteract it.

subject: Chemistry
title: pH Definition
description: Logarithmic scale for acidity. For neutral water at 25C, pH = 7.
derivation:
Concentrations of \(H^+\) can vary over many orders of magnitude (e.g., \(10^{-1}\) to \(10^{-14}\)).
To make these numbers manageable, Sorensen introduced the negative log scale.
Definition:
\(pH = -\log_{10} a_{H^+} \approx -\log_{10} [H^+]\)
The negative sign ensures that as concentration drops, pH increases (becomes less acidic).

related_concepts.name: Auto-ionization of Water
related_concepts.definition: \(2H_2O \rightleftharpoons H_3O^+ + OH^-\). \(K_w = 10^{-14}\) at 25C.

subject: Chemistry
title: Ostwald's Dilution Law
description: Degree of dissociation for weak electrolytes. Valid when \(\alpha \ll 1\).
derivation:
Consider weak acid HA with conc C.
Equilibrium: \(HA \rightleftharpoons H^+ + A^-\)
Conc: \(C(1-\alpha)\) ... \(C\alpha\) ... \(C\alpha\)
\(K_a = \frac{[H^+][A^-]}{[HA]} = \frac{(C\alpha)(C\alpha)}{C(1-\alpha)} = \frac{C\alpha^2}{1-\alpha}\)
For weak electrolytes, \(\alpha\) is very small, so \(1-\alpha \approx 1\).
\(K_a \approx C\alpha^2 \implies \alpha = \sqrt{K_a/C}\)

related_concepts.name: Degree of Dissociation
related_concepts.definition: The fraction of the total number of solute molecules that dissociate into ions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Henderson-Hasselbalch (Acidic)
description: Calculates pH of an acidic buffer solution.
derivation:
From the dissociation of weak acid HA:
\(K_a = \frac{[H^+][A^-]}{[HA]}\)
Take negative log of both sides:
\(-\log K_a = -\log [H^+] - \log \frac{[A^-]}{[HA]}\)
Substitute definitions (\(pK_a\) and \(pH\)):
\(pK_a = pH - \log \frac{[A^-]}{[HA]}\)
Rearrange (Note: \([A^-]\) comes from Salt):
\(pH = pK_a + \log \frac{[\text{Salt}]}{[\text{Acid}]}\)

related_concepts.name: Buffer Solution
related_concepts.definition: A solution that resists changes in pH upon the addition of small amounts of acid or base.

subject: Chemistry
title: Henderson-Hasselbalch (Basic)
description: Calculates pOH of a basic buffer solution. Use \(pH = 14 - pOH\).
derivation:
Similar to acidic buffers, start with weak base BOH:
\(K_b = \frac{[B^+][OH^-]}{[BOH]}\)
Take negative log:
\(-\log K_b = -\log [OH^-] - \log \frac{[B^+]}{[BOH]}\)
\(pK_b = pOH - \log \frac{[\text{Salt}]}{[\text{Base}]}\)
Rearrange:
\(pOH = pK_b + \log \frac{[\text{Salt}]}{[\text{Base}]}\)

related_concepts.name: pOH
related_concepts.definition: The negative logarithm of the hydroxide ion concentration.

subject: Chemistry
title: Solubility Product (Ksp)
description: Equilibrium constant for a solid dissolving into ions. Precipitation occurs if \(IP > K_{sp}\).
derivation:
For a sparingly soluble salt \(A_x B_y(s)\):
\(A_x B_y(s) \rightleftharpoons x A^{y+}(aq) + y B^{x-}(aq)\)
The equilibrium constant expression is:
\(K = \frac{[A^{y+}]^x [B^{x-}]^y}{[A_x B_y(s)]}\)
The concentration of a pure solid is constant (conventionally 1).
Therefore:
\(K_{sp} = [A^{y+}]^x [B^{x-}]^y\)

related_concepts.name: Common Ion Effect
related_concepts.definition: The suppression of the degree of dissociation of a weak electrolyte by adding a strong electrolyte containing a common ion.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydrolysis (Weak Acid-Strong Base)
description: pH of a salt solution like Sodium Acetate. Solution is basic (pH > 7).
derivation:
Anion \(A^-\)(from weak acid) reacts with water:
\(A^- + H_2O \rightleftharpoons HA + OH^-\)
This generates \(OH^-\), making the solution basic.
Using hydrolysis constant \(K_h = K_w/K_a\) and approx \([OH^-] = C\cdot h\):
\([OH^-] = \sqrt{K_h C} = \sqrt{\frac{K_w C}{K_a}}\)
Taking negative logs to find pOH, then pH:
\(pH = \frac{1}{2}pK_w + \frac{1}{2}pK_a + \frac{1}{2}\log C\)

related_concepts.name: Salt Hydrolysis
related_concepts.definition: Reaction of cation or anion of a salt with water to produce acidic or alkaline solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydrolysis (Strong Acid-Weak Base)
description: pH of a salt solution like Ammonium Chloride. Solution is acidic (pH < 7).
derivation:
Cation \(B^+\)(from weak base) reacts with water:
\(B^+ + H_2O \rightleftharpoons BOH + H^+\)
This generates \(H^+\), making the solution acidic.
\([H^+] = \sqrt{K_h C} = \sqrt{\frac{K_w C}{K_b}}\)
Taking -log:
\(pH = \frac{1}{2}pK_w - \frac{1}{2}pK_b - \frac{1}{2}\log C\)
Since \(pK_w = 14\) (at 25C), \(\frac{1}{2}pK_w = 7\).

related_concepts.name: Conjugate Acid
related_concepts.definition: A species formed by the reception of a proton (H+) by a base.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydrolysis (Weak Acid-Weak Base)
description: pH of salt like Ammonium Acetate. Independent of concentration.
derivation:
Both ions hydrolyze.
\([H^+] = K_a \sqrt{\frac{K_w}{K_a K_b}}\)
Taking negative logs:
\(pH = \frac{1}{2}pK_w + \frac{1}{2}pK_a - \frac{1}{2}pK_b\)
At 25C, \(pK_w = 14\), so:
\(pH = 7 + 0.5(pK_a - pK_b)\)
Note that the concentration term \(C\) cancels out.

related_concepts.name: Neutral Salt
related_concepts.definition: If \(K_a = K_b\), the solution is neutral (pH = 7).

subject: Chemistry
title: Nernst Equation
description: Calculates cell potential at non-standard conditions (at 298K).
derivation:
Thermodynamics relation: \(\Delta G = \Delta G^\circ + RT \ln Q\)
Relate Free Energy to Potential: \(\Delta G = -nFE\)
Substitute:
\(-nFE = -nFE^\circ + RT \ln Q\)
Divide by \(-nF\):
\(E = E^\circ - \frac{RT}{nF} \ln Q\)
Convert natural log to log base 10 (\(\ln x = 2.303 \log x\)) and substitute constants (R, T=298K, F) to get 0.059.

related_concepts.name: Standard Electrode Potential
related_concepts.definition: The potential of a half-cell under standard conditions relative to the Standard Hydrogen Electrode.

related_concepts.name: Reaction Quotient (Q)
related_concepts.definition: Ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations at a specific moment.

subject: Chemistry
title: Gibbs Energy & EMF
description: Relationship between standard thermodynamic potential and cell potential. \(F\): Faraday constant (96500 C/mol).
derivation:
Electrical work done by a galvanic cell is the product of charge and potential difference.
Charge flowed for \(n\) moles of electrons: \(Q = nF\)
Max Work done \(w_{max} = Q \times E^\circ_{cell} = nFE^\circ_{cell}\)
Thermodynamically, maximum useful work comes from the decrease in Gibbs Free Energy:
\(w_{max} = -\Delta G^\circ\)
Therefore:
\(\Delta G^\circ = -nFE^\circ_{cell}\)

related_concepts.name: Spontaneous Reaction
related_concepts.definition: Requires \(\Delta G < 0\), which implies \(E_{cell} > 0\).

related_concepts.name: Faraday Constant
related_concepts.definition: The magnitude of electric charge per mole of electrons.

subject: Chemistry
title: Faraday's First Law
description: Mass of substance deposited at an electrode. \(E_{eq}\): equivalent weight, \(I\): current, \(t\): time.
derivation:
The mass (\(w\)) deposited is directly proportional to the quantity of electricity (\(Q\)) passed.
\(w \propto Q\)
Since \(Q = I \times t\) (Current \(\times\) Time):
\(w = Z \cdot I \cdot t\)
Where \(Z\) is the Electrochemical Equivalent.
\(Z = \frac{\text{Equivalent Weight}}{F} = \frac{E_{eq}}{96500}\)
Substituting \(Z\):
\(w = \frac{E_{eq} I t}{96500}\)

related_concepts.name: Equivalent Weight
related_concepts.definition: Molar Mass divided by the n-factor (valency factor).

subject: Chemistry
title: Molar Conductivity
description: Conducting power of all ions produced by 1 mole of electrolyte. \(\kappa\): specific conductance [S/cm].
derivation:
Conductivity (\(\kappa\)) is the conductance of a 1 cm\(^3\) solution.
Molar conductivity is the conductance of volume \(V\) containing 1 mole of electrolyte.
\(\Lambda_m = \kappa \times V\)
If Molarity is \(M\) (mol/L), then the volume containing 1 mole is:
\(V = \frac{1000 \text{ cm}^3/L}{M}\)
Substituting \(V\):
\(\Lambda_m = \frac{\kappa \times 1000}{M}\)

related_concepts.name: Kohlrausch's Law
related_concepts.definition: Limiting molar conductivity of an electrolyte is the sum of the limiting ionic conductivities of the cation and anion.

subject: Chemistry
title: Raoult's Law (Volatile Liquids)
description: Total vapor pressure of a solution containing two volatile components. \(x\): mole fraction.
derivation:
According to Raoult's Law, the partial pressure of each component is proportional to its mole fraction.
\(P_A = P_A^\circ x_A\)
\(P_B = P_B^\circ x_B\)
According to Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures:
\(P_{total} = P_A + P_B\)
Substitute expressions:
\(P_{total} = P_A^\circ x_A + P_B^\circ x_B\)

related_concepts.name: Ideal Solution
related_concepts.definition: A solution that obeys Raoult's law over the entire range of concentration.

subject: Chemistry
title: Relative Lowering of Vapor Pressure
description: Colligative property. The relative drop in VP depends only on the mole fraction of non-volatile solute.
derivation:
For a solution with non-volatile solute (B) and solvent (A):
\(P_{solution} = P_A = P_A^\circ x_A\)
We know \(x_A + x_B = 1 \implies x_A = 1 - x_B\).
Substitute \(x_A\):
\(P = P^\circ (1 - x_B)\)
\(P = P^\circ - P^\circ x_B\)
Rearrange:
\(P^\circ x_B = P^\circ - P\)
\(x_B = \frac{P^\circ - P}{P^\circ}\)

related_concepts.name: Colligative Properties
related_concepts.definition: Properties that depend on the number of solute particles, not their identity.

subject: Chemistry
title: Elevation in Boiling Point
description: Boiling point increases when a non-volatile solute is added. \(i\): Van't Hoff factor, \(K_b\): ebullioscopic constant.
derivation:
The addition of non-volatile solute lowers vapor pressure.
The solution must be heated to a higher temperature to match atmospheric pressure.
For dilute solutions, the elevation is proportional to molality (\(m\)):
\(\Delta T_b \propto m\)
\(\Delta T_b = K_b m\)
Incorporating dissociation/association factor \(i\):
\(\Delta T_b = i K_b m\)

related_concepts.name: Ebullioscopic Constant
related_concepts.definition: The elevation in boiling point for a 1 molal solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Depression in Freezing Point
description: Freezing point decreases upon solute addition. \(K_f\): cryoscopic constant.
derivation:
At freezing point, solid solvent and liquid solvent are in equilibrium (have same vapor pressure).
Solute lowers the liquid's VP, so the equilibrium curve intersects the solid VP curve at a lower T.
Similar to boiling point, for dilute solutions:
\(\Delta T_f \propto m\)
\(\Delta T_f = i K_f m\)

related_concepts.name: Cryoscopic Constant
related_concepts.definition: Depression in freezing point for a 1 molal solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Osmotic Pressure
description: Pressure required to stop osmosis. \(C\): molarity, \(R\): gas constant.
derivation:
Van't Hoff observed dilute solutions behave like ideal gases.
Ideal Gas Law: \(P V = n R T\)
Rearrange for Pressure (here \(\pi\)):
\(\pi = \frac{n}{V} R T\)
Since \(n/V = C\) (Molarity):
\(\pi = C R T\)
Including the Van't Hoff factor for particles:
\(\pi = i C R T\)

related_concepts.name: Isotonic Solutions
related_concepts.definition: Solutions having the same osmotic pressure at a given temperature.

subject: Chemistry
title: Van't Hoff Factor
description: Correction factor for dissociation. \(n\): particles per molecule, \(\alpha\): degree of dissociation.
derivation:
Consider electrolyte \(A_n \rightleftharpoons nA\).
Initial moles: 1
Equilibrium moles: \(1-\alpha\) (undissociated) + \(n\alpha\) (dissociated).
Total moles after dissociation = \(1 - \alpha + n\alpha\)
\(i = \frac{\text{Observed moles}}{\text{Theoretical moles}} = \frac{1 + (n-1)\alpha}{1}\)
\(i = 1 + (n-1)\alpha\)

related_concepts.name: Association
related_concepts.definition: When molecules join together (e.g., dimerization), \(i < 1\). Formula: \(i = 1 + (1/n - 1)\alpha\).

subject: Chemistry
title: Density of Unit Cell
description: Calculates density of crystal. \(Z\): atoms per cell, \(M\): molar mass, \(a\): edge length.
derivation:
Density is Mass per unit Volume.
Volume of cubic cell = \(a^3\).
Mass of cell = (No. of atoms) \(\times\) (Mass of 1 atom).
Mass of cell = \(Z \times m_{atom}\).
Since \(M = m_{atom} \times N_A\), then \(m_{atom} = M/N_A\).
Substitute:
\(\rho = \frac{Z \times (M/N_A)}{a^3} = \frac{ZM}{a^3 N_A}\)

related_concepts.name: Unit Cell
related_concepts.definition: The smallest repeating unit in a crystal lattice.

subject: Chemistry
title: Packing Efficiency (FCC/CCP)
description: Face Centered Cubic efficiency. Relation \(4r = a\sqrt{2}\).
derivation:
FCC has \(Z=4\) atoms.
Atoms touch along the face diagonal.
Face diagonal length = \(a\sqrt{2}\).
In terms of radius \(r\): \(4r = a\sqrt{2} \implies a = 2\sqrt{2}r\).
Volume of 4 spheres = \(4 \times \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\).
Total Volume = \(a^3 = (2\sqrt{2}r)^3 = 16\sqrt{2}r^3\).
Ratio = \(\frac{16/3 \pi r^3}{16\sqrt{2}r^3} = \frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}} \approx 0.74\)

related_concepts.name: Coordination Number (FCC)
related_concepts.definition: 12 (Each atom touches 12 nearest neighbors).

subject: Chemistry
title: Packing Efficiency (BCC)
description: Body Centered Cubic efficiency. Relation \(4r = a\sqrt{3}\).
derivation:
BCC has \(Z=2\) atoms.
Atoms touch along the body diagonal.
Body diagonal length = \(a\sqrt{3}\).
In terms of radius: \(4r = a\sqrt{3} \implies a = \frac{4r}{\sqrt{3}}\).
Volume of 2 spheres = \(2 \times \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\).
Total Volume = \(a^3 = (4r/\sqrt{3})^3\).
Calculating ratio yields \(\approx 0.68\).

related_concepts.name: Coordination Number (BCC)
related_concepts.definition: 8 (Each atom touches 8 nearest neighbors).

subject: Chemistry
title: Bragg's Equation
description: Condition for constructive interference in X-ray diffraction. \(d\): interplanar spacing.
derivation:
Consider X-rays reflecting off two parallel crystal planes separated by distance \(d\).
The ray hitting the second plane travels an extra distance.
Geometry shows this extra path length is \(d \sin \theta\) for incidence and \(d \sin \theta\) for reflection.
Total path difference = \(2d \sin \theta\).
For constructive interference, this must equal an integer number of wavelengths:
\(n\lambda = 2d \sin \theta\)

related_concepts.name: Diffraction
related_concepts.definition: The bending of waves around obstacles and spreading out, used here to determine crystal structure.

subject: Chemistry
title: Spin Only Magnetic Moment
description: Calculates magnetic nature. \(n\): number of unpaired electrons. BM: Bohr Magneton.
derivation:
The magnetic moment arises from electron spin.
The formula is derived from quantum mechanics where angular momentum depends on total spin quantum number \(S\).
\(\mu = \sqrt{4S(S+1)}\)
Since each unpaired electron contributes spin \(1/2\), total spin \(S = n/2\).
Substitute \(S\):
\(\mu = \sqrt{4(n/2)(n/2 + 1)}\)
\(\mu = \sqrt{n(n+2)}\)

related_concepts.name: Paramagnetic
related_concepts.definition: Substance with unpaired electrons, attracted by a magnetic field.

related_concepts.name: Diamagnetic
related_concepts.definition: Substance with all electrons paired, slightly repelled by a magnetic field.

subject: Chemistry
title: CFSE (Octahedral)
description: Crystal Field Stabilization Energy. \(P\): pairing energy.
derivation:
In an octahedral field, d-orbitals split into lower \(t_{2g}\) and higher \(e_g\).
The barycenter (average energy) is conserved.
\(t_{2g}\) orbitals stabilize by \(-0.4 \Delta_o\).
\(e_g\) orbitals destabilize by \(+0.6 \Delta_o\).
Total Energy = (Sum of electron contributions) + (Pairing energy if forced pairing occurs).
\(CFSE = (-0.4 t_{2g} + 0.6 e_g)\Delta_o\)

related_concepts.name: Spectrochemical Series
related_concepts.definition: A list of ligands ordered by the strength of the field splitting (\(\Delta\)) they produce.

subject: Chemistry
title: CFSE (Tetrahedral)
description: Relates splitting energy in tetrahedral field to octahedral field.
derivation:
In a tetrahedral field, only 4 ligands approach, compared to 6 in octahedral.
Also, ligands approach 'between' the axes, not directly along them.
The reduction in number of ligands reduces field by factor of \(2/3\).
The geometric angle approach reduces it by another \(2/3\).
Total factor: \(\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{2}{3} = \frac{4}{9}\).
Thus, \(\Delta_t \approx \frac{4}{9} \Delta_o\).

related_concepts.name: High Spin Complex
related_concepts.definition: Complexes where \(\Delta\) is small (weak field), favoring unpaired electrons over pairing.

subject: Chemistry
title: Van der Waals Equation
description: Equation of state for real gases correcting for intermolecular forces and molecular volume.
derivation:
Ideal Gas Law \(PV=nRT\) ignores molecular size and attraction.
1. Volume Correction: Molecules occupy space.
   Available volume = \(V_{container} - V_{molecules}\)
   \(V_{real} = V - nb\) (where \(b\) is excluded volume).
2. Pressure Correction: Attractive forces reduce impact on walls.
   \(P_{ideal} = P_{real} + p'\)
   Attraction depends on density squared (\(n/V\)).
   \(p' = a(n/V)^2\)
Combining both:
\((P + an^2/V^2)(V-nb) = nRT\)

related_concepts.name: Compressibility Factor (Z)
related_concepts.definition: The ratio \(PV/nRT\), indicating deviation from ideal behavior.

related_concepts.name: Critical Constants
related_concepts.definition: Temperature, pressure, and volume at the critical point where gas and liquid phases are indistinguishable.

subject: Chemistry
title: Root Mean Square Speed
description: Statistical measure of the magnitude of gas molecule velocity. \(M\): molar mass in kg/mol.
derivation:
From the Kinetic Molecular Theory of Gases:
Pressure equation: \(PV = \frac{1}{3} N m u_{rms}^2\)
Since \(N \times m = \text{Total Mass} = n \times M\):
\(PV = \frac{1}{3} n M u_{rms}^2\)
From Ideal Gas Law, substitute \(PV = nRT\):
\(nRT = \frac{1}{3} n M u_{rms}^2\)
Cancel \(n\) and rearrange:
\(u_{rms}^2 = \frac{3RT}{M} \implies u_{rms} = \sqrt{\frac{3RT}{M}}\)

related_concepts.name: Maxwell-Boltzmann Distribution
related_concepts.definition: A probability distribution used for describing particle speeds in ideal gases.

subject: Chemistry
title: Graham's Law of Effusion
description: Rate of effusion (r) is inversely proportional to the square root of molar mass.
derivation:
At a constant temperature, the average Kinetic Energy of two gases is equal.
\(KE_1 = KE_2\)
\(\frac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^2 = \frac{1}{2} m_2 v_2^2\)
Rearranging the velocities:
\(\frac{v_1^2}{v_2^2} = \frac{m_2}{m_1}\)
Since rate of effusion \(r\) is proportional to velocity \(v\):
\(\frac{r_1}{r_2} = \sqrt{\frac{M_2}{M_1}}\)

related_concepts.name: Effusion
related_concepts.definition: The process of gas molecules escaping through a tiny hole into a vacuum.

subject: Chemistry
title: Compressibility Factor
description: Factor indicating deviation from ideal behavior. \(Z=1\) for ideal gas.
derivation:
Defined to measure deviation from Ideal Gas Law.
For Ideal Gas: \(PV = nRT \implies Z = 1\).
For Real Gas:
If \(Z < 1\): Attractive forces dominate (gas is more compressible, easier to liquefy).
If \(Z > 1\): Repulsive forces dominate (gas is less compressible, difficult to liquefy).

related_concepts.name: Boyle Temperature
related_concepts.definition: The temperature at which a real gas behaves like an ideal gas over a range of pressure.

subject: Chemistry
title: Dalton's Law
description: Total pressure of a non-reacting gas mixture is the sum of partial pressures.
derivation:
Assume gases behave ideally and independently.
\(P_1 = n_1 RT/V\)
\(P_2 = n_2 RT/V\)
\(P_{total} = (n_1 + n_2 + ...) \frac{RT}{V}\)
\(P_{total} = P_1 + P_2 + ...\)
Partial Pressure \(P_i\) is related to mole fraction \(x_i = n_i/n_{total}\):
\(P_i = x_i P_{total}\)

related_concepts.name: Partial Pressure
related_concepts.definition: The pressure that a gas would exert if it were present alone in the container.

subject: Chemistry
title: Freundlich Isotherm
description: Empirical relationship for adsorption extent at moderate pressures. \(n > 1\).
derivation:
Based on experimental observation of physical adsorption.
Plotting \(\log(x/m)\) vs \(\log P\) gives a straight line.
\(\log \frac{x}{m} = \log k + \frac{1}{n} \log P\)
Slope = \(1/n\) and Intercept = \(\log k\).
At low pressure, graph is linear (\(1/n = 1\)).
At high pressure, graph flattens (\(1/n = 0\)).

related_concepts.name: Physisorption
related_concepts.definition: Adsorption involving weak van der Waals forces.

subject: Chemistry
title: Langmuir Isotherm
description: Model for monolayer adsorption. \(\theta\): fractional coverage.
derivation:
Assumes dynamic equilibrium between adsorption and desorption.
Rate of Adsorption \(\propto P(1-\theta)\) (Pressure \(\times\) vacant sites).
Rate of Desorption \(\propto \theta\) (Occupied sites).
At equilibrium: \(k_a P(1-\theta) = k_d \theta\)
\(k_a P - k_a P \theta = k_d \theta\)
\(k_a P = \theta (k_d + k_a P)\)
\(\theta = \frac{k_a P}{k_d + k_a P} = \frac{(k_a/k_d)P}{1 + (k_a/k_d)P}\)

related_concepts.name: Chemisorption
related_concepts.definition: Adsorption involving strong chemical bonds.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hardy-Schulze Rule
description: Coagulating power increases with the valency \(Z\) of the oppositely charged ion.
derivation:
Coagulation occurs when charge on colloid is neutralized.
Higher valency ions (e.g., \(Al^{3+}\) vs \(Na^+\)) compress the electric double layer more effectively.
The critical coagulation concentration (CCC) decreases roughly as the inverse sixth power of valency.
\(CCC \propto 1/Z^6\)
Power is inverse of CCC.

related_concepts.name: Flocculation
related_concepts.definition: The process where colloids come out of suspension in the form of floc or flake.

subject: Chemistry
title: Finkelstein Reaction
description: Halogen exchange to prepare Alkyl Iodides. Driven by precipitation of NaX.
derivation:
General Reaction: \(R-Cl + NaI \rightleftharpoons R-I + NaCl\)
Key Principle: Le Chatelier's Principle.
Solubility: NaI is soluble in acetone, but NaCl and NaBr are NOT.
Since NaCl precipitates out, the concentration of product decreases.
This shifts the equilibrium forward to replace it.

related_concepts.name: SN2 Mechanism
related_concepts.definition: This reaction typically proceeds via SN2, so \(1^\circ\) halides react fastest.

subject: Chemistry
title: Swarts Reaction
description: Synthesis of Alkyl Fluorides using metallic fluorides (AgF, Hg2F2, SbF3).
derivation:
Direct fluorination with \(F_2\) is explosive/uncontrollable.
Swarts reaction uses heavy metal fluorides for a milder exchange.
The driving force is the formation of stable metal bromide/chloride precipitates (like AgBr).
It is a substitution reaction where F replaces Cl or Br.

related_concepts.name: Transition Metal Catalysis
related_concepts.definition: Using d-block metals to facilitate reactions that are otherwise difficult.

subject: Chemistry
title: Sandmeyer Reaction
description: Substitution of diazonium group with Halogen using Copper(I) salts.
derivation:
1. Diazotization: Aniline + \(NaNO_2/HCl\) at 0-5°C forms Benzene Diazonium Chloride (\(Ph-N_2^+Cl^-\)).
2. Radical Transfer: The Cuprous ion (\(Cu^+\)) acts as a catalyst.
   Electron transfer from CuCl generates an aryl radical (\(Ph^\bullet\)).
   Radical captures Cl from CuCl2.
   Product \(Ph-Cl\) forms and \(N_2\) gas is released.

related_concepts.name: Diazonium Salt
related_concepts.definition: A group of organic compounds sharing a common functional group \(R-N_2^+ X^-\).

subject: Chemistry
title: Wurtz Reaction
description: Coupling of two alkyl halides to form a symmetrical alkane.
derivation:
Two proposed mechanisms:
1. Ionic: \(R-X + 2Na \rightarrow R^- Na^+ + NaX\).
   Then \(R^- (nucleophile)\) attacks \(R-X\) (SN2) to form \(R-R\).
2. Free Radical: \(R-X + Na \rightarrow R^\bullet + NaX\).
   Then \(R^\bullet + R^\bullet \rightarrow R-R\).
Requires Dry Ether to prevent Na reacting with moisture.

related_concepts.name: Wurtz-Fittig Reaction
related_concepts.definition: Coupling between an alkyl halide and an aryl halide to form alkylbenzene.

subject: Chemistry
title: Friedel-Crafts Alkylation
description: Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution to attach alkyl group to benzene ring.
derivation:
1. Generation of Electrophile:
   \(R-Cl + AlCl_3 \rightarrow R^+ + AlCl_4^-\)
   (Lewis Acid \(AlCl_3\) pulls Cl away).
2. Attack:
   Benzene pi electrons attack the carbocation \(R^+\).
3. Deprotonation:
   \(AlCl_4^-\)
 removes H from the ring to restore aromaticity, releasing HCl and regenerating \(AlCl_3\).

related_concepts.name: Carbocation Rearrangement
related_concepts.definition: Primary carbocations may rearrange to more stable secondary/tertiary forms before attacking benzene.

subject: Chemistry
title: Grignard Reagent
description: Formation of organomagnesium halide. Reverses polarity of Carbon (Umpolung).
derivation:
Mechanism involves Single Electron Transfer (SET) on the Mg surface.
\(R-X + \cdot Mg \cdot \rightarrow R^\bullet + \cdot MgX\)
\(R^\bullet + \cdot MgX \rightarrow R-Mg-X\)
Carbon becomes Nucleophilic (carbanion-like) because Mg is electropositive.
Must be kept anhydrous as \(R-Mg-X\) acts as a strong base with water: \(R-H + Mg(OH)X\).

related_concepts.name: Nucleophilic Addition
related_concepts.definition: Grignard reagents add to carbonyl carbons (aldehydes/ketones) to form alcohols.

subject: Chemistry
title: SN1 Mechanism
description: Unimolecular Nucleophilic Substitution. Favored by \(3^\circ\) halides and polar protic solvents.
derivation:
Step 1 (Slow/RDS): Leaving group departs, forming planar carbocation.
   \(R-X \rightarrow R^+ + X^-\)
Step 2 (Fast): Nucleophile attacks carbocation.
   \(R^+ + Nu^- \rightarrow R-Nu\)
Since \(R^+\) is planar, attack can happen from front or back, leading to Racemization.

related_concepts.name: Racemization
related_concepts.definition: Formation of a 50:50 mixture of enantiomers, resulting in zero optical rotation.

subject: Chemistry
title: SN2 Mechanism
description: Bimolecular Nucleophilic Substitution. Favored by \(1^\circ\) halides and polar aprotic solvents.
derivation:
Concerted one-step process.
1. Nucleophile attacks Carbon from the side opposite to the Leaving Group (Backside Attack).
2. Transition State: Carbon is temporarily pentavalent (bonded to both Nu and X).
3. Leaving group departs as bond to Nu forms fully.
Result: Walden Inversion (umbrella flip) of configuration.

related_concepts.name: Steric Hindrance
related_concepts.definition: Bulky groups block the nucleophile's path, slowing down SN2 reactions (Reason \(3^\circ\) don't do SN2).

subject: Chemistry
title: Dipole Moment
description: Vector quantity measuring bond polarity. \(q\): magnitude of charge, \(d\): distance.
derivation:
A dipole arises when electron density is unequal between two atoms.
Calculated as the product of partial charge (\(\delta\)) and bond length.
For polyatomic molecules, \(\mu_{net}\) is the vector sum of individual bond dipoles.
\(\mu_{net} = \sqrt{\mu_1^2 + \mu_2^2 + 2\mu_1\mu_2 \cos \theta}\)
Symmetrical molecules (e.g., \(CO_2, BF_3\)) have \(\mu = 0\).

related_concepts.name: Polar Molecule
related_concepts.definition: A molecule with a non-zero net dipole moment.

subject: Chemistry
title: Formal Charge
description: Theoretical charge on an atom in a molecule. \(V\): valence e-, \(L\): lone pair e-, \(S\): shared e-.
derivation:
Method to determine the most stable Lewis structure (lowest FC is best).
Formula logic:
1. Start with atom's group number (Valence, \(V\)).
2. Subtract all non-bonding electrons owned entirely by the atom (\(L\)).
3. Subtract half of the bonding electrons (\(S/2\)), assuming equal sharing.
\(FC = V - (L + S/2)\)

related_concepts.name: Lewis Structure
related_concepts.definition: Diagram showing bonding between atoms and lone pairs of electrons.

subject: Chemistry
title: Bond Order
description: Stability index from Molecular Orbital Theory. Higher BO = stronger bond.
derivation:
Bond Order represents the effective number of bonds.
\(N_b\): Number of electrons in Bonding Molecular Orbitals (Lower energy, stabilizing).
\(N_a\): Number of electrons in Antibonding Molecular Orbitals (Higher energy, destabilizing).
Net bonding interaction is excess of bonding over antibonding electrons, shared by 2 atoms.

related_concepts.name: Bond Length
related_concepts.definition: Inversely proportional to Bond Order (Higher BO = Shorter Bond).

subject: Chemistry
title: Hybridization (Steric Number)
description: Formula to predict hybridization. \(V\): Valence e-, \(M\): Monovalent atoms.
derivation:
Steric Number (SN) counts the number of electron domains around the central atom.
\(V\): Valence electrons of central atom.
\(M\): Add 1 for each monovalent atom (H, Cl, F) forming a sigma bond.
\(C\): Subtract charge if cation (lost electrons).
\(A\): Add charge if anion (gained electrons).
Result:
2=sp, 3=sp2, 4=sp3, 5=sp3d, 6=sp3d2.

related_concepts.name: VSEPR Theory
related_concepts.definition: Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion theory, used to predict geometry based on steric number.

subject: Chemistry
title: Percentage Ionic Character
description: Hannay-Smith equation. Estimates ionic character based on electronegativity diff (\(\Delta \chi\)).
derivation:
Empirical relation.
If \(\Delta \chi = 0\) (e.g., H-H), ionic character is 0%.
If \(\Delta \chi = 1.7\), ionic character is approx 50%.
Term 1 (\(16\Delta\chi\)) accounts for linear dependence.
Term 2 (\(3.5\Delta\chi^2\)) corrects for larger differences.

related_concepts.name: Electronegativity
related_concepts.definition: Tendency of an atom to attract a shared pair of electrons.

subject: Chemistry
title: Fajan's Rule
description: Rules determining covalent character in ionic bonds due to polarization.
derivation:
No bond is 100% ionic. Cation distorts anion's electron cloud (Polarization).
Favorable conditions for Covalent Character:
1. Small Cation (High charge density).
2. Large Anion (Electrons loosely held, easy to distort).
3. High Charge on either ion.
4. Pseudo-noble gas config (\(ns^2 np^6 nd^{10}\)) of cation (e.g., Cu+, Ag+).

related_concepts.name: Polarizability
related_concepts.definition: The ease with which an anion's electron cloud can be distorted.

subject: Chemistry
title: Lucas Test
description: Distinguishes \(1^\circ, 2^\circ, 3^\circ\) alcohols based on turbidity rate.
derivation:
Reaction proceeds via SN1 mechanism involving Carbocation intermediate.
Rate depends on Carbocation Stability: \(3^\circ > 2^\circ > 1^\circ\).
1. \(3^\circ\): Stable carbocation, reacts instantly \(\rightarrow\) Immediate turbidity (insoluble alkyl halide).
2. \(2^\circ\): Less stable, takes ~5 mins.
3. \(1^\circ\): Unstable, no reaction at room temp (requires heat).

related_concepts.name: Carbocation Stability
related_concepts.definition: Stability order: Tertiary > Secondary > Primary > Methyl.

subject: Chemistry
title: Reimer-Tiemann Reaction
description: Formylation of phenol at ortho position.
derivation:
1. Electrophile Generation: \(OH^-\) removes H from \(CHCl_3\), Cl leaves \(\rightarrow :CCl_2\) (Dichlorocarbene).
2. Attack: Phenoxide ion attacks electron-deficient \(:CCl_2\) at ortho position.
3. Hydrolysis: The \(-CHCl_2\) group is hydrolyzed by alkali to \(-CHO\).
4. Acidification gives o-hydroxybenzaldehyde.

related_concepts.name: Carbene
related_concepts.definition: A neutral reactive intermediate containing a divalent carbon with six valence electrons.

subject: Chemistry
title: Kolbe's Reaction
description: Carboxylation of phenol. Industrial method for Aspirin precursor.
derivation:
1. Phenol is treated with NaOH to form Phenoxide (stronger nucleophile).
2. Phenoxide attacks weak electrophile \(CO_2\) (O=C=O) at ortho position.
3. Tautomerization restores aromaticity.
4. Acidification yields Salicylic Acid (o-hydroxybenzoic acid).

related_concepts.name: Electrophilic Substitution
related_concepts.definition: A reaction where an electrophile replaces an atom (usually H) on an aromatic ring.

subject: Chemistry
title: Williamson Ether Synthesis
description: Preparation of symmetrical and asymmetrical ethers via SN2.
derivation:
Mechanism: SN2 attack.
Alkoxide ion (\(RO^-\)) acts as Nucleophile.
Alkyl Halide (\(RX\)) acts as Substrate.
Constraint: The Alkyl Halide must be Primary (\(1^\circ\)).
If RX is \(3^\circ\), Elimination dominates over Substitution (forming alkene instead of ether) because alkoxides are also strong bases.

related_concepts.name: Elimination Reaction
related_concepts.definition: Removal of atoms to form a double bond, competing with substitution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Dehydration of Alcohols
description: Elimination of water to form alkene. Mechanism involves carbocation.
derivation:
Mechanism:
1. Protonation: Alcohol accepts H+ \(\rightarrow R-OH_2^+\) (Good leaving group).
2. Formation of Carbocation (Slow): Water leaves \(\rightarrow R^+\).
3. Elimination: H+ is removed from adjacent carbon to form double bond.
Note: At lower temp (413K), substitution competes to form Ether.

related_concepts.name: Saytzeff Rule
related_concepts.definition: In elimination, the more substituted alkene (more stable) is the major product.

subject: Chemistry
title: Victor Meyer Test
description: Colorimetric test to distinguish primary, secondary, and tertiary alcohols.
derivation:
Reaction Sequence:
1. Alcohol \(\xrightarrow{P/I_2}\) Alkyl Iodide.
2. Alkyl Iodide \(\xrightarrow{AgNO_2}\) Nitroalkane.
3. Nitroalkane treated with \(HNO_2\) (Nitrous Acid) then NaOH.

Results:
- \(1^\circ\) (Primary): Forms Nitrolic Acid \(\rightarrow\) Dissolves in NaOH \(\rightarrow\) **Red** color.
- \(2^\circ\) (Secondary): Forms Pseudonitrole \(\rightarrow\) Insoluble \(\rightarrow\) **Blue** color.
- \(3^\circ\) (Tertiary): No H on \(\alpha\)-carbon \(\rightarrow\) No reaction with \(HNO_2\) \(\rightarrow\) **Colorless**.

related_concepts.name: Alpha Hydrogen
related_concepts.definition: A hydrogen atom attached to the carbon atom adjacent to a functional group.

subject: Chemistry
title: Rosenmund Reduction
description: Selective hydrogenation of acid chlorides to aldehydes using Lindlar's catalyst.
derivation:
Catalytic hydrogenation usually reduces carbonyls all the way to alcohols.
To stop at the Aldehyde stage, the catalyst activity is lowered ('poisoned').
Catalyst: Palladium (Pd) deposited on Barium Sulfate (\(BaSO_4\)).
Poison: Sulfur or Quinoline.
This prevents further reduction: \(RCHO \nrightarrow RCH_2OH\).

related_concepts.name: Lindlar's Catalyst
related_concepts.definition: A heterogeneous catalyst used for selective hydrogenation of alkynes to cis-alkenes.

subject: Chemistry
title: Stephen Reaction
description: Preparation of aldehydes from nitriles via an imine intermediate.
derivation:
1. Reduction: Stannous chloride (\(SnCl_2\)) and HCl generate nascent hydrogen.
   \(SnCl_2 + 2HCl \rightarrow SnCl_4 + 2[H]\)
2. Imine Formation: Nitrile (\(R-C\equiv N\)) is reduced to Imine hydrochloride (\(R-CH=NH\cdot HCl\)).
3. Hydrolysis: Boiling with water converts the imine to aldehyde.
   \(R-CH=NH + H_2O \rightarrow RCHO + NH_3\)

related_concepts.name: Partial Reduction
related_concepts.definition: Stopping a reduction reaction at an intermediate oxidation state.

subject: Chemistry
title: Etard Reaction
description: Oxidation of Toluene to Benzaldehyde using Chromyl Chloride.
derivation:
1. Chromyl chloride (\(CrO_2Cl_2\)) attacks the methyl group of toluene.
2. Formation of brown Chromium Complex (precipitate):
   \(Ph-CH(OCrOHCl_2)_2\)
3. Hydrolysis: The complex is decomposed by water to give Benzaldehyde.
Solvent \(CS_2\) or \(CCl_4\) is used as it is non-polar.

related_concepts.name: Mild Oxidation
related_concepts.definition: Oxidation that stops at the aldehyde/ketone stage without proceeding to carboxylic acid.

subject: Chemistry
title: Gatterman-Koch Reaction
description: Formylation of benzene ring (Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution).
derivation:
1. Generation of Electrophile:
   Carbon monoxide (CO) and HCl react in situ to form Formyl Chloride (unstable).
   \(CO + HCl \rightleftharpoons HCOCl\)
   Lewis acid \(AlCl_3\) helps generate the electrophile \([HCO]^+ \leftrightarrow [C^+=O]\).
2. Attack: Benzene attacks the formyl cation.
3. Restoration: Loss of proton restores aromaticity, yielding Benzaldehyde.

related_concepts.name: Friedel-Crafts Acylation
related_concepts.definition: Similar mechanism using RCOCl to add an acyl group.

subject: Chemistry
title: Clemmensen Reduction
description: Deoxygenation of carbonyl group to methylene. Uses Acidic medium.
derivation:
Mechanism involves electron transfer from Zinc metal surface.
1. Carbonyl oxygen is protonated by acid.
2. Zn donates electrons to Carbon, C-O bond breaks.
3. Sequential protonation and electron transfer reduce \(C=O\) to \(CH_2\).
Constraint: Cannot be used if the molecule contains acid-sensitive groups (like -OH, -C=C-).

related_concepts.name: Amalgam
related_concepts.definition: An alloy of mercury with another metal (Zn-Hg), used to moderate the reactivity of the metal.

subject: Chemistry
title: Wolff-Kishner Reduction
description: Deoxygenation of carbonyl group to methylene. Uses Basic medium.
derivation:
1. Hydrazone Formation: Ketone reacts with Hydrazine (\(NH_2NH_2\)).
   \(C=O + H_2NNH_2 \rightarrow C=N-NH_2\)
2. Base Catalysis: KOH removes protons from the -NH2 group.
3. Nitrogen Elimination: \(N_2\) gas leaves (entropy driver).
4. Protonation: The carbon picks up protons from solvent (Ethylene Glycol) to become \(CH_2\).

related_concepts.name: Nucleophilic Addition-Elimination
related_concepts.definition: Mechanism where nucleophile adds to C=O, followed by loss of water (e.g., imine formation).

subject: Chemistry
title: Aldol Condensation
description: Reaction of aldehydes/ketones with \(\alpha\)-hydrogen. Forms \(\beta\)-hydroxy aldehyde.
derivation:
1. Enolate Formation: Base (OH-) removes acidic \(\alpha\)-hydrogen.
   \(CH_3CHO \rightarrow [\cdot CH_2CHO]^-\)
2. Nucleophilic Attack: Enolate attacks the carbonyl carbon of a second molecule.
3. Protonation: Forms 'Aldol' (Aldehyde + Alcohol).
4. Condensation (Heating): Water is eliminated (E1cB mechanism) to form an \(\alpha,\beta\)-unsaturated aldehyde (stable due to conjugation).

related_concepts.name: Cross Aldol
related_concepts.definition: Condensation between two different aldehydes/ketones. Gives 4 products if both have alpha-H.

subject: Chemistry
title: Cannizzaro Reaction
description: Disproportionation (Self-Redox) of aldehydes with NO \(\alpha\)-hydrogen.
derivation:
1. Nucleophilic Attack: OH- attacks Carbonyl C (High conc NaOH drives this).
   Forms a dianion intermediate.
2. Hydride Transfer (RDS): A hydride ion (\(H^-\)) shifts from the intermediate to the carbonyl carbon of the second molecule.
3. Result: One molecule is Oxidized (Acid salt) and one is Reduced (Alcohol).
   \(HCHO \rightarrow HCOO^-\)
   \(HCHO \rightarrow CH_3OH\)

related_concepts.name: Disproportionation
related_concepts.definition: A redox reaction where the same element is simultaneously oxidized and reduced.

subject: Chemistry
title: HVZ Reaction
description: Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky. Halogenation at the \(\alpha\)-carbon of carboxylic acids.
derivation:
Mechanism relies on the formation of Acyl Halide.
1. P + \(X_2\) forms \(PX_3\), which converts Acid to Acid Halide (\(RCH_2COX\)).
2. Enolization: Acid halides enolize more easily than acids.
3. Halogenation: \(X_2\) attacks the enol to substitute alpha-H.
4. Hydrolysis: The acid halide hydrolyzes back to Carboxylic Acid upon workup.

related_concepts.name: Alpha Substitution
related_concepts.definition: Substitution reaction occurring at the carbon atom adjacent to the functional group.

subject: Chemistry
title: Soda-Lime Decarboxylation
description: Removal of \(CO_2\) to form an alkane with one less carbon atom.
derivation:
Mechanism involves Carbanion intermediate.
1. Heat causes loss of \(CO_2\) from the carboxylate ion.
2. Formation of unstable Carbanion (\(R^-\)).
3. Rapid protonation from moisture or solvent to form Alkane (\(R-H\)).
Role of CaO: Keeps NaOH dry (hygroscopic) and keeps the fusion mix porous.

related_concepts.name: Step Down Reaction
related_concepts.definition: A reaction series that reduces the length of the carbon chain.

subject: Chemistry
title: Glucose Structure
description: Aldohexose. D-Glucose is the most abundant monosaccharide.
derivation:
Evidence for structure:
1. Straight Chain: HI reduction gives n-hexane.
2. Carbonyl Group: Reacts with hydroxylamine (\(NH_2OH\)).
3. Aldehyde Group: Oxidized by Bromine water to Gluconic Acid.
4. Five -OH groups: Acetylation gives pentaacetate.
5. Primary -OH: Nitric acid oxidation gives Saccharic acid (dicarboxylic).

related_concepts.name: Anomers
related_concepts.definition: Isomers (alpha/beta) differing only in configuration at the hemiacetal carbon (C1).

subject: Chemistry
title: Peptide Bond Formation
description: Amide linkage joining amino acids in proteins.
derivation:
Condensation reaction between Carboxyl group of one amino acid and Amino group of another.
1. Nucleophilic attack of Nitrogen lone pair on Carbonyl carbon.
2. Elimination of a water molecule.
3. The C-N bond has partial double bond character due to resonance, making the peptide backbone planar.

related_concepts.name: Polypeptide
related_concepts.definition: A chain of many amino acids linked by peptide bonds (Protein primary structure).

subject: Chemistry
title: Zwitter Ion
description: Internal salt form of amino acids. Net charge is zero at Isoelectric Point (pI).
derivation:
Amino acids contain both acidic (-COOH) and basic (-NH2) groups.
1. In solution, the proton (H+) transfers from Acid to Base.
2. -COOH becomes -COO- (Carboxylate).
3. -NH2 becomes -NH3+ (Ammonium).
This makes amino acids amphoteric (react with both acids and bases).

related_concepts.name: Isoelectric Point (pI)
related_concepts.definition: The pH at which a molecule carries no net electrical charge.

subject: Chemistry
title: Nylon 6,6
description: Polyamide condensation polymer. '6,6' refers to carbons in each monomer.
derivation:
Reaction: Step-Growth Polymerization.
Monomers:
1. Adipic Acid: \(HOOC-(CH_2)_4-COOH\)
2. Hexamethylenediamine: \(H_2N-(CH_2)_6-NH_2\)
Process: Condensation with removal of water molecules.
Forms strong hydrogen bonds between chains (high tensile strength).

related_concepts.name: Condensation Polymer
related_concepts.definition: Polymer formed with the loss of a small molecule like water or HCl.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hoffmann Bromamide Degradation
description: Conversion of primary amide to primary amine with one less carbon.
derivation:
1. Bromination: Amide + \(Br_2/OH^-\) forms N-bromoamide.
2. Formation of Nitrene: Loss of HBr gives unstable Acyl Nitrene intermediate.
3. Rearrangement (RDS): Alkyl group (R) migrates from Carbon to Nitrogen.
   Forms Isocyanate (\(R-N=C=O\)).
4. Hydrolysis: Isocyanate reacts with KOH to release \(CO_2\) and form Amine \(R-NH_2\).

related_concepts.name: Intramolecular Rearrangement
related_concepts.definition: Reaction where a group moves from one atom to another within the same molecule.

subject: Chemistry
title: Carbylamine Reaction
description: Test for Primary Amines (Isocyanide Test). Produces foul smell.
derivation:
1. Electrophile Formation: Alpha-elimination of HCl from Chloroform gives Dichlorocarbene (\(:CCl_2\)).
2. Attack: Amine nitrogen attacks electron-deficient carbene.
3. Elimination: Loss of protons and Cl- ions results in Isocyanide (\(R-N^+\equiv C^-\)).
Only primary amines have 2 hydrogens available to be removed for this triple bond formation.

related_concepts.name: Alpha Elimination
related_concepts.definition: Removal of two atoms/groups from the same carbon atom.

subject: Chemistry
title: Effective Nuclear Charge
description: Net positive charge experienced by an electron. \(\sigma\): shielding constant.
derivation:
Outer electrons are pushed away by inner electrons (Shielding Effect).
Slater's Rules estimate \(\sigma\).
Trend:
- Across Period: Z increases by 1, \(\sigma\) increases by <1 (electrons added to same shell). So \(Z_{eff}\) Increases.
- Down Group: Z increases, but shells increase. \(Z_{eff}\) remains roughly constant.

related_concepts.name: Atomic Radius
related_concepts.definition: Inversely proportional to Z effective. Decreases across a period.

subject: Chemistry
title: Electron Gain Enthalpy (Cl vs F)
description: Energy released when adding an electron. Cl releases more energy than F.
derivation:
Expected Trend: F should be higher due to high Zeff.
Exception Reality:
1. Fluorine is extremely small (2p orbital).
2. Existing 7 valence electrons are crowded.
3. Inter-electronic repulsion resists the incoming electron.
4. Chlorine (3p) is larger, has less repulsion, and accepts electron more easily.

related_concepts.name: Electron Affinity
related_concepts.definition: The energy change when a neutral atom attracts an electron to become a negative ion.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hall-Heroult Process
description: Electrolytic reduction of Alumina to Aluminium.
derivation:
Pure Alumina (\(Al_2O_3\)) has high MP (2050°C) and low conductivity.
Solution:
1. Add Cryolite (\(Na_3AlF_6\)) and Fluorspar (\(CaF_2\)).
   - Lowers MP to ~900°C.
   - Increases conductivity.
2. Electrolysis:
   Cathode (Steel vessel + Graphite): \(Al^{3+} + 3e^- \rightarrow Al(l)\)
   Anode (Graphite rods): \(C(s) + O^{2-} \rightarrow CO/CO_2 + e^-\)

related_concepts.name: Electrometallurgy
related_concepts.definition: Process of reduction of metals using electricity, used for reactive metals (Na, Mg, Al).

subject: Chemistry
title: Van Arkel Method
description: Vapor phase refining for Zirconium and Titanium. Based on thermal decomposition.
derivation:
Principle: Impurity does not react with Iodine, or the iodide is non-volatile.
1. Formation (T1 ~ 870K): Impure metal is heated with Iodine.
   \(Zr(s) + 2I_2(g) \rightarrow ZrI_4(g)\) (Volatile Iodide).
2. Decomposition (T2 ~ 2075K): The gas is passed over a hot Tungsten filament.
   \(ZrI_4(g) \rightarrow Zr(s) + 2I_2(g)\)
   Pure metal deposits on the filament.

related_concepts.name: Vapor Phase Refining
related_concepts.definition: Purification method where metal is converted to a volatile compound and then decomposed.

subject: Chemistry
title: Mond Process
description: Purification of Nickel. Relies on formation of volatile Nickel Tetracarbonyl.
derivation:
1. Complexation: Impure Nickel reacts with Carbon Monoxide at moderate temp.
   \(Ni + 4CO \rightarrow Ni(CO)_4\)
   Impurities remain solid.
2. Decomposition: The volatile carbonyl is heated to higher temp.
   \(Ni(CO)_4 \rightarrow Ni \downarrow + 4CO \uparrow\)
   The CO gas is recycled.

related_concepts.name: Metal Carbonyls
related_concepts.definition: Coordination complexes of transition metals with carbon monoxide ligands.

subject: Chemistry
title: Haber Process
description: Industrial synthesis of Ammonia. Catalyst: Iron with Molybdenum promoter.
derivation:
According to Le Chatelier's Principle:
1. Concentration: High conc of reactants pushes equilibrium forward.
2. Pressure: Reaction reduces moles (4 mol \(\to\) 2 mol). High Pressure (200 atm) favors product.
3. Temperature: Reaction is Exothermic. Low Temperature favors product, but slows rate.
   Optimization: Moderate Temp (~700K) with Catalyst.

related_concepts.name: Le Chatelier's Principle
related_concepts.definition: If a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts to counteract the disturbance.

subject: Chemistry
title: Ostwald Process
description: Industrial preparation of Nitric Acid via catalytic oxidation of ammonia.
derivation:
Step 1: Catalytic Oxidation (Exothermic)
   \(NH_3\) oxidized to NO over Pt/Rh gauge at 500K, 9 bar.
Step 2: Oxidation to \(NO_2\)
   \(2NO + O_2 \rightleftharpoons 2NO_2\)
Step 3: Absorption in Water
   \(3NO_2 + H_2O \rightarrow 2HNO_3 + NO\)
   The NO produced is recycled.

related_concepts.name: Azeotrope
related_concepts.definition: Constant boiling mixture. Conc. HNO3 forms azeotrope at 68% by mass.

subject: Chemistry
title: Contact Process
description: Manufacture of Sulfuric Acid. Absorption of SO3 in acid prevents fog formation.
derivation:
1. Production of \(SO_2\) (burning sulfur).
2. Conversion to \(SO_3\) (Key Step):
   Reversible and Exothermic. Needs \(V_2O_5\) catalyst, 2 bar pressure, 720K.
3. Absorption:
   Direct reaction \(SO_3 + H_2O\) is too violent.
   Instead, \(SO_3\) is absorbed in 98% \(H_2SO_4\) to form Oleum (\(H_2S_2O_7\)).
   \(H_2S_2O_7 + H_2O \rightarrow 2H_2SO_4\)

related_concepts.name: Oleum
related_concepts.definition: Fuming sulfuric acid (Pyrosulfuric acid), mixture of H2SO4 and SO3.

subject: Chemistry
title: Interhalogen Compounds
description: Compounds formed between two different halogens. X is larger than X'.
derivation:
Formation: Direct combination or reaction of halogen with lower interhalogen.
Structure (VSEPR):
- \(XX'_3\) (e.g., \(ClF_3\)): sp3d, T-shaped (2 lone pairs).
- \(XX'_5\) (e.g., \(BrF_5\)): sp3d2, Square Pyramidal (1 lone pair).
- \(XX'_7\) (e.g., \(IF_7\)): sp3d3, Pentagonal Bipyramidal.
Reactivity: Bond \(X-X'\) is weaker than \(X-X\) (except F-F), making them highly reactive.

related_concepts.name: Pseudo-halide
related_concepts.definition: Polyatomic anions (like CN-, SCN-) that resemble halide ions in chemistry.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydrolysis of XeF6
description: Complete hydrolysis of Xenon Hexafluoride yields explosive Xenon Trioxide.
derivation:
Mechanism involves stepwise replacement of F atoms with O.
1. Partial: \(XeF_6 + H_2O \rightarrow XeOF_4 + 2HF\)
2. Partial: \(XeOF_4 + H_2O \rightarrow XeO_2F_2 + 2HF\)
3. Complete: \(XeO_2F_2 + H_2O \rightarrow XeO_3 + 2HF\)
\(XeO_3\) has Pyramidal structure (sp3, 1 lone pair).

related_concepts.name: Noble Gas Chemistry
related_concepts.definition: Study of compounds involving Group 18 elements, primarily Xenon due to its lower ionization energy.

subject: Chemistry
title: Holme's Signal
description: Signal used in ships. Uses spontaneous combustion of Phosphine.
derivation:
A container with Calcium Carbide (\(CaC_2\)) and Calcium Phosphide (\(Ca_3P_2\)) is thrown into the sea.
1. Water enters, reacting to release Acetylene (\(C_2H_2\)) and Phosphine (\(PH_3\)).
2. Impure \(PH_3\) (containing \(P_2H_4\)) catches fire spontaneously.
3. This ignites the Acetylene, producing a bright luminous flame.

related_concepts.name: Phosphine
related_concepts.definition: Toxic gas (PH3) with rotten fish smell. Weak base compared to Ammonia.

subject: Chemistry
title: Markownikoff's Rule
description: Addition to unsymmetrical alkene. Negative part of addendum goes to carbon with fewer hydrogens.
derivation:
Based on Carbocation Stability.
1. Electrophile (\(H^+\)) attacks alkene.
2. Possibility A: Forms \(1^\circ\) carbocation (\(CH_3-CH_2-CH_2^+\)). Unstable.
3. Possibility B: Forms \(2^\circ\) carbocation (\(CH_3-CH^+-CH_3\)). Stable.
4. Nucleophile (\(Br^-\)) attacks the stable carbocation.
Result: 2-Bromopropane (Major).

related_concepts.name: Hyperconjugation
related_concepts.definition: Stabilization interaction that delocalizes electrons, explaining carbocation stability order (3 > 2 > 1).

subject: Chemistry
title: Anti-Markownikoff (Kharasch Effect)
description: Free radical addition. Valid ONLY for HBr with Organic Peroxide.
derivation:
Mechanism: Free Radical Chain Reaction.
1. Initiation: Peroxide homolysis gives Alkoxy radical (\(RO^\bullet\)).
   \(RO^\bullet + HBr \rightarrow ROH + Br^\bullet\)
2. Propagation: \(Br^\bullet\) attacks alkene to form the MORE stable carbon radical.
   \(R-CH=CH_2 + Br^\bullet \rightarrow R-C^\bullet H-CH_2Br\) (Secondary Radical).
3. H-abstraction: Radical takes H from HBr.
   \(R-CH_2-CH_2Br\) + \(Br^\bullet\).

related_concepts.name: Homolysis
related_concepts.definition: Bond cleavage where each atom retains one electron, forming radicals.

subject: Chemistry
title: Ozonolysis (Reductive)
description: Cleavage of double bond to form Carbonyls. Zn prevents oxidation to acid.
derivation:
1. Addition: Ozone adds across double bond to form Molozonide (unstable), which rearranges to Ozonide.
2. Cleavage: Zn dust with water acts as a reducing agent.
   It reacts with the oxygen atom of the ozonide linkage: \(Zn + [O] \rightarrow ZnO\).
   The C-C bond breaks, forming two C=O bonds.
Without Zn, \(H_2O_2\) forms and oxidizes aldehydes.

related_concepts.name: Locating Double Bonds
related_concepts.definition: Ozonolysis is historically used to determine the position of unsaturation in unknown alkenes.

subject: Chemistry
title: Kolbe's Electrolysis
description: Electrochemical decarboxylation to form symmetric alkanes.
derivation:
Mechanism: Free Radical.
At Anode (Oxidation):
1. Acetate ion loses electron: \(2CH_3COO^- \rightarrow 2CH_3COO^\bullet + 2e^-\)
2. Decarboxylation: Unstable radical breaks down.
   \(2CH_3COO^\bullet \rightarrow 2CH_3^\bullet + 2CO_2\)
3. Dimerization: Methyl radicals combine.
   \(CH_3^\bullet + CH_3^\bullet \rightarrow C_2H_6\)
pH of solution increases as NaOH is formed at cathode.

related_concepts.name: Soda-Lime Process
related_concepts.definition: Alternative thermal decarboxylation method yielding alkane with one less carbon (R-H).

subject: Chemistry
title: Birch Reduction
description: Stereoselective reduction of internal alkynes to trans-alkenes.
derivation:
Mechanism: Dissolving Metal Reduction.
1. Na donates electron to alkyne \(\rightarrow\) Radical Anion.
2. Protonation by \(NH_3\) \(\rightarrow\) Vinyl Radical.
3. Second electron donation \(\rightarrow\) Vinyl Anion.
4. Second protonation \(\rightarrow\) Alkene.
Stereochemistry: The intermediate Vinyl Anion adopts a Trans geometry to minimize repulsion between the lone pair and the alkyl group.

related_concepts.name: Solvated Electron
related_concepts.definition: Free electron in solution (ammoniated electron), responsible for deep blue color and reducing nature.

subject: Chemistry
title: Lindlar's Catalyst
description: Stereoselective hydrogenation. Catalyst poisoned with Quinoline or Sulfur.
derivation:
Mechanism: Surface Catalysis.
1. Hydrogen adsorbs onto the Palladium surface.
2. Alkyne approaches the surface.
3. Two hydrogen atoms transfer to the alkyne from the *same side* (Syn-addition).
4. Poisoning (Quinoline) lowers catalyst activity, preventing further reduction to alkane.

related_concepts.name: Syn-Addition
related_concepts.definition: Addition of two substituents to the same side (face) of a double or triple bond.

subject: Chemistry
title: Aromatization
description: Conversion of alkanes (6+ carbons) into aromatic hydrocarbons at high T.
derivation:
Process involves Dehydrogenation and Cyclization.
n-Hexane passed over oxide catalyst (Cr, V, or Mo supported on Alumina).
1. Removal of Hydrogen allows ring closure.
2. Formation of conjugated double bonds achieves aromatic stability.
n-Heptane gives Toluene under same conditions.

related_concepts.name: Reforming
related_concepts.definition: Processing of hydrocarbons to improve fuel quality (octane number) often via aromatization.

subject: Chemistry
title: Kohlrausch's Law
description: Law of independent migration of ions at infinite dilution.
derivation:
At infinite dilution, the dissociation of electrolyte is complete and interionic effects disappear.
Each ion makes a definite contribution to the total molar conductivity, irrespective of the other ions present.
For \(A_x B_y\):
\(\Lambda_m^\circ = x \lambda^\circ_{A^+} + y \lambda^\circ_{B^-}\)
Used to calculate \(\Lambda_m^\circ\) for weak electrolytes (e.g., acetic acid) using strong electrolytes.

related_concepts.name: Infinite Dilution
related_concepts.definition: A theoretical state where concentration approaches zero and ions do not interact.

subject: Chemistry
title: Debye-Huckel-Onsager Equation
description: Describes conductivity variation for Strong Electrolytes.
derivation:
For strong electrolytes, ions are fully dissociated but interact.
As concentration (C) increases, conductivity decreases due to:
1. Relaxation Effect: Ionic atmosphere becomes asymmetric, retarding motion.
2. Electrophoretic Effect: Solvent molecules dragged by opposite ions retard motion.
Plot of \(\Lambda_m\) vs \(\sqrt{C}\) is linear with slope \(-A\).

related_concepts.name: Weak Electrolyte Graph
related_concepts.definition: Plot is a steep curve (rectangular hyperbola), not linear. Cannot find \(\Lambda_m^\circ\) by extrapolation.

subject: Chemistry
title: Efficiency of Galvanic Cell
description: Ratio of useful electrical work to the heat content (enthalpy) of the reaction.
derivation:
Thermodynamics of Cell:
Total energy change = Enthalpy change (\(\Delta H\)).
Useful work available (Electrical) = Gibbs Free Energy change (\(\Delta G\)).
Since \(\Delta G = -nFE_{cell}\):
Efficiency \(\eta = \frac{\text{Output}}{\text{Input}} = \frac{\Delta G}{\Delta H}\)
Typically \(\eta > 100\%\) is possible if cell absorbs heat from surroundings (endothermic).

related_concepts.name: Fuel Cell
related_concepts.definition: A cell converting chemical energy of fuel directly into electricity with high efficiency (~70%).

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of White Phosphorus
description: Discrete tetrahedral P4 molecules. Highly reactive and glows in dark (chemiluminescence).
derivation:
Structure:
4 Phosphorus atoms at corners of a regular tetrahedron.
Each P is bonded to 3 other P atoms.
Bond Angle (PPP) = 60°.
Strain:
Ideal angle for p-orbitals is 90° (or sp3 109.5°).
The deviation to 60° creates immense Angular Strain.
Result: P-P bonds are weak and easily broken, making White P highly reactive.

related_concepts.name: Red Phosphorus
related_concepts.definition: Polymeric structure formed by opening P4 rings. Less strained, less reactive, non-toxic.

subject: Chemistry
title: Basicity of Oxoacids (P)
description: Basicity depends on the number of ionizable -OH groups.
derivation:
Structure Logic:
Phosphorus forms sp3 hybrid orbitals (Tetrahedral).
One bond is always \(P=O\).
Rest are \(P-OH\) or \(P-H\).
- \(H_3PO_4\) (Orthophosphoric): 1 \(P=O\), 3 \(P-OH\). 3 H+ can release. Basicity = 3.
- \(H_3PO_3\) (Phosphorous): 1 \(P=O\), 2 \(P-OH\), 1 \(P-H\). Basicity = 2.
- \(H_3PO_2\) (Hypophosphorous): 1 \(P=O\), 1 \(P-OH\), 2 \(P-H\). Basicity = 1.

related_concepts.name: Reducing Property
related_concepts.definition: P-H bonds are responsible for reducing character. H3PO2 is a strong reducing agent.

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of XeF4
description: Xenon Tetrafluoride geometry via VSEPR theory.
derivation:
Electron Count:
Xe (Valence) = 8.
F (Monovalent) = 4.
Total Pairs = (8+4)/2 = 6.
Hybridization: \(sp^3d^2\) (Octahedral geometry).
Bond Pairs = 4 (Xe-F).
Lone Pairs = 6 - 4 = 2.
Arrangement: To minimize repulsion, the 2 Lone Pairs occupy axial positions (180° apart).
Shape: Square Planar.

related_concepts.name: VSEPR Theory
related_concepts.definition: Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion theory predicts geometry based on minimizing e- pair repulsion.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydrolysis of NCl3
description: Nitrogen Trichloride hydrolyzes explosively. NF3 does NOT hydrolyze.
derivation:
Reason for Hydrolysis:
Chlorine has vacant d-orbitals.
Water oxygen (Nucleophile) attacks the Cl atom.
Intermediate forms, N-Cl bond breaks.
\(H\) goes to \(N\), \(OH\) goes to \(Cl\).
Repeat 3 times \(\rightarrow NH_3 + 3HOCl\).
Contrast \(NF_3\): Fluorine has NO d-orbitals, and C-F bond is strong, so no hydrolysis.

related_concepts.name: Orbital Availability
related_concepts.definition: Absence of d-orbitals in Period 2 elements limits their covalency and reactivity patterns.

subject: Chemistry
title: Magnetic Moment
description: Spin-only magnetic moment. \(n\): unpaired electrons.
derivation:
Magnetic moment arises from electron spin and orbital motion.
For 3d series, orbital contribution is quenched by crystal field.
Only spin contributes.
Spin Angular Momentum \(S = n/2\).
Formula: \(\mu = \sqrt{4S(S+1)} = \sqrt{n(n+2)}\).
Example: \(Fe^{3+} ([Ar]3d^5)\) has n=5. \(\mu = \sqrt{35} \approx 5.92\) BM.

related_concepts.name: Diamagnetism
related_concepts.definition: Condition where all electrons are paired (n=0, \(\mu=0\)), leading to repulsion by magnetic field.

subject: Chemistry
title: Chromyl Chloride Test
description: Confirmatory test for Chloride ions. Uses K2Cr2O7 and Conc H2SO4.
derivation:
1. Formation of Chromic Acid in situ: \(K_2Cr_2O_7 + H_2SO_4 \rightarrow CrO_3\).
2. Reaction with Chloride: \(CrO_3 + 2HCl \rightarrow CrO_2Cl_2 + H_2O\).
   \(CrO_2Cl_2\) is Chromyl Chloride (Deep Red Vapors).
3. Confirmation: Vapors passed into NaOH give yellow solution (\(Na_2CrO_4\)).
   \(CrO_2Cl_2 + 4OH^- \rightarrow CrO_4^{2-} + 2Cl^- + 2H_2O\).

related_concepts.name: Qualitative Analysis
related_concepts.definition: Branch of chemistry dealing with identification of ions/compounds.

subject: Chemistry
title: KMnO4 Titration (Acidic)
description: Permanganate as oxidizing agent in acidic medium. n-factor = 5.
derivation:
Oxidation State Change:
Reactant: \(MnO_4^-\), Mn is +7.
Product: \(Mn^{2+}\), Mn is +2.
Change = \(7 - 2 = 5\) electrons gained.
Equivalent Weight = Molar Mass / 5.
Indicator: KMnO4 acts as a self-indicator (Purple to Colorless).

related_concepts.name: Redox Titration
related_concepts.definition: Titration based on a redox reaction between analyte and titrant.

subject: Chemistry
title: Lanthanoid Contraction
