description: Steady decrease in atomic size along Lanthanoids causes 4d and 5d elements to have similar radii.
derivation:
Cause: Poor Shielding of 4f electrons.
1. As we move from La to Lu, electrons enter 4f subshell.
2. f-orbitals are diffuse and shield the nucleus poorly.
3. Nuclear charge (Z) increases by 1 each step.
4. Result: Effective Nuclear Charge (Zeff) increases significantly, pulling shells closer.
Consequence: The normal size increase down a group (4d to 5d) is cancelled by this contraction.

related_concepts.name: Chemical Twins
related_concepts.definition: Elements like Zr/Hf or Nb/Ta having identical size and properties, making separation difficult.

subject: Chemistry
title: Inductive Effect (+I)
description: Electron Releasing Groups (ERG). Stabilize carbocations, destabilize carbanions.
derivation:
Mechanism: Partial shifting of sigma electrons.
Alkyl groups are electron releasing.
Reason: Higher electron density on Hydrogen/Carbon relative to the substituted center (or Hyperconjugation overlap).
More branching = More carbons pushing electrons = Stronger +I effect.
Application: Tertiary alcohols are less acidic than primary because +I destabilizes the alkoxide ion.

related_concepts.name: Permanent Effect
related_concepts.definition: Inductive effect operates permanently in the ground state of the molecule.

subject: Chemistry
title: Inductive Effect Order (-I)
visual_data: NF_3^+ > NO_2 > CN > F > Cl > Br > I
description: Electron Withdrawing Groups (EWG). Increases acidity of carboxylic acids by stabilizing the carboxylate ion.
derivation:
Mechanism: Sigma bond electron displacement towards more electronegative atom.
1. Cationic poles (\(N^+\)) are the strongest withdrawers due to electrostatic attraction.
2. \(NO_2\) and \(CN\) have strong electronegativity and sp/sp2 character.
3. Halogens follow electronegativity order (F > Cl > Br > I).
Effect decays rapidly with distance (negligible after 3 carbons).

related_concepts.name: Acid Strength
related_concepts.definition: Directly proportional to -I effect strength of substituents.

subject: Chemistry
title: Mesomeric Effect (+M)
visual_data: O^- > NH_2 > OH > OR > NHCOR > Ph
description: Electron Donating Groups via Resonance. Activates benzene ring towards electrophilic attack.
derivation:
Groups with Lone Pairs can donate electrons into a conjugated system.
1. \(O^-\): Full negative charge, strongest donor.
2. \(NH_2\) vs \(OH\): N is less electronegative than O, so it holds lone pairs loosely and donates better.
3. \(NHCOR\): The lone pair on N is cross-conjugated with the carbonyl group, reducing donation to the ring.

related_concepts.name: Ortho-Para Director
related_concepts.definition: Groups that increase electron density specifically at ortho and para positions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hyperconjugation
description: No-bond resonance. Stabilizes carbocations and alkenes.
derivation:
Orbital Overlap:
Interaction between the filled \(\sigma\)-orbital of the \(C_\alpha-H\) bond and the empty p-orbital of the carbocation (or \(\pi^*\) of alkene).
Electrons delocalize from the bond into the empty orbital.
More \(\alpha\)-hydrogens \(\rightarrow\) More contributing structures \(\rightarrow\) Higher Stability.
Order: \((CH_3)_3C^+ > (CH_3)_2CH^+ > CH_3CH_2^+ > CH_3^+\).

related_concepts.name: Baker-Nathan Effect
related_concepts.definition: Another name for Hyperconjugation.

subject: Chemistry
title: Heat of Hydrogenation
description: Energy released when 1 mole of alkene is hydrogenated. Measure of stability.
derivation:
Hydrogenation is Exothermic.
\(\text{Alkene} + H_2 \rightarrow \text{Alkane} + \text{Heat}\)
Since the product (Alkane) energy is fixed for isomers:
A more stable alkene has lower potential energy to start with.
Therefore, the difference (Heat Released) is smaller.
Trans-2-butene is more stable than Cis-2-butene \(\rightarrow\) Trans has lower HOH.

related_concepts.name: Steric Hindrance
related_concepts.definition: Repulsion between groups in cis-alkenes raises energy, increasing HOH.

subject: Chemistry
title: Aromaticity (Huckel's Rule)
description: Criteria for aromatic stability. System must be Cyclic, Planar, and Fully Conjugated.
derivation:
Molecular Orbital Theory:
In cyclic conjugated systems, stability arises when all bonding MOs are filled and anti-bonding are empty.
This configuration occurs with \(4n+2\) pi electrons (2, 6, 10, 14...).
Example: Benzene (6 pi e-, n=1) is aromatic.
Cyclobutadiene (4 pi e-) is Anti-aromatic.

related_concepts.name: Resonance Energy
related_concepts.definition: The difference in energy between the real hybrid structure and the most stable hypothetical contributor.

subject: Chemistry
title: Ortho Effect
description: Ortho-substituted benzoic acids are strongest acids, regardless of group nature.
derivation:
Steric Inhibition of Resonance (SIR):
1. Bulky group at ortho position forces the -COOH group out of the plane of the ring.
2. Resonance between benzene ring and -COOH is lost.
3. The electron-withdrawing benzene ring destabilizes the acid less (or the carboxylate is not destabilized by donation).
4. Main Factor: The carboxylate ion is stabilized by solvation, which is easier when twisted out of plane.

related_concepts.name: Benzoic Acid
related_concepts.definition: Simplest aromatic carboxylic acid.

subject: Chemistry
title: Lassaigne's Test (Nitrogen)
description: Detection of Nitrogen. Formation of Ferric Ferrocyanide.
derivation:
1. Sodium Fusion: \(Na + C + N \rightarrow NaCN\).
2. Add Ferrous Sulfate: \(FeSO_4 + 2NaCN \rightarrow Fe(CN)_2 + Na_2SO_4\).
   \(Fe(CN)_2 + 4NaCN \rightarrow Na_4[Fe(CN)_6]\) (Sodium Ferrocyanide).
3. Acidification/Oxidation: Some \(Fe^{2+}\) oxidizes to \(Fe^{3+}\).
4. Complex Formation: \(4Fe^{3+} + 3[Fe(CN)_6]^{4-} \rightarrow Fe_4[Fe(CN)_6]_3\).

related_concepts.name: Sodium Fusion Extract
related_concepts.definition: Ionic solution prepared by fusing organic compound with Na metal to convert covalent elements (N, S, X) to ions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Kjeldahl's Method
description: Quantitative estimation of Nitrogen via Ammonia conversion.
derivation:
1. Digestion: Compound + Conc \(H_2SO_4 \rightarrow (NH_4)_2SO_4\).
2. Distillation: Add Alkali (NaOH) \(\rightarrow\) Releases \(NH_3\) gas.
3. Titration: Absorb \(NH_3\) in known excess standard acid.
   Moles of N = Moles of \(NH_3\) = Moles of Acid Neutralized.
   Formula derived from equivalents: \(N_1 V_1 = N_2 V_2\).

related_concepts.name: Dumas Method
related_concepts.definition: Alternative N estimation where N is converted directly to N2 gas.

subject: Chemistry
title: Fehling's Test
description: Test for Aliphatic Aldehydes. Forms Red precipitate of Copper(I) Oxide.
derivation:
Reagents:
Fehling A: Aqueous \(CuSO_4\) (Blue).
Fehling B: Alkaline Sodium Potassium Tartrate (Rochelle Salt).
Reaction:
Aldehyde acts as reducing agent.
\(Cu^{2+} (Blue) \xrightarrow{reduction} Cu^+ (Red ppt)\).
Note: Aromatic aldehydes (Benzaldehyde) do NOT respond because the C=O bond is stabilized by resonance.

related_concepts.name: Reducing Sugar
related_concepts.definition: Sugars with free aldehyde/ketone groups that give positive Fehling's test.

subject: Chemistry
title: Iodoform Test
description: Specific test for Methyl Ketones (-COCH3) or Methyl Carbinols (-CH(OH)CH3).
derivation:
1. Oxidation (if alcohol): \(CH_3-CH(OH)-R \rightarrow CH_3-CO-R\).
2. Halogenation: Base catalyzed alpha-halogenation replaces all H in \(CH_3\) with I.
   \(R-CO-CH_3 \rightarrow R-CO-CI_3\).
3. Hydrolysis: The electron-withdrawing \(CI_3\) group makes the carbonyl carbon susceptible to attack by \(OH^-\).
   C-C bond cleaves to form \(CHI_3\) (Yellow ppt) and Acid Salt.

related_concepts.name: Haloform Reaction
related_concepts.definition: General term for reaction with Cl2, Br2, or I2 to form CHX3.

subject: Chemistry
title: Group 0 (Zero Group)
description: Detection of Ammonium ion. Ammonia gas turns Red Litmus Blue and gives white fumes with HCl.
derivation:
Principle: Ammonium salts are weak acid salts.
Reaction with a strong base (NaOH) liberates the weak base (Ammonia).
Confirmatory Test (Nessler's Reagent):
\(2K_2[HgI_4] + NH_3 + 3KOH \rightarrow H_2N-Hg-O-Hg-I\) (Brown ppt, Iodide of Millon's base).

related_concepts.name: Nessler's Reagent
related_concepts.definition: Alkaline solution of Potassium Tetraiodomercurate(II).

subject: Chemistry
title: Group 2 (Acidic Radicals)
visual_data: K_{sp} \text{ Principle: Low } K_{sp} \text{ sulfides precipitate in acid.}
description: Reagent: H2S in Dilute HCl. Precipitates Cu, Pb, Hg, Cd, As, Sb, Sn.
derivation:
Common Ion Effect:
HCl provides high concentration of \(H^+\).
\(H_2S \rightleftharpoons 2H^+ + S^{2-}\).
High \([H^+]\) shifts equilibrium backward, suppressing \([S^{2-}]\).
Only sulfides with very low Solubility Product (\(K_{sp}\)) precipitate at this low sulfide concentration.
Group 4 sulfides (Zn, Mn, Ni) have higher \(K_{sp}\) and need basic medium to precipitate.

related_concepts.name: Solubility Product
related_concepts.definition: The equilibrium constant for a solid substance dissolving in an aqueous solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Group 3 Analysis
description: Precipitation as Hydroxides. Reagent: NH4OH in presence of NH4Cl.
derivation:
Buffer Action:
We need a controlled concentration of \(OH^-\).
If \(OH^-\)- is too high, Group 4 and 5 might coprecipitate.
\(NH_4Cl\) (Strong Electrolyte) suppresses ionization of \(NH_4OH\) (Weak Base) via Common Ion Effect.
This ensures \([OH^-]\) is just enough to exceed \(K_{sp}\) of trivalent metals (Fe, Al, Cr) but not divalent ones.

related_concepts.name: Buffer Solution
related_concepts.definition: A solution that resists change in pH. Here, NH4OH + NH4Cl acts as a basic buffer.

subject: Chemistry
title: Group 4 Analysis
description: Precipitation as Sulfides in Basic Medium. Reagent: H2S + NH4OH.
derivation:
Reverse of Group 2.
Base (\(NH_4OH\)) consumes \(H^+\) produced by \(H_2S\).
Equilibrium \(H_2S \rightleftharpoons 2H^+ + S^{2-}\) shifts forward.
\([S^{2-}]\) increases significantly.
High sulfide concentration exceeds the higher \(K_{sp}\) values of Zn, Mn, Ni, Co sulfides.

related_concepts.name: Kipp's Apparatus
related_concepts.definition: Laboratory apparatus used for preparing small volumes of gases like H2S.

subject: Chemistry
title: Group 5 Analysis
description: Precipitation as Carbonates. Reagent: (NH4)2CO3 + NH4OH.
derivation:
Role of \(NH_4OH\):
Prevents the precipitation of Magnesium Carbonate.
\(MgCO_3\) has a high solubility product.
Ammonium salts lower the \([CO_3^{2-}]\) slightly and form soluble complex with Mg, keeping it in solution for Group 6.

related_concepts.name: Flame Test
related_concepts.definition: Ba (Apple Green), Sr (Crimson Red), Ca (Brick Red).

subject: Chemistry
title: Group 6 Analysis (Mg)
description: Detection of Magnesium. Formation of white crystalline precipitate.
derivation:
Reagent: Disodium Hydrogen Phosphate (\(Na_2HPO_4\)) in ammoniacal solution.
Reaction:
1. \(Mg^{2+}\) does not precipitate in previous groups.
2. In the presence of \(NH_4OH\) and \(NH_4Cl\), phosphate ions precipitate Mg.
3. Product: Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate (White ppt).
Note: Solution must be cooled and scratched against the glass wall to induce crystallization.

related_concepts.name: Microcosmic Salt Bead
related_concepts.definition: Another test for Mg, forming a colorless bead.

subject: Chemistry
title: Brown Ring Test
description: Confirmatory test for Nitrate (\(NO_3^-\)). Formation of Nitroso Ferrous Sulphate complex.
derivation:
1. Reduction: Ferrous sulfate (\(Fe^{2+}\)) reduces Nitrate to Nitric Oxide (NO).
   \(NO_3^- + 3Fe^{2+} + 4H^+ \rightarrow NO + 3Fe^{3+} + 2H_2O\)
2. Complexation: The NO molecule coordinates with remaining \(Fe^{2+}\) ions.
   \([Fe(H_2O)_6]^{2+} + NO \rightarrow [Fe(H_2O)_5(NO)]^{2+} + H_2O\)
3. Observation: A brown ring forms at the junction of the solution and concentrated \(H_2SO_4\).

related_concepts.name: Charge Transfer
related_concepts.definition: The brown color arises from charge transfer between Fe and NO (Fe is +1, NO is +1 in complex).

subject: Chemistry
title: Nessler's Reagent Test
description: Detection of Ammonium (\(NH_4^+\)). Formation of Iodide of Millon's Base (Brown ppt).
derivation:
Reagent: \(K_2[HgI_4]\) (Potassium Tetraiodomercurate) + KOH (Alkaline).
Reaction:
1. \(2K_2[HgI_4] + NH_3 + 3KOH \rightarrow H_2N \cdot HgO \cdot HgI + 7KI + 2H_2O\)
   Structure is often written as \(NH_2-Hg-O-Hg-I\).
2. Sensitivity: Can detect trace amounts of ammonia (ppm level).

related_concepts.name: Zero Group
related_concepts.definition: Ammonium is analyzed separately before Group 1 because reagents for other groups introduce ammonium salts.

subject: Chemistry
title: Prussian Blue
description: Test for Ferric (\(Fe^{3+}\)) ions using Ferrocyanide.
derivation:
Reaction between \(Fe^{3+}\) and Potassium Ferrocyanide (\(K_4[Fe(CN)_6]\)).
Ion Exchange:
\(4Fe^{3+} + 3[Fe(CN)_6]^{4-} \rightarrow Fe_4[Fe(CN)_6]_3\)
Appearance: Deep blue precipitate.
Note: Often called 'Ferric Ferrocyanide'.

related_concepts.name: Mixed Valence Complex
related_concepts.definition: Compounds containing the same element in two different oxidation states.

subject: Chemistry
title: Turnbull's Blue
description: Test for Ferrous (\(Fe^{2+}\)) ions using Ferricyanide.
derivation:
Reaction between \(Fe^{2+}\) and Potassium Ferricyanide (\(K_3[Fe(CN)_6]\)).
Ion Exchange:
\(3Fe^{2+} + 2[Fe(CN)_6]^{3-} \rightarrow Fe_3[Fe(CN)_6]_2\)
Appearance: Deep blue precipitate.
Note: While historically distinct, X-ray diffraction suggests Prussian and Turnbull's blue have the same lattice structure.

related_concepts.name: Redox Stability
related_concepts.definition: Fe2+ with Ferrocyanide gives white ppt; Fe3+ with Ferricyanide gives brown solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Scarlet Red Precipitate
description: Confirmatory test for Mercuric ion (\(Hg^{2+}\)). Dissolves in excess reagent.
derivation:
1. Addition of KI: Reacts with \(Hg^{2+}\).
   \(Hg^{2+} + 2I^- \rightarrow HgI_2 \downarrow\) (Scarlet Red ppt).
2. Excess KI: Complex formation.
   \(HgI_2 + 2I^- \rightarrow [HgI_4]^{2-}\) (Soluble, Colorless).
   This complex is the precursor to Nessler's reagent.

related_concepts.name: Complexation
related_concepts.definition: The process of forming a coordination complex, often increasing solubility.

subject: Chemistry
title: Dimethyl Glyoxime (DMG) Test
description: Confirmatory for Nickel. Rosy Red precipitate. Stabilized by Hydrogen Bonding.
derivation:
1. Reagent: Dimethyl Glyoxime in ammoniacal (basic) medium.
2. Chelation: Two DMG molecules coordinate with one \(Ni^{2+}\).
3. Structure: Square Planar complex.
   Key Feature: Formation of Strong Intramolecular Hydrogen Bonds between the Oxygen atoms of the oxime groups, providing extra stability.

related_concepts.name: Chelate Effect
related_concepts.definition: Enhanced stability of complexes containing multidentate ligands.

subject: Chemistry
title: Borax Bead Test
description: Dry test for transition metals. Forms colored metaborates in oxidizing flame.
derivation:
1. Bead Formation: Heating Borax (\(Na_2B_4O_7 \cdot 10H_2O\)).
   Loses water \(\rightarrow\) Swells \(\rightarrow\) Transparent glassy bead (\(NaBO_2 + B_2O_3\)).
2. Color Formation: Boric Anhydride (\(B_2O_3\)) reacts with Metal Oxide.
   \(CuO + B_2O_3 \rightarrow Cu(BO_2)_2\) (Blue Bead).
   \(CoO + B_2O_3 \rightarrow Co(BO_2)_2\) (Deep Blue Bead).

related_concepts.name: Oxidizing/Reducing Flame
related_concepts.definition: Colors may differ based on flame zone (e.g., Cu is Red in reducing flame due to Cu2O formation).

subject: Chemistry
title: Flame Test (Sodium)
description: Excitation of valence electrons emits characteristic yellow light.
derivation:
Principle: Thermal Excitation.
1. Heat from Bunsen burner volatilizes the chloride salt.
2. Valence electron (3s) absorbs energy and jumps to higher levels (3p).
3. Relaxation: Electron falls back to 3s, emitting photon.
   Energy gap corresponds to wavelength of yellow light (~589 nm).

related_concepts.name: Emission Spectrum
related_concepts.definition: The spectrum of frequencies of electromagnetic radiation emitted due to an atom or molecule making a transition from a high energy state to a lower energy state.

subject: Chemistry
title: Flame Test (Barium)
description: Characteristic flame color for Barium salts.
derivation:
Electronic transition specific to Barium cation.
Usually performed with Platinum wire dipped in Conc HCl (to form volatile chlorides).
Caution: Copper salts (if Cu is not removed) can sometimes mimic green flames (bluish-green), so Group 2 removal is essential.

related_concepts.name: Calcium Flame
related_concepts.definition: Brick Red.

related_concepts.name: Strontium Flame
related_concepts.definition: Crimson Red.

subject: Chemistry
title: Acid Rain
description: Precipitation with pH < 5.6 due to dissolved oxides of Sulfur and Nitrogen.
derivation:
Natural rain is slightly acidic (pH ~5.6) due to \(H_2CO_3\).
Mechanism of Acid Rain:
1. Emission: \(SO_2\) (burning fossil fuels) and \(NO_2\) (vehicles).
2. Oxidation: Catalyzed by particulate matter or ozone.
   \(4NO_2 + 2H_2O + O_2 \rightarrow 4HNO_3\)
3. Deposition: Acids fall with rain, damaging marble (\(CaCO_3\)) and aquatic life.

related_concepts.name: Stone Leprosy
related_concepts.definition: Corrosion of historical monuments (Taj Mahal) by acid rain: \(CaCO_3 + H_2SO_4 \rightarrow CaSO_4 + H_2O + CO_2\).

subject: Chemistry
title: Photochemical Smog
description: Oxidizing Smog (Los Angeles Smog). Contains Ozone, PAN, and NO2.
derivation:
Condition: Warm, dry, sunny climate + Vehicular exhaust.
Chain Reaction:
1. Photolysis: \(NO_2\) absorbs sunlight \(\rightarrow NO + O (atomic)\).
2. Ozone Formation: \(O + O_2 \rightarrow O_3\).
3. PAN Formation: Hydrocarbons + \(O_3/NO_2 \rightarrow\) Peroxyacetyl Nitrate (PAN).
PAN is a powerful eye irritant.

related_concepts.name: Secondary Pollutants
related_concepts.definition: Pollutants formed in the atmosphere (Ozone, PAN) rather than emitted directly.

subject: Chemistry
title: Classical Smog
description: Reducing Smog (London Smog). Occurs in cool, humid climates.
derivation:
Composition:
1. Smoke (Carbon particulates/soot).
2. Fog (Condensed water vapor).
3. Sulfur Dioxide (\(SO_2\)).
Nature: Reducing (due to Carbon and SO2).
Mechanism: \(SO_2\) is adsorbed on particulates and inhaled, forming \(H_2SO_4\) in lungs.

related_concepts.name: Particulate Matter (PM)
related_concepts.definition: Microscopic solid or liquid matter suspended in the atmosphere (PM2.5, PM10).

subject: Chemistry
title: Ozone Depletion Mechanism
description: Catalytic destruction of ozone by CFCs (Freons).
derivation:
1. Photolysis: UV breaks C-Cl bond in CFCs.
   \(CF_2Cl_2 \xrightarrow{h\nu} \cdot CF_2Cl + Cl^\bullet\)
2. Propagation (Ozone destruction):
   \(Cl^\bullet + O_3 \rightarrow ClO^\bullet + O_2\)
3. Regeneration of Catalyst:
   \(ClO^\bullet + O^\bullet \rightarrow Cl^\bullet + O_2\)
Result: One Chlorine radical can destroy thousands of Ozone molecules.

related_concepts.name: Ozone Hole
related_concepts.definition: Thinning of ozone layer, particularly over Antarctica during spring.

subject: Chemistry
title: Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD)
description: Measure of dissolved oxygen consumed by microorganisms to decompose organic matter over 5 days at 20°C.
derivation:
Water pollution indicator:
High Organic Waste \(\rightarrow\) High Bacterial Activity \(\rightarrow\) High Oxygen Consumption \(\rightarrow\) High BOD.
Clean Water: BOD < 5 ppm.
Highly Polluted Water: BOD > 17 ppm.

related_concepts.name: Eutrophication
related_concepts.definition: Nutrient enrichment leading to algal blooms and oxygen depletion.

subject: Chemistry
title: Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD)
description: Oxygen required to oxidize ALL organic matter (biodegradable + non-biodegradable) using a strong oxidizer.
derivation:
1. Reagent: Acidified Potassium Dichromate (\(K_2Cr_2O_7\)).
2. Process: Oxidizes all organic carbon to \(CO_2\).
3. Comparison: Since it degrades chemicals that bacteria cannot, COD is always higher than BOD for the same sample.

related_concepts.name: TOC
related_concepts.definition: Total Organic Carbon, another measure of water quality.

subject: Chemistry
title: Radius Ratio (Octahedral)
description: Limiting ratio for Coordination Number 6 (e.g., NaCl).
derivation:
Consider a cation (r) in the void formed by 4 anions (R) in a square plane (cross-section of octahedron).
Diagonal of square = \(2R + 2r\).
Side of square = \(2R\).
Pythagoras: \((2R + 2r)^2 = (2R)^2 + (2R)^2\)
\(2(R+r) = 2\sqrt{2}R\)
\(R+r = \sqrt{2}R\)
\(r/R = \sqrt{2} - 1 = 1.414 - 1 = 0.414\)

related_concepts.name: Void
related_concepts.definition: Interstitial space between packed spheres in a lattice.

subject: Chemistry
title: Schottky Defect
description: Stoichiometric defect where equal numbers of cations and anions are missing.
derivation:
Thermodynamic Origin: Increases entropy of the crystal.
Characteristics:
1. Maintains electrical neutrality.
2. Volume remains constant (lattice structure holds).
3. Mass decreases (atoms missing).
4. Therefore, Density (\(\text{Mass}/\text{Volume}\)) decreases.
Occurs in high Coordination Number salts (NaCl, CsCl, KBr).

related_concepts.name: Point Defect
related_concepts.definition: Irregularities or deviations from ideal arrangement around a point or an atom.

subject: Chemistry
title: Frenkel Defect
description: Stoichiometric defect where an ion moves to an interstitial site.
derivation:
Also called 'Dislocation Defect'.
1. Smaller ion (usually cation, e.g., \(Ag^+\)) leaves its lattice site.
2. Occupies a void (interstitial site).
3. Mass remains constant (no ions lost).
4. Volume remains constant.
5. Therefore, Density remains unchanged.
Occurs when there is large difference in ion sizes (AgCl, ZnS).

related_concepts.name: AgBr
related_concepts.definition: Silver Bromide shows both Schottky and Frenkel defects.

subject: Chemistry
title: Aspirin (Non-Narcotic)
description: Analgesic (pain), Antipyretic (fever), Anti-inflammatory.
derivation:
Mechanism of Action:
1. Pain/Inflammation is caused by Prostaglandins.
2. Aspirin acetylates the enzyme Cyclooxygenase (COX).
3. This irreversibly inhibits COX, stopping Prostaglandin synthesis.
Note: Also acts as an anti-coagulant (prevents heart attacks).

related_concepts.name: Salol
related_concepts.definition: Phenyl salicylate, used as an intestinal antiseptic.

subject: Chemistry
title: Antiseptics vs Disinfectants
description: Same chemical acts differently based on concentration.
derivation:
Principle: Toxicity to tissues.
1. 0.2% Phenol: Low toxicity, safe for living tissues \(\rightarrow\) Antiseptic.
2. 1.0% Phenol: High toxicity, damages tissues, kills germs on floors/drains \(\rightarrow\) Disinfectant.
Other examples: Chlorine (0.2-0.4 ppm in water is antiseptic, higher is bleach).

related_concepts.name: Dettol
related_concepts.definition: Mixture of Chloroxylenol and Terpineol.

subject: Chemistry
title: Cationic Detergents
description: Quaternary ammonium salts (e.g., Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide).
derivation:
Structure:
1. Hydrophobic Tail: Long hydrocarbon chain (Cetyl = C16).
2. Hydrophilic Head: Positively charged Ammonium ion.
Properties:
- The cation is the active cleansing agent.
- Possesses germicidal properties.
- Used in hair conditioners (neutralizes static negative charge on hair).

related_concepts.name: Anionic Detergent
related_concepts.definition: Sodium Lauryl Sulfate (Head is negative). Used in toothpaste and laundry.

subject: Chemistry
title: Jones Reagent
description: Strong oxidizing agent. Converts \(1^\circ\) alcohols to carboxylic acids.
derivation:
Composition: \(CrO_3 + H_2SO_4\) in Acetone.
Mechanism:
1. Formation of Chromate Ester between Alcohol and Chromic Acid.
2. Elimination (E2-like): Water removes alpha-hydrogen.
3. Forms Aldehyde.
4. In presence of water (acidic medium), Aldehyde hydrates to Gem-diol.
5. Gem-diol oxidizes further to Carboxylic Acid.

related_concepts.name: Oxidation State
related_concepts.definition: Chromium reduces from +6 (Orange) to +3 (Green).

subject: Chemistry
title: PCC (Pyridinium Chlorochromate)
description: Selective oxidation of primary alcohols to Aldehydes (stops here).
derivation:
Reagent: \(CrO_3 + HCl + Pyridine\).
Key Feature: Anhydrous conditions (usually in \(CH_2Cl_2\)).
Logic:
Since water is absent, the intermediate Aldehyde cannot form the Gem-diol hydrate.
Without the hydrate, the second oxidation step to Carboxylic acid is impossible.
Thus, reaction stops at Aldehyde.

related_concepts.name: Collins Reagent
related_concepts.definition: CrO3 with 2 Pyridine molecules, also used for stopping oxidation at aldehyde.

subject: Chemistry
title: Lithium Aluminium Hydride
description: Strong reducing agent. Reduces acids, esters, amides, nitriles.
derivation:
Source of Nucleophilic Hydride (\(H^-\)).
Al-H bond is polar (Al is +ve, H is -ve).
1. \(H^-\) attacks the carbonyl carbon (Nucleophilic Addition).
2. Leaving group leaves (if acid/ester).
3. Second \(H^-\) attack reduces it to alkoxide.
4. Workup with water gives alcohol.
Caution: Reacts violently with water/alcohol (must use dry ether).

related_concepts.name: Sodium Borohydride
related_concepts.definition: Weaker reducer. Only reduces Aldehydes/Ketones. Safe in protic solvents.

subject: Chemistry
title: DIBAL-H
description: Selective reduction of Esters and Nitriles to Aldehydes.
derivation:
Full Name: Di-isobutyl Aluminium Hydride.
Mechanism:
1. Steric Bulk: Two large isobutyl groups prevent the reagent from attacking twice.
2. Complexation: Forms a stable Aluminium-Nitrogen intermediate at low temp (-78°C).
3. Hydrolysis: The intermediate breaks down upon adding water to yield Aldehyde.
If warmed, it may reduce fully to amine/alcohol.

related_concepts.name: Partial Reduction
related_concepts.definition: Stopping a reduction reaction at a specific intermediate stage.

subject: Chemistry
title: N-Bromosuccinimide (NBS)
description: Allylic and Benzylic Bromination (Substitution, not Addition).
derivation:
Mechanism: Free Radical Substitution.
1. NBS provides a constant, low concentration of \(Br_2\) (prevents addition to double bond).
2. Propagation: Bromine radical abstracts an Allylic Hydrogen.
   Reason: Allylic radical is Resonance Stabilized.
3. The radical reacts with \(Br_2\) to form Allyl Bromide.

related_concepts.name: Wohl-Ziegler Reaction
related_concepts.definition: The formal name for allylic bromination using NBS.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hinsberg Test
description: Distinguishes Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Amines.
derivation:
Reaction with Amine:
1. \(1^\circ\) Amine: Forms Sulfonamide (\(PhSO_2NHR\)). Has acidic H on Nitrogen. Soluble in NaOH.
2. \(2^\circ\) Amine: Forms Sulfonamide (\(PhSO_2NR_2\)). No acidic H. Insoluble in NaOH.
3. \(3^\circ\) Amine: No H on Nitrogen. No reaction. Remains insoluble (or dissolves in acid).

related_concepts.name: Sulfonamides
related_concepts.definition: Class of compounds including 'Sulfa drugs' (antibiotics).

subject: Chemistry
title: Carbonate Test
description: Detection of \(CO_3^{2-}\). Lime water turns milky.
derivation:
1. Action of Acid: Dilute HCl/H2SO4 on carbonate releases \(CO_2\).
   \(CO_3^{2-} + 2H^+ \rightarrow H_2O + CO_2 \uparrow\)
2. Lime Water Test: Gas passed through \(Ca(OH)_2\).
   Forms insoluble Calcium Carbonate (Milky).
3. Excess Gas: Milkiness disappears due to formation of soluble Bicarbonate.
   \(CaCO_3 + CO_2 + H_2O \rightarrow Ca(HCO_3)_2\).

related_concepts.name: Bicarbonate Test
related_concepts.definition: Bicarbonates also give CO2 but do not precipitate with MgSO4 in cold.

subject: Chemistry
title: Sulphite Test
description: Detection of \(SO_3^{2-}\). Gas turns dichromate paper Green.
derivation:
1. Action of Acid: Releases \(SO_2\) (suffocating smell of burning sulfur).
2. Redox Reaction: \(SO_2\) is a reducing agent.
   It reduces Orange Dichromate (\(Cr^{+6}\)) to Green Chromium (\(Cr^{+3}\)).
   This distinguishes \(SO_2\) from \(CO_2\).

related_concepts.name: KMnO4 Test
related_concepts.definition: SO2 also decolorizes Pink KMnO4 solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Sulphide Test
description: Detection of Sulphide ion (\(S^{2-}\)). Lead Acetate paper turns black.
derivation:
1. Acidification: Dilute \(H_2SO_4\) releases \(H_2S\) gas (Rotten egg smell).
2. Confirmatory Test: The gas is passed over filter paper dipped in Lead Acetate.
3. Reaction: \(H_2S + Pb^{2+} \rightarrow PbS\) (Lead Sulphide).
4. Observation: The paper turns shiny black due to formation of PbS.

related_concepts.name: Sodium Nitroprusside Test
related_concepts.definition: Another test for sulphide giving a violet color: \([Fe(CN)_5NOS]^{4-}\).

subject: Chemistry
title: Nitrite Test
description: Detection of Nitrite (\(NO_2^-\)). Evolves brown fumes with dilute acid.
derivation:
1. Action of Dilute Acid: Nitrites are unstable in acid.
   \(2HNO_2 \rightarrow H_2O + NO + NO_2\)
2. Oxidation: Nitric Oxide (NO) reacts with oxygen in air to form Nitrogen Dioxide (\(NO_2\)).
   \(2NO + O_2 \rightarrow 2NO_2\) (Brown Fumes).
3. Starch-Iodide Test: The fumes turn starch-iodide paper blue (oxidizes \(I^-\to I_2\)).

related_concepts.name: Diazotization
related_concepts.definition: Nitrites react with aromatic primary amines at low temp to form diazonium salts.

subject: Chemistry
title: Nitrate Test (Ring Test)
description: Confirmatory for Nitrate (\(NO_3^-\)). Brown ring forms at interface.
derivation:
1. Reduction: Ferrous sulfate (\(Fe^{2+}\)) reduces Nitrate to NO in presence of conc \(H_2SO_4\).
   \(NO_3^- + 3Fe^{2+} + 4H^+ \rightarrow NO + 3Fe^{3+} + 2H_2O\)
2. Complexation: NO binds to excess \(Fe^{2+}\).
   \([Fe(H_2O)_6]^{2+} + NO \rightarrow [Fe(H_2O)_5NO]^{2+} + H_2O\)
   The complex (Nitroso ferrous sulphate) forms a brown ring at the junction of acid and solution.

related_concepts.name: Brown Ring Complex
related_concepts.definition: In this complex, Fe is in +1 oxidation state and NO is +1.

subject: Chemistry
title: Chromyl Chloride Test
description: Specific test for Chloride ions using K2Cr2O7 and Conc H2SO4.
derivation:
1. Formation: Chloride salt + \(K_2Cr_2O_7\) + Conc \(H_2SO_4\) \(\rightarrow\) Heating.
   \(K_2Cr_2O_7 + 4NaCl + 6H_2SO_4 \rightarrow 2CrO_2Cl_2 + 4NaHSO_4 + 2KHSO_4 + 3H_2O\)
2. Confirmation: Pass red vapors into NaOH \(\rightarrow\) Yellow solution (\(Na_2CrO_4\)).
3. Precipitation: Add Lead Acetate \(\rightarrow\) Yellow ppt (\(PbCrO_4\)).
Note: Chlorides of Ag, Pb, Hg, and Sn do not give this test.

related_concepts.name: Dry Test
related_concepts.definition: A test performed on the solid salt rather than a solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Layer Test (Br/I)
description: Redox test using Chlorine water and \(CHCl_3\) (Chloroform) or \(CS_2\).
derivation:
Principle: Chlorine is a stronger oxidizing agent than Bromine or Iodine.
1. Displacement: \(Cl_2\) displaces \(Br^-\)/\(I^-\).
   \(2Br^- + Cl_2 \rightarrow Br_2 + 2Cl^-\)
   \(2I^- + Cl_2 \rightarrow I_2 + 2Cl^-\)
2. Extraction: The free halogen dissolves in the organic layer (Chloroform).
3. Color: Bromine \(\rightarrow\) Orange/Brown layer. Iodine \(\rightarrow\) Violet layer.

related_concepts.name: Solvent Extraction
related_concepts.definition: Separation of compounds based on their relative solubilities in two immiscible liquids.

subject: Chemistry
title: Phosphate Test
description: Canary Yellow precipitate of Ammonium Phosphomolybdate.
derivation:
1. Reagent: Ammonium Molybdate \((NH_4)_2MoO_4\) in presence of Conc \(HNO_3\).
2. Reaction: Phosphate reacts with Molybdate.
   \(PO_4^{3-} + 12MoO_4^{2-} + 24H^+ + 3NH_4^+ \rightarrow (NH_4)_3[PMo_{12}O_{40}] + 12H_2O\)
3. Condition: Solution must be acidic and heated gently.
Arsenic gives a similar yellow ppt, so interfere must be removed.

related_concepts.name: Heteropoly Acid
related_concepts.definition: Complex acids composed of hydrogen, oxygen, a heteroatom (P), and addenda atoms (Mo).

subject: Chemistry
title: Tyndall Effect Conditions
description: Criteria for light scattering by colloidal particles (why true solutions don't show it).
derivation:
1. Size Condition: The diameter of the dispersed particles (d) must be comparable to the wavelength (\(\lambda\)) of light used.
2. Refractive Index Condition: There must be a large magnitude difference between the refractive indices of the dispersed phase (\(n_1\)) and dispersion medium (\(n_2\)).
   This ensures significant scattering at the interface.

related_concepts.name: Lyophobic Colloids
related_concepts.definition: Show strong Tyndall effect due to large difference in refractive indices.

subject: Chemistry
title: Gold Number
description: Measure of protective power of lyophilic colloids. Lower Gold Number = Better Protection.
derivation:
Definition Standard:
- Volume of Gold Sol: 10 ml.
- Electrolyte added: 1 ml of 10% NaCl.
- Result to prevent: Color change from Red to Blue (Coagulation).
The Gold Number is the milligrams of protective colloid needed to just prevent this change.
Example: Gelatin (0.005) is a better protector than Starch (25).

related_concepts.name: Lyophilic Colloid
related_concepts.definition: Solvent-loving colloids (e.g., Gelatin, Gum) that protect unstable lyophobic colloids.

subject: Chemistry
title: Ellingham Diagram
description: Graph of \(\Delta G^\circ\) of oxide formation vs Temperature. Predicts reducing agents.
derivation:
Thermodynamics of Reduction:
For reduction \(MO + C \rightarrow M + CO\) to be spontaneous, total \(\Delta G\) must be negative.
Graph Logic:
1. Plots formation of oxides (e.g., \(2M + O_2 \rightarrow 2MO\)).
2. Any metal whose line is *below* another metal's line can reduce the upper metal oxide.
3. The intersection point defines the temperature above which reduction becomes feasible.

related_concepts.name: Pyrometallurgy
related_concepts.definition: Extraction of metals using heat (smelting, roasting).

subject: Chemistry
title: Nernst Equation
description: Calculates electrode potential at non-standard conditions (at 298K).
derivation:
From Thermodynamics: \(\Delta G = \Delta G^\circ + RT \ln Q\)
Substitute \(\Delta G = -nFE\):
\(-nFE = -nFE^\circ + RT \ln Q\)
Divide by \(-nF\):
\(E = E^\circ - \frac{RT}{nF} \ln Q\)
Constants at 298K: \(2.303 RT/F \approx 0.0591\).

related_concepts.name: Reaction Quotient (Q)
related_concepts.definition: Ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations raised to stoichiometric coefficients.

subject: Chemistry
title: Arrhenius Equation
description: Relationship between rate constant (k), activation energy (Ea), and temperature (T).
derivation:
1. Kinetic Energy: Fraction of molecules with energy \(\ge E_a\) is proportional to \(e^{-E_a/RT}\) (Boltzmann Factor).
2. Frequency Factor (A): Represents collision frequency and orientation probability.
3. Linear Form: \(\ln k = \ln A - \frac{E_a}{R} \left(\frac{1}{T}\right)\).
   Slope of \(\ln k\) vs \(1/T\) graph is \(-E_a/R\).

related_concepts.name: Activation Energy
related_concepts.definition: Minimum energy required for reactants to form the activated complex.

subject: Chemistry
title: Van't Hoff Factor (i)
description: Correction for Dissociation or Association of solute.
derivation:
1. Dissociation (e.g., NaCl \(\to\) 2 ions): Moles increase.
   \(i = 1 + (n-1)\alpha\) (where \(n\) is ions per molecule).
2. Association (e.g., Acetic acid in benzene \(\to\) Dimer): Moles decrease.
   \(i = 1 + (\frac{1}{n}-1)\beta\) (where \(n\) is number of molecules associating).
   For strong electrolytes (\(\alpha=1\)), \(i\) equals number of ions.

related_concepts.name: Abnormal Molar Mass
related_concepts.definition: Molar mass calculated from colligative properties differs from theoretical mass due to \(i \neq 1\).

subject: Chemistry
title: Crystal Field Splitting (Octahedral)
description: Splitting of d-orbitals in presence of 6 ligands. \(t_{2g}\) lowers, \(e_g\) raises.
derivation:
1. Isotropic Field: All 5 d-orbitals raised in energy equally by negative ligand charge.
2. Octahedral Field: Ligands approach along x, y, z axes.
   - \(d_{x^2-y^2}, d_{z^2}\) (e_g) point *at* ligands \(\rightarrow\) High Repulsion \(\rightarrow\) Energy rises (+0.6 \(\Delta_o\)).
   - \(d_{xy}, d_{yz}, d_{zx}\) (t_{2g}) point *between* ligands \(\rightarrow\) Less Repulsion \(\rightarrow\) Energy drops (-0.4 \(\Delta_o\)).

related_concepts.name: Spectrochemical Series
related_concepts.definition: Series ordering ligands by field strength (\(I^- < H_2O < NH_3 < CN^- < CO\)).

subject: Chemistry
title: CFT Splitting (Tetrahedral)
description: Splitting pattern is inverted relative to Octahedral. \(e_g\) is lower, \(t_{2g}\) is higher.
derivation:
1. Geometry: 4 ligands approach corners of a tetrahedron (alternating corners of a cube).
2. Interaction: The \(d_{xy}, d_{yz}, d_{zx}\) orbitals point *closer* to the ligands than the axial orbitals.
3. Result: \(t_{2g}\) set is repelled more (Higher Energy).
   \(e_g\) set is repelled less (Lower Energy).
4. Magnitude: \(\Delta_t < \Delta_o\) because there are fewer ligands (4 vs 6) and they don't point directly at orbitals.

related_concepts.name: High Spin Complex
related_concepts.definition: Tetrahedral complexes are almost always high spin because \(\Delta_t\) is usually smaller than Pairing Energy (P).

subject: Chemistry
title: Geometrical Isomerism (MA2B2)
description: Stereoisomerism based on ligand position. Common in Square Planar and Octahedral.
derivation:
Case: Square Planar \([MA_2B_2]\) (e.g., Cisplatin).
1. Cis-isomer: Identical ligands (A-A or B-B) are adjacent (90° angle).
2. Trans-isomer: Identical ligands are opposite (180° angle) across the metal center.
Note: Tetrahedral complexes do NOT show geometrical isomerism because all positions are equidistant and adjacent (109.5°).

related_concepts.name: Fac-Mer Isomerism
related_concepts.definition: Occurs in Octahedral \([MA_3B_3]\). Fac = Face (cis-like), Mer = Meridian (trans-like).

subject: Chemistry
title: Optical Isomerism
description: Chiral complexes that rotate plane-polarized light. Non-superimposable mirror images.
derivation:
Condition for Chirality: Absence of Plane of Symmetry (POS).
1. Example: \([Co(en)_3]^{3+}\) (Octahedral with 3 bidentate ligands).
   The chelate rings form a 'propeller' shape.
2. Mirror Image: The left-handed propeller cannot be superimposed on the right-handed one.
   Forms: Dextro (d) and Levo (l).
3. Trans-isomers with bidentate ligands often have a POS and are optically inactive (Meso).

related_concepts.name: Chelate Ring
related_concepts.definition: A ring structure formed when a polydentate ligand bonds to a central metal atom.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hess's Law
description: Enthalpy change is independent of the path taken.
derivation:
Since Enthalpy (H) is a State Function:
Path A: $Reactants \rightarrow Products$ ($\Delta H$)
Path B: $Reactants \rightarrow Intermediate \rightarrow Products$ ($\Delta H_1 + \Delta H_2$)
According to conservation of energy:
$\Delta H = \Delta H_1 + \Delta H_2$

related_concepts.name: State Function
related_concepts.definition: A property whose value does not depend on the path taken to reach that specific value.

subject: Chemistry
title: Bond Enthalpy Reaction
description: Calculating reaction enthalpy using bond energies.
derivation:
Chemical reaction involves breaking old bonds and forming new ones.
1. Energy absorbed to break reactant bonds: $+\sum BE_R$
2. Energy released to form product bonds: $-\sum BE_P$
Net Enthalpy: $\Delta H = \text{Energy absorbed} - \text{Energy released}$

related_concepts.name: Resonance Energy
related_concepts.definition: Difference between observed bond energy and theoretical bond energy calculated for a canonical structure.

subject: Chemistry
title: n-factor (Oxidizing/Reducing Agent)
description: Valency factor used to calculate Equivalent Weight ($E = M/n$).
derivation:
Example: Dichromate ($Cr_2O_7^{2-} \rightarrow Cr^{3+}$)
1. O.S. of Cr in reactant: $+6$
2. O.S. of Cr in product: $+3$
3. Change per atom: $|3 - 6| = 3$
4. Number of Cr atoms in molecule: 2
$n = 3 \times 2 = 6$

related_concepts.name: Normality
related_concepts.definition: Concentration term defined as $N = n \times Molarity$.

subject: Chemistry
title: n-factor (Disproportionation)
description: Equivalent weight for species undergoing both oxidation and reduction.
derivation:
Consider $2H_2O_2 \rightarrow 2H_2O + O_2$
1. Oxidation half: $H_2O_2 \rightarrow O_2$ ($O^{-1} \to O^0$). Change = 1 per O. $n_{ox} = 2$.
2. Reduction half: $H_2O_2 \rightarrow H_2O$ ($O^{-1} \to O^{-2}$). Change = 1 per O. $n_{red} = 2$.
Total Equivalent Weight $E = E_{ox} + E_{red} = M/n_{ox} + M/n_{red} = M(1/n_{ox} + 1/n_{red})$.

related_concepts.name: Disproportionation
related_concepts.definition: A redox reaction where the same element is simultaneously oxidized and reduced.

subject: Chemistry
title: MOT Energy Order (Z > 7)
description: Orbital filling order for $O_2$ and $F_2$.
derivation:
Due to large energy gap between 2s and 2p orbitals (high Zeff), there is no s-p mixing.
The $\sigma_{2p_z}$ orbital (head-on overlap) forms a strong bond and lowers in energy significantly, dropping below the $\pi$ orbitals.
Order: $\sigma_{1s} < \sigma^*_{1s} < \sigma_{2s} < \sigma^*_{2s} < \sigma_{2p_z} < \pi_{2p} < \pi^*_{2p} < \sigma^*_{2p_z}$.

related_concepts.name: s-p Mixing
related_concepts.definition: Interaction that raises the energy of $\sigma_{2p}$ above $\pi_{2p}$ for lighter elements ($B_2, C_2, N_2$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydrogen Bonding Conditions
description: Requires H attached to electronegative X (F, O, N) and a lone pair on Y.
derivation:
Electrostatic attraction.
1. High electronegativity of X creates a strong partial positive charge ($\delta+$) on Hydrogen.
2. Small size of Hydrogen allows it to approach the lone pair of atom Y closely.
Strength: $F-H...F > O-H...N > N-H...N$.

related_concepts.name: Chelation
related_concepts.definition: Intramolecular Hydrogen bonding (e.g., o-nitrophenol) forms a ring-like structure.

subject: Chemistry
title: E1 Mechanism (Elimination)
description: Unimolecular elimination. Competing reaction with SN1.
derivation:
Step 1 (Slow): Loss of Leaving Group forms Carbocation.
   $R-CH_2-C^+R_2$.
Step 2 (Fast): Weak base (solvent) removes $\beta$-hydrogen.
   $H^+$ leaves, C-C double bond forms.
Favored by: $3^\circ$ substrates, weak bases, high temperature (Entropy favored).

related_concepts.name: Saytzeff Product
related_concepts.definition: The more substituted, more stable alkene is the major product in E1.

subject: Chemistry
title: E2 Mechanism (Elimination)
description: Bimolecular elimination. Single step concerted process.
derivation:
Concerted Reaction:
1. Base abstracts $\beta$-proton.
2. C-H bond breaks, C=C bond starts forming.
3. Leaving Group departs simultaneously.
Stereochemistry: Requires Anti-Periplanar geometry (H and LG must be $180^\circ$ apart).

related_concepts.name: Hofmann Product
related_concepts.definition: Less substituted alkene formed when using bulky bases (e.g., t-BuOK).

subject: Chemistry
title: Specific Rotation
description: Measure of optical activity. $\alpha$: observed angle, $l$: length (dm), $c$: conc (g/mL).
derivation:
Optical rotation depends on the number of chiral molecules encountered by light.
$\alpha_{obs} \propto l$ (path length).
$\alpha_{obs} \propto c$ (concentration).
Proportionality constant is Specific Rotation $[\alpha]$.
Standard state: $l=1$ dm, $c=1$ g/mL.

related_concepts.name: Racemic Mixture
related_concepts.definition: Equimolar mixture of enantiomers. Net rotation is zero.

subject: Chemistry
title: Enantiomeric Excess (ee)
description: Purity of a chiral sample. Also equal to $\frac{\alpha_{obs}}{\alpha_{pure}} \times 100$.
derivation:
If a mixture contains 70% R and 30% S:
The 30% S cancels the rotation of 30% R (Racemic part).
The remaining 40% R contributes to rotation.
$ee = 70 - 30 = 40\%$.

related_concepts.name: Optical Purity
related_concepts.definition: Synonymous with enantiomeric excess.

subject: Chemistry
title: Borazine Structure
description: Inorganic Benzene. Isoelectronic with benzene.
derivation:
Synthesis: $3B_2H_6 + 6NH_3 \rightarrow 2B_3N_3H_6 + 12H_2$.
Structure:
Planar hexagonal ring with alternating B and N atoms.
Backbonding: N donates lone pair to empty p-orbital of B.
Reactivity: Unlike benzene, it undergoes addition reactions because the B-N bond is polar.

related_concepts.name: Back Bonding
related_concepts.definition: Transfer of electrons from a filled orbital of one atom to an empty orbital of an adjacent atom.

subject: Chemistry
title: Diborane Structure
description: Electron deficient bonding in $B_2H_6$.
derivation:
Boron ($s^2 p^1$) has only 3 valence electrons but forms 4 bonds in dimer.
Terminal H: 4 normal $2c-2e$ bonds.
Bridging H: 2 bonds where one H atom bridges two Boron atoms.
Configuration: $B-H-B$.
Electrons involved: 2 (one from B, one from H). Atoms involved: 3.
Result: Three-center two-electron bond.

related_concepts.name: Electron Deficient
related_concepts.definition: Molecules that do not have enough electrons to form normal 2-electron bonds between all atoms.

subject: Chemistry
title: Pseudo First Order
description: Reaction appearing 1st order because reactant B is in large excess.
derivation:
True Rate Law: Rate = $k[A][B]$.
If $[B] \gg [A]$, concentration of B remains effectively constant ($[B] \approx [B]_0$).
Combine constants: $k' = k[B]_0$.
New Rate Law: Rate = $k'[A]$.
Example: Hydrolysis of ester in excess water.

related_concepts.name: Inversion of Cane Sugar
related_concepts.definition: A classic pseudo-first order reaction: Sucrose + Water -> Glucose + Fructose.

subject: Chemistry
title: Decay Constant Relation
description: Radioactive decay follows first order kinetics. $\lambda$: decay constant.
derivation:
Rate of decay is proportional to number of nuclei present.
$-dN/dt = \lambda N$.
Integrate from $N_0$ to $N_t$:
$\ln(N_t/N_0) = -\lambda t$.
$N_t = N_0 e^{-\lambda t}$.

related_concepts.name: Activity
related_concepts.definition: The rate of decay ($A = \lambda N$). Unit: Becquerel (Bq) or Curie (Ci).

subject: Chemistry
title: Average Life
description: The average time a radioactive nucleus survives.
derivation:
Definition: Sum of lifetimes of all atoms / Total atoms.
$\tau = \frac{\int_0^\infty t (\lambda N_0 e^{-\lambda t}) dt}{N_0}$.
Solving the integral yields $\tau = 1/\lambda$.
Since $t_{1/2} = 0.693/\lambda$, then $\tau = t_{1/2} / 0.693 = 1.44 t_{1/2}$.

related_concepts.name: Nuclear Stability
related_concepts.definition: Determined by n/p ratio. Unstable nuclei decay to adjust this ratio.

subject: Chemistry
title: Indicator Theory (HIn)
description: Henderson equation applied to indicators. Determines color change range.
derivation:
Indicators are weak organic acids/bases.
$HIn (Color A) \rightleftharpoons H^+ + In^- (Color B)$.
$K_{In} = \frac{[H^+][In^-]}{[HIn]}$.
Take -log:
$pH = pK_{In} + \log([In^-]/[HIn])$.
Human eye detects color change when ratio shifts from 1:10 to 10:1 ($pH = pK_{In} \pm 1$).

related_concepts.name: Methyl Orange
related_concepts.definition: pH range 3.1-4.4. Red in acid, Yellow in base.

subject: Chemistry
title: Buffer Capacity
description: Moles of strong acid/base required to change pH of 1L buffer by 1 unit.
derivation:
Quantitative measure of buffer efficiency.
Maximum capacity occurs when $[Salt] = [Acid]$.
At this point, $pH = pK_a$.
The system can absorb maximum protons or hydroxide ions with minimal pH shift.

related_concepts.name: Buffer Action
related_concepts.definition: Mechanism by which added H+ or OH- ions are neutralized by buffer components.

subject: Chemistry
title: 18 Electron Rule
description: Stability rule for organometallics. V: Valence e- of metal, L: e- from ligands.
derivation:
Based on filling s(2), p(6), and d(10) orbitals of the metal valence shell.
Example: $Fe(CO)_5$.
Fe ($d^6 s^2$) = 8e.
CO donates 2e $\times$ 5 = 10e.
Total = 18e (Stable).
Exceptions exist (e.g., Square planar $d^8$ complexes often stable at 16e).

related_concepts.name: Synergic Bonding
related_concepts.definition: Simultaneous donation from Ligand to Metal (sigma) and Metal to Ligand (pi back-bonding).

subject: Chemistry
title: Silicates (Basic Unit)
description: Tetrahedral structural unit of all silicates.
derivation:
Silicon is $sp^3$ hybridized.
Si is at the center, bonded to 4 Oxygen atoms at the corners of a tetrahedron.
Sharing of corners (Oxygen atoms) leads to chains, sheets, and 3D networks.
- 0 shared: Orthosilicate.
- 1 shared: Pyrosilicate.
- 2 shared: Chain silicate.

related_concepts.name: Zeolites
related_concepts.definition: Aluminosilicates with microporous structures used as catalysts (e.g., ZSM-5).

subject: Chemistry
title: Azeotrope (Min Boiling)
description: Large positive deviation from Raoult's Law. Example: Ethanol + Water (95%).
derivation:
Interaction A-B is weaker than A-A or B-B.
Vapor pressure of mixture is higher than expected.
Boiling point is lower than either component.
At azeotropic composition, vapor phase composition = liquid phase composition ($y_A = x_A$), so separation by distillation is impossible.

related_concepts.name: Fractional Distillation
related_concepts.definition: Separation method that fails for azeotropes.

subject: Chemistry
title: Photoelectric Effect
description: Conservation of energy for photon-electron interaction. $\Phi$: Work function.
derivation:
Einstein's Equation:
Energy of incident photon = Energy to remove electron + Kinetic Energy.
$E_{photon} = W + K_{max}$
$h\nu = h\nu_0 + \frac{1}{2}mv^2_{max}$
If $\nu < \nu_0$ (Threshold frequency), no emission occurs regardless of intensity.

related_concepts.name: Stopping Potential
related_concepts.definition: The negative potential ($V_0$) required to stop the most energetic photoelectrons: $eV_0 = KE_{max}$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Nuclear Binding Energy
description: Energy released when nucleons form a nucleus. $\Delta m$: Mass defect.
derivation:
Mass of nucleus is always less than sum of masses of individual protons and neutrons.
$\Delta m = [Z m_p + (A-Z) m_n] - M_{nucleus}$
This 'lost' mass is converted to energy holding the nucleus together.
1 amu $\approx$ 931.5 MeV.

related_concepts.name: Binding Energy per Nucleon
related_concepts.definition: Measure of stability. Higher BE/A (e.g., Fe-56) means higher stability.

subject: Chemistry
title: Q-Value of Reaction
description: Energy released ($Q>0$, Exo) or absorbed ($Q<0$, Endo) in a nuclear reaction.
derivation:
Based on Mass-Energy Equivalence.
Total Mass-Energy is conserved.
If product mass is lower, mass was converted to kinetic energy (Q).
$Q = [\sum m_{parent} - \sum m_{daughter}] \times 931.5 \text{ MeV}$.

related_concepts.name: Alpha Decay
related_concepts.definition: Emission of Helium nucleus ($^4_2He$). Usually has positive Q-value for heavy nuclei.

subject: Chemistry
title: Critical Temperature (Tc)
description: Temperature above which a gas cannot be liquefied, no matter the pressure.
derivation:
Derived from Van der Waals equation at the Critical Point (inflection point).
Conditions: $(\frac{\partial P}{\partial V})_T = 0$ and $(\frac{\partial^2 P}{\partial V^2})_T = 0$.
Solving these for $T$ yields $T_c$ in terms of constants $a$ and $b$.
At $T_c$, gas behaves ideally only at low pressure.

subject: Chemistry
title: Inversion Temperature
description: Temp at which Joule-Thomson coefficient is zero (no heating/cooling on expansion).
derivation:
For a real gas, expansion usually causes cooling (work done against attractive forces).
However, if $T > T_i$, repulsive forces dominate, and expansion causes heating.
Relation: $T_i = 2 T_{Boyle} = \frac{2a}{Rb}$.
For Hydrogen/Helium, $T_i$ is very low (requires precooling for liquefaction).

related_concepts.name: Joule-Thomson Effect
related_concepts.definition: Temperature change of a real gas or liquid when it is forced through a valve or porous plug while kept insulated.

subject: Chemistry
title: Collision Frequency (Z)
description: Number of collisions per unit volume per second.
derivation:
From Kinetic Theory of Gases.
$Z$ depends on:
1. Collision Cross-section ($\/sigma$): Size of molecules.
2. Average Velocity ($v_{avg} \propto \sqrt{T/\mu}$).
3. Number density ($N_A, N_B$).
Rate = $Z_{AB} \times e^{-E_a/RT} \times \rho$ (Steric Factor).

related_concepts.name: Steric Factor (P)
related_concepts.definition: Accounts for proper orientation requirement in collisions. Rate = $P Z e^{-Ea/RT}$.

subject: Chemistry
title: MacArthur-Forrest Process
description: Cyanide process for extraction of Silver (Ag) and Gold (Au).
derivation:
1. Leaching: Impure metal treated with dilute NaCN in presence of Air ($O_2$).
   Oxygen acts as oxidizing agent ($Au^0 \to Au^+$).
   Forms soluble complex: Sodium Dicyanoaurate(I).
2. Displacement: Zinc dust is added.
   $2[Au(CN)_2]^- + Zn \rightarrow [Zn(CN)_4]^{2-} + 2Au \downarrow$.
   Zinc acts as reducing agent.

related_concepts.name: Hydrometallurgy
related_concepts.definition: Separation of a metal from other material by aqueous processes.

subject: Chemistry
title: Deacon's Process
description: Industrial recovery of Chlorine from HCl byproduct.
derivation:
Catalytic Oxidation.
Catalyst: Cupric Chloride ($CuCl_2$).
Mechanism: Cu acts as oxygen carrier.
1. $2CuCl_2 \to Cu_2Cl_2 + Cl_2$
2. $Cu_2Cl_2 + O_2 \to 2CuO + Cl_2$
3. $CuO + 2HCl \to CuCl_2 + H_2O$
Net: Oxidation of HCl by air.

related_concepts.name: Weldon's Process
related_concepts.definition: Older method using $MnO_2$ to oxidize HCl: $MnO_2 + 4HCl \to MnCl_2 + Cl_2$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Marshall's Acid (Structure)
description: Contains Peroxide linkage ($O-O$). Oxidation state of S is +6.
derivation:
Calculating O.S. using formula gives $2x + 2(1) + 8(-2) = 0 \implies x = +7$ (Wrong, max is +6).
Structure Logic:
Two $HSO_4$ units joined by peroxide bridge.
$HO-SO_2-O-O-SO_2-OH$.
The two peroxide oxygens have O.S. -1.
Calc: $2x + 2(+1) + 6(-2) + 2(-1) = 0 \implies x = +6$.

related_concepts.name: Caro's Acid
related_concepts.definition: Peroxomonosulfuric acid ($H_2SO_5$). Contains one peroxide group ($S-O-O-H$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Spectrochemical Series
visual_data: I^- < Br^- < Cl^- < F^- < OH^- < H_2O < NH_3 < CN^- < CO
description: Arrangement of ligands in increasing order of Crystal Field Splitting energy ($\Delta$).
derivation:
Empirical order determined by absorption spectra.
Trend Logic:
1. Halides (Weak): $\pi$-donors (filled p-orbitals) reduce $\Delta$.
2. Water/Ammonia (Intermediate): $\sigma$-donors only.
3. CN/CO (Strong): $\pi$-acceptors (vacant orbitals) allow Back Bonding, increasing $\Delta$ significantly.

related_concepts.name: Synergic Effect
related_concepts.definition: Self-strengthening bond mechanism in Metal Carbonyls due to sigma-donation and pi-backdonation.

subject: Chemistry
title: SNi Mechanism
description: Internal Nucleophilic Substitution. Occurs with Thionyl Chloride. Retention of Config.
derivation:
1. Formation of Chlorosulfite ester: $R-O-SO-Cl$.
2. Intramolecular Attack: The Chlorine atom attacks the alkyl group from the *same side* as the leaving oxygen.
   Reaction proceeds via a cyclic transition state.
   Result: Retention of Stereochemistry.
Note: If Pyridine is added, mechanism changes to SN2 (Inversion) because Pyridine removes HCl and frees $Cl^-$ for backside attack.

related_concepts.name: Darzen's Process
related_concepts.definition: Preparation of alkyl chlorides using $SOCl_2$ (preferred as byproducts are gases).

subject: Chemistry
title: E1cB Mechanism
description: Elimination Unimolecular conjugate Base. Occurs when leaving group is poor (F, OH) and acidic H is present.
derivation:
Step 1 (Fast): Base removes acidic $\beta$-proton.
   Forms a Carbanion intermediate (stabilized by EWG like -CO, -NO2).
Step 2 (Slow/RDS): Poor leaving group departs.
   $C^- - C - LG \rightarrow C=C + LG^-$.
Order is Second Order, but mechanism is stepwise (unlike E2).

related_concepts.name: Aldol Elimination
related_concepts.definition: Dehydration of aldol product follows E1cB due to acidic alpha-hydrogen and OH leaving group.

subject: Chemistry
title: Pinacol-Pinacolone Rearrangement
description: Acid catalyzed conversion of Vicinal Diols to Ketones involving Methyl shift.
derivation:
1. Protonation: One -OH group accepts $H^+$ and leaves as water ($H_2O$).
2. Carbocation Formation: A stable tertiary carbocation forms.
3. 1,2-Methyl Shift: Alkyl group migrates to the cation to form a more stable cation (Octet complete on Oxygen via Resonance).
   $C^+(OH)-C(Me) \rightarrow C(=O^+H)-C(Me)$.
4. Deprotonation: Yields Pinacolone (t-butyl methyl ketone).

related_concepts.name: Migratory Aptitude
related_concepts.definition: Order of group migration: Aryl > Alkyl (Tertiary > Secondary > Primary) > Methyl.

subject: Chemistry
title: Tischenko Reaction
description: Modified Cannizzaro reaction. All aldehydes (with or w/o alpha-H) form Esters.
derivation:
Reagent: Aluminium Ethoxide.
Mechanism:
1. Similar to Cannizzaro (hydride transfer).
2. Instead of forming separate Alcohol and Acid, the intermediate coordinates with Aluminium.
3. Hydride transfer occurs intermolecularly or intramolecularly to form an Ester directly.
Example: Acetaldehyde $\to$ Ethyl Acetate.

related_concepts.name: Disproportionation
related_concepts.definition: One molecule oxidized to acid part, one reduced to alcohol part, combined as ester.

subject: Chemistry
title: Gabriel Phthalimide Synthesis
description: Preparation of pure primary aliphatic amines.
derivation:
1. Acid-Base: Phthalimide (acidic NH) + KOH $\to$ Potassium Phthalimide ($N^-K^+$).
2. SN2 Attack: $N^-$ attacks Alkyl Halide ($RX$). Forms N-Alkyl Phthalimide.
   Constraint: $RX$ must be suitable for SN2 (Primary/Secondary). Aryl halides do not react.
3. Hydrolysis: NaOH cleaves the imide bond releasing $R-NH_2$.

related_concepts.name: Nucleophilic Substitution
related_concepts.definition: The phthalimide anion acts as a bulky nucleophile.

subject: Chemistry
title: Mutarotation
description: Spontaneous change in specific rotation of an optically active compound.
derivation:
Glucose crystallizes in two forms:
- $\alpha$-form ($+112^\circ$)
- $\beta$-form ($+19^\circ$)
In aqueous solution, the hemiacetal ring opens and re-closes dynamically.
Equilibrium mixture attains a constant rotation of $+52.7^\circ$ (approx 36% $\alpha$, 64% $\beta$).
Driven by the stability of the chair conformations.

related_concepts.name: Anomers
related_concepts.definition: Isomers differing in configuration at C1 (Hemiacetal carbon).

subject: Chemistry
title: Isoelectric Point (Amino Acids)
description: pH at which amino acid exists as Zwitterion (net charge 0) and does not migrate in electric field.
derivation:
For neutral amino acid (e.g., Glycine):
$Cation (+1) \xrightarrow{K_{a1}} Zwitterion (0) \xrightarrow{K_{a2}} Anion (-1)$.
We need max concentration of Zwitterion.
$pH = pK_{a1} + \log([Z]/[Cat])$ and $pH = pK_{a2} + \log([An]/[Z])$.
At pI, $[Cat] = [An]$. Adding equations gives $2pH = pK_{a1} + pK_{a2}$.

related_concepts.name: Electrophoresis
related_concepts.definition: Technique to separate amino acids based on migration in electric field at a specific pH.

subject: Chemistry
title: Vulcanization of Rubber
description: Heating natural rubber with Sulfur to improve properties.
derivation:
Natural Rubber (cis-1,4-polyisoprene) is soft and sticky.
Mechanism:
1. Sulfur forms cross-links between the polymer chains at the allylic positions (reactive C=C sites).
2. Result: Formation of a 3D network.
   - Increases elasticity.
   - Increases tensile strength.
   - Reduces solubility in organic solvents.

related_concepts.name: Elastomer
related_concepts.definition: Polymer with viscoelasticity and weak intermolecular forces, allowing stretching.

subject: Chemistry
title: Iodometric Titration
description: Indirect estimation of oxidizing agents (Cu2+, KMnO4, K2Cr2O7).
derivation:
Step 1: Oxidizing Agent liberates Iodine from Iodide ($KI$).
   $2Cu^{2+} + 4I^- \rightarrow Cu_2I_2 + I_2$.
Step 2: Liberated $I_2$ is titrated against standard Sodium Thiosulfate (Hypo).
   $I_2 + 2Na_2S_2O_3 \rightarrow 2NaI + Na_2S_4O_6$ (Sodium Tetrathionate).
Indicator: Starch (Blue $\to$ Colorless at endpoint).

related_concepts.name: Iodimetry
related_concepts.definition: Direct titration using standard Iodine solution against reducing agents.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hardness of Water (EDTA)
description: Complexometric titration to estimate $Ca^{2+}$ and $Mg^{2+}$.
derivation:
1. Buffer: pH 10 ($NH_4OH/NH_4Cl$).
2. Indicator: Eriochrome Black T (EBT). Forms unstable Wine Red complex with metal.
3. Titration: EDTA (stronger ligand) displaces EBT from the metal.
   $M-EBT + EDTA \rightarrow M-EDTA (Stable) + EBT (Free)$.
4. Endpoint: Color changes from Wine Red to Blue (color of free EBT at pH 10).

related_concepts.name: Chelation
related_concepts.definition: EDTA is a hexadentate ligand forming stable ring complexes.

subject: Chemistry
title: Volume Strength of H2O2
description: Relates molarity to the volume of O2 gas released at STP.
derivation:
Decomposition: $2H_2O_2 \rightarrow 2H_2O + O_2$
2 moles of $H_2O_2$ produce 1 mole of $O_2$ (22.4 L at STP).
Thus, 1 Molar solution ($1$ mol/L) produces $11.2$ L of $O_2$.
Formula: $V = 11.2 \times M = 5.6 \times N$.

related_concepts.name: Perhydrol
related_concepts.definition: Commercial name for 30% H2O2 solution (approx 100 volume strength).

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of NaCl (Rock Salt)
description: Coordination Number 6:6. 4 formula units per unit cell.
derivation:
Arrangement:
1. Anions ($Cl^-$) form the Face Centered Cubic (FCC) lattice.
2. Cations ($Na^+$) occupy all Octahedral Voids (Body center + Edge centers).
Radius Ratio: $r^+/r^-$ is between 0.414 and 0.732.
Position of ions: Na+ at (1/2, 0, 0), Cl- at (0, 0, 0).

related_concepts.name: Formula Units (Z)
related_concepts.definition: Number of motifs per unit cell. For NaCl, $Z = 4$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of ZnS (Zinc Blende)
description: Coordination Number 4:4. 4 formula units per unit cell.
derivation:
Arrangement:
1. Sulfide ions ($S^{2-}$) form FCC lattice.
2. Zinc ions ($Zn^{2+}$) occupy 50% of Tetrahedral Voids (TVs).
   There are 8 TVs in FCC; Zn occupies 4.
Location: Body diagonals ($1/4$ distance from corner).
Note: Wurtzite is the HCP polymorph of ZnS.

related_concepts.name: Diamond Structure
related_concepts.definition: Same geometry as Zinc Blende but all atoms are Carbon.

subject: Chemistry
title: Lead Storage Battery (Discharge)
description: Secondary cell reaction used in automobiles. $H_2SO_4$ is consumed.
derivation:
Anode (Oxidation): $Pb + SO_4^{2-} \rightarrow PbSO_4 + 2e^-$
Cathode (Reduction): $PbO_2 + SO_4^{2-} + 4H^+ + 2e^- \rightarrow PbSO_4 + 2H_2O$
Overall: $H_2SO_4$ density decreases during discharge.
Recharging reverses the reaction (Electrolytic cell).

related_concepts.name: Secondary Battery
related_concepts.definition: A battery that can be recharged by passing current in the opposite direction.

subject: Chemistry
title: Parallel First Order Reaction
description: Reactant A forms B (k1) and C (k2) simultaneously.
derivation:
Rate Law:
$-\frac{d[A]}{dt} = k_1[A] + k_2[A] = (k_1 + k_2)[A]$
Integrated form: $[A] = [A]_0 e^{-(k_1+k_2)t}$
Product Ratio: $[B]/[C] = k_1/k_2$
Activation Energy: $E_{eff} = \frac{k_1 E_1 + k_2 E_2}{k_1 + k_2}$.

related_concepts.name: Selectivity
related_concepts.definition: The ratio of desired product rate constant to side reaction rate constants.

subject: Chemistry
title: Boric Acid Structure
description: Planar $BO_3$ units linked by Hydrogen Bonds. Slippery solid.
derivation:
Hybridization: Boron is $sp^2$ (Trigonal Planar).
Network:
Each $B(OH)_3$ unit is H-bonded to 6 others.
This creates a sheet-like structure similar to graphite.
Weak Van der Waals forces between layers make it soft/slippery.
Acidity: Acts as Lewis acid accepting $OH^-$ from water, not proton donor.

related_concepts.name: Lewis Acid
related_concepts.definition: An electron pair acceptor ($B(OH)_3 + H_2O \rightleftharpoons [B(OH)_4]^- + H^+$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Silicones (Polymers)
description: Organosilicon polymers. Water repellent, heat resistant.
derivation:
Synthesis:
1. $RCl + Si \xrightarrow{Cu} R_2SiCl_2$ (Rochow Process).
2. Hydrolysis: $R_2SiCl_2 + H_2O \rightarrow R_2Si(OH)_2$.
3. Polymerization: Condensation of silanols with loss of water.
   Forms $Si-O-Si$ backbone with organic $R$ side groups.
Chain length controlled by adding $R_3SiCl$ (Chain terminator).

related_concepts.name: Hydrophobic
related_concepts.definition: Water-repelling nature due to non-polar alkyl groups on the surface.

subject: Chemistry
title: Chromate-Dichromate Equilibrium
description: pH dependent equilibrium. Acid favors Dichromate; Alkali favors Chromate.
derivation:
Le Chatelier's Principle:
1. Add Acid ($H^+$): Equilibrium shifts Right (Consumes H+). Solution turns Orange.
2. Add Base ($OH^-$): Removes H+, shifts Left. Solution turns Yellow.
Note: Oxidation state of Cr remains +6 in both; it is not a redox reaction.

related_concepts.name: Condensation Reaction
related_concepts.definition: Two tetrahedral chromate units join through an oxygen bridge to form dichromate.

subject: Chemistry
title: Color in Complexes
description: Color arises from d-d transitions or Charge Transfer.
derivation:
1. d-d Transition: Electron absorbs photon to jump from $t_{2g}$ to $e_g$ (in octahedral).
   Required energy corresponds to visible light.
   Example: $[Ti(H_2O)_6]^{3+}$ is Purple.
2. Charge Transfer (CT): Electron moves between Ligand and Metal.
   Example: $KMnO_4$ (Deep Purple) has $d^0$ config, so color is due to $L \to M$ Charge Transfer, not d-d.

related_concepts.name: Complementary Color
related_concepts.definition: The color observed is complementary to the color absorbed (e.g., Absorb Yellow $\to$ See Violet).

subject: Chemistry
title: Oxymercuration-Demercuration
description: Hydration of alkene. Markovnikov addition. NO Rearrangement.
derivation:
Step 1 (Oxymercuration): Electrophilic attack by $Hg(OAc)^+$.
   Forms cyclic Mercurinium Ion (Bridged).
   Water attacks the *more substituted* carbon (backside).
Step 2 (Demercuration): $NaBH_4$ replaces the $HgOAc$ group with Hydrogen.
Key Advantage: Avoids carbocation rearrangements common in acid-catalyzed hydration.

related_concepts.name: Markovnikov's Rule
related_concepts.definition: Negative part of the addendum attaches to the carbon with fewer hydrogen atoms.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydroboration-Oxidation
visual_data: R-CH=CH_2 \xrightarrow{1. BH_3 \cdot THF}{2. H_2O_2, OH^-} R-CH_2-CH_2-OH
description: Hydration of alkene. Anti-Markovnikov product. Syn-Addition.
derivation:
Step 1: Syn-addition of $H-BH_2$ across the double bond.
   Boron adds to the *less hindered* carbon (Anti-Markovnikov regioselectivity).
   Forms Trialkylborane $R_3B$.
Step 2: Oxidation with alkaline $H_2O_2$.
   Boron is replaced by -OH group with retention of configuration.

related_concepts.name: Syn-Addition
related_concepts.definition: Both H and OH add to the same face of the double bond.

subject: Chemistry
title: Benzoin Condensation
description: Self-condensation of aromatic aldehydes to alpha-hydroxy ketone (Benzoin).
derivation:
Catalyst: Cyanide ion ($CN^-$).
1. Nucleophilic attack: $CN^-$ attacks Carbonyl.
2. Umpolung: The intermediate carbanion is stabilized by resonance with -CN.
3. Attack 2: Carbanion attacks second aldehyde molecule.
4. Proton Transfer & Elimination of $CN^-$.
Result: Formation of new C-C bond.

related_concepts.name: Umpolung
related_concepts.definition: Reversal of polarity of a functional group (Carbonyl carbon acts as nucleophile).

subject: Chemistry
title: Perkin Reaction
description: Condensation of aromatic aldehyde with acid anhydride to form Cinnamic Acid.
derivation:
Base: Acetate ion (from salt).
1. Base creates carbanion from anhydride ($\alpha$-hydrogen).
2. Carbanion attacks aldehyde carbonyl.
3. Intramolecular acylation and subsequent hydrolysis/dehydration.
Product: $\alpha,\beta$-unsaturated carboxylic acid.

related_concepts.name: Cinnamic Acid
related_concepts.definition: 3-Phenylprop-2-enoic acid, common product of Perkin reaction.

subject: Chemistry
title: Beckmann Rearrangement
description: Conversion of Ketoxime to N-substituted Amide.
derivation:
1. Protonation of -OH group of oxime -> leaves as water.
2. Migration: The alkyl group *anti* (trans) to the leaving -OH group migrates to Nitrogen.
   Simultaneous C-N bond formation and C-C bond breaking.
3. Hydrolysis of the resulting nitrilium ion gives the amide.
Stereospecific reaction.

related_concepts.name: Caprolactam
related_concepts.definition: Monomer for Nylon-6, produced via Beckmann rearrangement of cyclohexanone oxime.

subject: Chemistry
title: Heating Effect (Dicarboxylic Acids)
description: Blanc's Rule regarding ring size stability.
derivation:
Behavior depends on $n$ (carbon chain length):
- $n=0, 1$ (Oxalic, Malonic): Loss of $CO_2$ (Decarboxylation).
  Example: Oxalic $\to CO + CO_2 + H_2O$.
- $n=2, 3$ (Succinic, Glutaric): Loss of $H_2O$ to form Cyclic Anhydride (5, 6 membered rings).
- $n=4, 5$ (Adipic, Pimelic): Loss of $CO_2 + H_2O$ to form Cyclic Ketone (5, 6 membered rings).

related_concepts.name: Blanc's Rule
related_concepts.definition: Formation of 5- and 6-membered rings is favored upon heating dicarboxylic acids.

subject: Chemistry
title: Diazonium Coupling
description: Electrophilic aromatic substitution to form Azo Dyes.
derivation:
Electrophile: Weak Diazonium cation ($Ph-N_2^+$).
Substrate: Activated benzene ring ($G = -OH, -NH_2$).
Mechanism:
1. Electrophile attacks Para position (sterically favored).
2. Loss of proton restores aromaticity.
Conditions:
- Phenols: pH 9-10 (Basic, forms Phenoxide).
- Amines: pH 4-5 (Acidic, but not too acidic to protonate amine).

related_concepts.name: Azo Dye
related_concepts.definition: Colored compounds containing $-N=N-$ linkage (e.g., Methyl Orange).

subject: Chemistry
title: Biuret Test
description: Test for presence of Peptide bonds (-CONH-). Proteins give violet color.
derivation:
Reagent: Alkaline $CuSO_4$ (1%).
Principle:
$Cu^{2+}$ ions form a square planar coordination complex with the lone pairs of 4 Nitrogen atoms from peptide bonds.
Requirement: Minimum two peptide linkages (tripeptide or larger) are needed for positive test.
Amino acids (monomers) do NOT give this test.

related_concepts.name: Xanthoproteic Test
related_concepts.definition: Test for aromatic amino acids (Tyrosine, Tryptophan) using Conc HNO3 (Yellow color).

subject: Chemistry
title: Periodic Acid Oxidation (HIO4)
description: Oxidative cleavage of Vicinal Diols (Glycols). Malaprade Reaction.
derivation:
Mechanism:
1. Formation of cyclic periodate ester intermediate.
2. C-C bond cleavage occurs.
3. The -OH groups are oxidized to Carbonyls.
Requirement: -OH or =O groups must be on adjacent carbons.
Note: $HCOOH$ is formed if terminal $CH_2OH$ is present.

related_concepts.name: Lead Tetraacetate (LTA)
related_concepts.definition: Pb(OAc)4 performs similar cleavage of 1,2-diols.

subject: Chemistry
title: Double Indicator Titration
visual_data: V_{Ph} = \frac{1}{2} V_{CO_3} + V_{OH}; \quad V_{MeOH} = V_{CO_3} + V_{OH}
description: Titration of mixture (NaOH + Na2CO3) vs HCl using Phenolphthalein (Ph) and Methyl Orange (MeOH).
derivation:
1. Phenolphthalein ($pH$ 8-10): Detects completion of $NaOH \to NaCl$ and $Na_2CO_3 \to NaHCO_3$ (half neutralization).
2. Methyl Orange ($pH$ 3-4): Detects reaction of everything, including $NaHCO_3 \to H_2CO_3$.
Calculations:
$V_{Ph}$ corresponds to $OH^- + 1/2 CO_3^{2-}$.
$V_{Total}$ (MeOH) corresponds to $OH^- + CO_3^{2-}$.

related_concepts.name: Equivalence Point
related_concepts.definition: The point in a titration where the amount of titrant added is chemically equivalent to the amount of analyte.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hardness of Water (Types)
description: Caused by Ca and Mg salts. Temporary (Boiling removes), Permanent (Chemicals needed).
derivation:
1. Temporary Hardness: Bicarbonates.
   Removal: Boiling. $Ca(HCO_3)_2 \xrightarrow{\Delta} CaCO_3 \downarrow + H_2O + CO_2$.
2. Permanent Hardness: Chlorides/Sulfates.
   Removal: Washing Soda ($Na_2CO_3$) or Ion Exchange (Zeolite/Resin).
   $Ca^{2+} + Na_2Z \rightarrow CaZ + 2Na^+$ (Z = Zeolite).

related_concepts.name: Calgon's Method
related_concepts.definition: Use of Sodium Hexametaphosphate to sequester calcium ions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Solvay Process (Ammonia-Soda)
visual_data: NaCl + NH_3 + CO_2 + H_2O \rightarrow NaHCO_3 \downarrow + NH_4Cl
description: Industrial preparation of Sodium Carbonate (Washing Soda). Principle: Low solubility of sodium bicarbonate.
derivation:
1. Carbonation: Ammoniated brine reacts with $CO_2$.
   $2NH_3 + H_2O + CO_2 \rightarrow (NH_4)_2CO_3$.
   $(NH_4)_2CO_3 + H_2O + CO_2 \rightarrow 2NH_4HCO_3$.
2. Precipitation: Ammonium bicarbonate reacts with NaCl.
   $NH_4HCO_3 + NaCl \rightarrow NaHCO_3 \downarrow + NH_4Cl$.
3. Calcination: Heating gives Soda Ash.
   $2NaHCO_3 \xrightarrow{\Delta} Na_2CO_3 + CO_2 + H_2O$.
4. Recovery: Ammonia regenerated using $Ca(OH)_2$.

related_concepts.name: Potassium Carbonate
related_concepts.definition: Cannot be made by Solvay process because $KHCO_3$ is too soluble to precipitate.

subject: Chemistry
title: Heating of Nitrates (Trends)
description: Thermal decomposition depends on polarization power of cation.
derivation:
1. Alkali Metals ($Na, K, Rb, Cs$): Stable nitrates. Decompose to Nitrite.
   $2NaNO_3 \rightarrow 2NaNO_2 + O_2$.
2. Lithium & Alkaline Earth ($Li, Mg, Ca...$): High polarizing power ($Li^+$ is small).
   Distorts electron cloud of $NO_3^-$, weakening N-O bonds.
   Decomposes to Oxide + Brown $NO_2$ gas.
   $4LiNO_3 \rightarrow 2Li_2O + 4NO_2 + O_2$.

related_concepts.name: Diagonal Relationship
related_concepts.definition: Similarity between Li and Mg due to similar ionic potential (Charge/Size ratio).

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of BeCl2
description: Beryllium Chloride exists as a polymer in solid state and dimer/monomer in vapor.
derivation:
1. Solid State: Polymeric chain via Chloro-bridges.
   Be is $sp^3$ hybridized (tetrahedral env). Coordination Number = 4.
2. Vapor Phase (< 1200K): Chloro-bridged Dimer ($Be_2Cl_4$).
   Be is $sp^2$ hybridized.
3. Vapor Phase (> 1200K): Linear Monomer ($Cl-Be-Cl$).
   Be is $sp$ hybridized (electron deficient, 4 valence e-).

related_concepts.name: Banana Bond
related_concepts.definition: 3-center-2-electron bond, though BeCl2 bridging is considered coordinate covalent (3c-4e in simple terms).

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of PCl5 (Solid)
description: In solid state, PCl5 exists as an ionic solid to improve packing efficiency.
derivation:
1. Gas Phase: Trigonal Bipyramidal ($sp^3d$).
2. Solid Phase: Auto-ionization occurs.
   $2PCl_5 \rightarrow [PCl_4]^+ + [PCl_6]^-$.
   - Cation $[PCl_4]^+$: Tetrahedral ($sp^3$).
   - Anion $[PCl_6]^-$: Octahedral ($sp^3d^2$).
   This arrangement maximizes electrostatic lattice energy.

related_concepts.name: PBr5 Solid
related_concepts.definition: Exists as $[PBr_4]^+ Br^-$ because huge $[PBr_6]^-$ is sterically unstable.

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of H2O2
description: Non-planar structure. Dihedral angle depends on phase.
derivation:
O-O bond allows rotation, but lone pair repulsion creates a twisted shape.
1. Gas Phase: Dihedral angle $\approx 111.5^\circ$. Minimized repulsion.
2. Solid Phase: Dihedral angle $\approx 90.2^\circ$.
   Reason: Strong intermolecular Hydrogen Bonding in the crystal lattice pulls the structure closer.

related_concepts.name: Peroxide Linkage
related_concepts.definition: O-O single bond, characteristic of peroxides, oxidation state -1.

subject: Chemistry
title: Clausius-Clapeyron Equation
description: Relates vapor pressure of a liquid to temperature.
derivation:
Starts from phase equilibrium condition $\Delta G = 0$.
Assume vapor behaves as Ideal Gas and molar volume of liquid is negligible.
$\frac{d \ln P}{dT} = \frac{\Delta H_{vap}}{RT^2}$.
Integrate between limits $(P_1, T_1)$ and $(P_2, T_2)$.

related_concepts.name: Boiling Point
related_concepts.definition: Temperature where vapor pressure equals external atmospheric pressure.

subject: Chemistry
title: Kirchhoff's Law (Thermochemistry)
description: Variation of enthalpy of reaction with temperature.
derivation:
Heat capacity $C_p = (\partial H / \partial T)_P$.
For a reaction: $\Delta C_p = \sum (C_p)_{products} - \sum (C_p)_{reactants}$.
$\frac{d(\Delta H)}{dT} = \Delta C_p$.
Integrate: $\int_{\Delta H_1}^{\Delta H_2} d(\Delta H) = \int_{T_1}^{T_2} \Delta C_p dT$.
Assuming $\Delta C_p$ is constant over small T range: $\Delta H_2 = \Delta H_1 + \Delta C_p \Delta T$.

related_concepts.name: Heat Capacity
related_concepts.definition: Amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a system by 1 degree.

subject: Chemistry
title: Critical Micelle Concentration (CMC)
description: Concentration above which surfactants aggregate to form micelles.
derivation:
Mechanism:
1. Low Conc: Surfactants exist as individual ions/molecules on surface.
2. At CMC: Surface is saturated. Bulk concentration increases.
3. Hydrophobic tails cluster away from water to minimize energy.
4. Hydrophilic heads face outward, forming a sphere (Micelle).
For soaps, CMC $\approx 10^{-4}$ to $10^{-3}$ mol/L.

related_concepts.name: Kraft Temperature
related_concepts.definition: The minimum temperature required for micelle formation.

subject: Chemistry
title: Claisen Condensation
description: Reaction of esters with $\alpha$-hydrogen to form $\beta$-keto esters.
derivation:
1. Enolate Formation: Strong base ($EtO^-$) removes $\alpha$-H from ester.
2. Nucleophilic Attack: Enolate attacks carbonyl of second ester molecule.
3. Elimination: Ethoxide ion ($EtO^-$) leaves, restoring double bond (C=O).
4. Acidification: Final workup gives $\beta$-keto ester.
Constraint: Requires at least 2 $\alpha$-hydrogens to prevent base hydrolysis consuming the product.

related_concepts.name: Dieckmann Condensation
related_concepts.definition: Intramolecular Claisen condensation producing a cyclic $\beta$-keto ester.

subject: Chemistry
title: Reformatsky Reaction
description: Organozinc reaction. Less reactive than Grignard, tolerates ester groups.
derivation:
1. Organozinc Formation: $\alpha$-bromoester reacts with Zinc dust.
   $Br-CH_2-COOEt + Zn \rightarrow Br-Zn-CH_2-COOEt$ (Zinc Enolate).
2. Nucleophilic Attack: C-Zn bond acts as nucleophile attacking Aldehyde/Ketone carbonyl.
3. Hydrolysis: Acid workup yields $\beta$-hydroxy ester.
Note: Magnesium (Grignard) would attack the ester group itself; Zn does not.

related_concepts.name: Organometallic
related_concepts.definition: Compounds containing a direct Metal-Carbon bond.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hunsdiecker Reaction
description: Decarboxylative bromination of silver salt of carboxylic acids.
derivation:
Mechanism: Free Radical.
1. Formation of Acyl Hypobromite: $RCOOAg + Br_2 \rightarrow RCOOBr + AgBr$.
2. Homolysis: $RCOO-Br \xrightarrow{\Delta} RCOO^\bullet + Br^\bullet$.
3. Decarboxylation: Unstable radical loses $CO_2$. $RCOO^\bullet \rightarrow R^\bullet + CO_2$.
4. Propagation: $R^\bullet + RCOOBr \rightarrow R-Br + RCOO^\bullet$.
Yield: Primary > Secondary > Tertiary.

related_concepts.name: Simonini Reaction
