related_concepts.definition: Reaction of silver salt with Iodine to form Ester ($2RCOOAg + I_2 \to RCOOR$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Mustard Oil Reaction
description: Test for Primary Amines. Formation of Alkyl Isothiocyanate.
derivation:
1. Addition: Primary amine reacts with Carbon Disulfide ($CS_2$) to form Dithiocarbamic acid salt.
   $RNH_2 + S=C=S \rightarrow R-NH-CS-S^- H^+$.
2. Decomposition: On heating with $HgCl_2$, it eliminates $H_2S$ (as $HgS$ ppt) and HCl.
   Product $R-N=C=S$ smells like mustard oil.

related_concepts.name: Hoffmann Isocyanide
related_concepts.definition: Another test for primary amines giving a foul smell (Carbylamine).

subject: Chemistry
title: Balz-Schiemann Reaction
description: Preparation of Fluorobenzene. Direct fluorination is too violent.
derivation:
1. Salt Formation: Diazonium chloride reacts with Fluoroboric acid ($HBF_4$).
   Precipitates stable Diazonium Fluoroborate ($PhN_2^+ BF_4^-$).
2. Thermal Decomposition: Dry heating decomposes the salt.
   $PhN_2^+ BF_4^- \rightarrow Ph-F + N_2 \uparrow + BF_3 \uparrow$.

related_concepts.name: Diazonium Stability
related_concepts.definition: Fluoroborate is one of the few stable diazonium salts that can be isolated.

subject: Chemistry
title: Knoevenagel Condensation
description: Condensation of aldehyde with active methylene compound (e.g., Malonic Acid).
derivation:
Reagents: Weak base (Pyridine/Piperidine).
Active Methylene: $Z-CH_2-Z'$ where Z is Electron Withdrawing ($COOH, CN, COOR$).
1. Base removes proton from active methylene $\rightarrow$ Carbanion.
2. Attack on Aldehyde Carbonyl.
3. Dehydration leads to $\alpha,\beta$-unsaturated product.
If Malonic acid is used, heating causes decarboxylation $\rightarrow$ Cinnamic acid derivative.

related_concepts.name: Active Methylene
related_concepts.definition: A CH2 group flanked by two electron-withdrawing groups, making hydrogens acidic.

subject: Chemistry
title: Liebermann Nitroso Test
description: Test for Phenols and Secondary Amines.
derivation:
1. Electrophile: $HNO_2$ generates Nitrosonium ion ($NO^+$).
2. Reaction with Phenol: Electrophilic substitution at para position $\rightarrow$ p-Nitrosophenol.
3. Tautomerism: Rearranges to Quinone Monoxime.
4. Condensation: Reacts with excess phenol/acid to form Indophenol (Red).
5. Alkali: In NaOH, the Indophenol anion is Blue.

related_concepts.name: N-Nitrosamine
related_concepts.definition: Yellow oily liquid formed when secondary amines react with nitrous acid.

subject: Chemistry
title: Barfoed's Test
description: Distinguishes Monosaccharides from Disaccharides.
derivation:
Reagent: Copper Acetate in Acetic Acid (Weakly acidic).
Principle:
Monosaccharides are stronger reducing agents than disaccharides.
In weakly acidic medium, only Monosaccharides reduce $Cu^{2+}$ to $Cu_2O$ within 2-3 minutes.
Disaccharides take much longer (>10 mins) or require hydrolysis first.

related_concepts.name: Benedict's Test
related_concepts.definition: Similar to Fehling's but uses Citrate. Used for general reducing sugars.

subject: Chemistry
title: Seliwanoff's Test
description: Distinguishes Ketoses (Fructose) from Aldoses (Glucose).
derivation:
Reagent: Resorcinol in Conc HCl.
Principle:
Ketoses dehydrate rapidly in conc acid to yield Furfural derivatives (e.g., Hydroxymethylfurfural).
Furfural condenses with Resorcinol to form a Cherry Red complex.
Aldoses dehydrate slowly, giving faint pink or no color in the same time.

related_concepts.name: Furfural
related_concepts.definition: Heterocyclic aldehyde derivative formed from dehydration of sugars.

subject: Chemistry
title: Nylon-6 (Preparation)
description: Polyamide formed by Ring Opening Polymerization of Caprolactam.
derivation:
Monomer: $\epsilon$-Caprolactam (7-membered ring containing Amide).
Process:
1. Hydrolysis: Water opens the ring to form $\epsilon$-Aminocaproic acid ($H_2N-(CH_2)_5-COOH$).
2. Polymerization: Self-condensation of the amino acid at high temp (533K).
   Forms peptide bonds between units.
Uses: Tire cords, fabrics, ropes.

related_concepts.name: Beckmann Rearrangement
related_concepts.definition: Industrial route to Caprolactam starting from Cyclohexanone Oxime.

subject: Chemistry
title: Bakelite (Network)
description: Thermosetting polymer (Phenol-Formaldehyde resin).
derivation:
Steps:
1. Electrophilic Sub: $HCHO$ adds to Phenol (o/p positions) forming Methylol phenols ($Ph-CH_2OH$).
2. Linear Polymer: Condensation gives **Novolac** (Linear chains used in paints).
3. Cross-linking: Heating with excess HCHO connects the linear chains via $-CH_2-$ bridges at all ortho/para positions.
Result: Infusible, hard 3D solid.

related_concepts.name: Thermosetting Plastic
related_concepts.definition: Polymer that becomes irreversibly hard upon heating and cannot be remolded.

subject: Chemistry
title: Green Chemistry (Atom Economy)
visual_data: \% \text{Atom Economy} = \frac{\text{Mass of Desired Product}}{\text{Total Mass of Reactants}} \times 100
description: Measure of reaction efficiency in terms of waste reduction.
derivation:
Contrast with % Yield.
Yield calculates actual vs theoretical.
Atom Economy calculates how many atoms from reactants end up in the final useful product vs waste byproducts.
Addition reactions (e.g., Hydrogenation) have 100% atom economy.
Substitution/Elimination reactions have lower economy due to byproducts.

related_concepts.name: E-Factor
related_concepts.definition: Ratio of mass of waste to mass of product (Environment Factor).

subject: Chemistry
title: Baeyer-Villiger Oxidation
description: Oxidation of Ketones to Esters using Peroxyacids (e.g., m-CPBA).
derivation:
Mechanism: Nucleophilic attack of peracid on carbonyl.
1. Criegee Intermediate forms.
2. Rearrangement: Alkyl group migrates from Carbon to Oxygen.
   Migratory Aptitude: $3^\circ Alkyl > 2^\circ > Phenyl > 1^\circ > Methyl$.
   The group best able to stabilize positive charge migrates.
3. Result: Insertion of Oxygen to form Ester.

related_concepts.name: Peroxyacid
related_concepts.definition: Acid containing an acidic -OOH group (e.g., Peracetic acid, Trifluoroperacetic acid).

subject: Chemistry
title: Michael Addition
description: Thermodynamic 1,4-addition of a nucleophile (Michael Donor) to an $\alpha,\beta$-unsaturated carbonyl (Michael Acceptor).
derivation:
1. Donor Formation: Base removes proton from active methylene (e.g., Malonic ester) $\rightarrow$ Enolate.
2. Attack: Enolate attacks the $\beta$-carbon of the $\alpha,\beta$-unsaturated system.
   Reason: Soft nucleophiles prefer Soft electrophilic centers ($\beta$-carbon) over Hard centers (Carbonyl C).
3. Protonation: Enol tautomerizes to stable Ketone.

related_concepts.name: Robinson Annulation
related_concepts.definition: Michael addition followed by Intramolecular Aldol condensation to form a 6-membered ring.

subject: Chemistry
title: Curtius Rearrangement
description: Thermal decomposition of Acyl Azide to Isocyanate, then Amine.
derivation:
1. Precursor: Acyl Azide ($RCON_3$) formed from Acid Chloride + $NaN_3$.
2. Rearrangement: Loss of $N_2$ gas drives migration of Alkyl group ($R$) from Carbon to Nitrogen.
   Forms Isocyanate ($R-N=C=O$).
3. Hydrolysis: Isocyanate reacts with water to form Carbamic Acid ($RNHCOOH$), which spontaneously decarboxylates to Amine.

related_concepts.name: Schmidt Reaction
related_concepts.definition: Similar rearrangement using Hydrazoic Acid ($HN_3$) directly with Carboxylic Acid.

subject: Chemistry
title: Gabriel Phthalimide Synthesis
description: Synthesis of pure primary aliphatic amines.
derivation:
1. Acid-Base: Phthalimide (pKa ~8.3) + KOH $\rightarrow$ Potassium Phthalimide (Nucleophile).
2. SN2: Nucleophile attacks $1^\circ$ Alkyl Halide ($RX$).
   *Note: Aryl halides cannot be used (No SN2).*
3. Hydrolysis: Hydrazine ($NH_2NH_2$) or Acid cleaves the amide bonds, releasing pure $1^\circ$ Amine.

related_concepts.name: Nucleophilicity
related_concepts.definition: The phthalimide anion is a strong, bulky nucleophile.

subject: Chemistry
title: Osmium Tetroxide (OsO4)
description: Syn-hydroxylation of alkenes (Addition of two OH groups to same side).
derivation:
Mechanism: Concerted Cycloaddition.
1. $OsO_4$ adds to the double bond forming a cyclic Osmate Ester.
   Geometry requires oxygen atoms to add from the same face (Syn).
2. Hydrolysis: $NaHSO_3$ cleaves the O-Os bonds, releasing the cis-1,2-diol.
Stereochemistry: Cis-alkene $\rightarrow$ Meso diol; Trans-alkene $\rightarrow$ Racemic diol.

related_concepts.name: Cold Alkaline KMnO4
related_concepts.definition: Baeyer's Reagent. Also performs syn-hydroxylation but can over-oxidize.

subject: Chemistry
title: DNA Double Helix
description: Watson-Crick Model. Two antiparallel strands held by H-bonds.
derivation:
Base Pairing Rules:
1. Adenine (Purine) pairs with Thymine (Pyrimidine) via **2 Hydrogen Bonds**.
2. Guanine (Purine) pairs with Cytosine (Pyrimidine) via **3 Hydrogen Bonds**.
Backbone: Sugar-Phosphate-Sugar chain on the outside (Hydrophilic).
Base Stacking: Hydrophobic interactions between stacked bases stabilize the helix.

related_concepts.name: Chargaff's Rule
related_concepts.definition: In DNA, moles of Purines = moles of Pyrimidines ($A+G = T+C$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Reducing Sugars
description: Sugars capable of reducing Tollens'/Fehling's reagents.
derivation:
Structural Requirement:
Must have a Hemiacetal group (Carbon bonded to -OH, -OR, -H, -R).
This allows the ring to open in solution, regenerating the free Aldehyde group.
Examples: Glucose, Fructose (tautomerizes to aldose), Maltose, Lactose.
Exception: Sucrose (non-reducing) because linkage involves both anomeric carbons ($C1-C2$).

related_concepts.name: Mutarotation
related_concepts.definition: Change in optical rotation because of interconversion between alpha and beta anomers via open chain.

subject: Chemistry
title: PHBV (Biodegradable)
description: Poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate-co-beta-hydroxyvalerate.
derivation:
Copolymerization:
Monomer 1: $CH_3-CH(OH)-CH_2-COOH$
Monomer 2: $CH_3-CH_2-CH(OH)-CH_2-COOH$
Reaction: Esterification (Condensation) between -OH of one and -COOH of another.
Significance: Bacterial degradation breaks ester linkages.

related_concepts.name: Nylon-2-nylon-6
related_concepts.definition: Another biodegradable copolymer of Glycine and Aminocaproic acid.

subject: Chemistry
title: Dacron (Terylene)
description: Polyester. Used in crease-resistant fabrics.
derivation:
Condensation Polymerization:
Monomers: 1,4-Benzene dicarboxylic acid + Ethane-1,2-diol.
Process: Loss of water molecules at high temp ($420-460K$) with Zinc Acetate-Antimony Trioxide catalyst.
Linkage: Ester ($ -CO-O- $).

related_concepts.name: Step-Growth Polymerization
related_concepts.definition: Polymerization mechanism involving stepwise reaction between functional groups.

subject: Chemistry
title: Tranquilizers (Mechanism)
description: Drugs for stress/anxiety. Example: Equanil, Barbiturates.
derivation:
Biochemical Basis:
Depression is often linked to low levels of Noradrenaline (neurotransmitter).
Antidepressants inhibit the enzymes that degrade noradrenaline.
Sedatives (Barbiturates like Luminal) act as GABA potentiators, depressing the CNS.

related_concepts.name: Psychotherapeutic Drugs
related_concepts.definition: Chemicals used for treatment of mental diseases.

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of P4O10
description: Dimer of P2O5. Dehydrating agent.
derivation:
Geometry: Based on $P_4$ tetrahedron.
1. Insert an Oxygen atom into each of the 6 P-P edges (Bridging Oxygens).
2. Add a terminal Oxygen atom to each of the 4 Phosphorus atoms ($P=O$).
Total P-O-P bonds = 6.
Each P is surrounded by 4 Oxygens (Tetrahedral environment).

related_concepts.name: Anhydride
related_concepts.definition: P4O10 is the anhydride of Phosphoric Acid ($P_4O_{10} + 6H_2O \rightarrow 4H_3PO_4$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of N2O5
description: Dinitrogen Pentoxide. Structure changes with phase.
derivation:
1. Gas Phase: Covalent molecule. Planar. $N-O-N$ bond angle is non-linear.
   Resonance makes terminal N-O bonds identical.
2. Solid Phase: Nitronium Nitrate.
   Ionizes to $[NO_2]^+$ (Linear, sp) and $[NO_3]^-$ (Trigonal Planar, sp2).
   This ionic character makes it a solid at room temp.

related_concepts.name: Anhydride
related_concepts.definition: N2O5 is the anhydride of Nitric Acid ($N_2O_5 + H_2O \rightarrow 2HNO_3$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of ClO2
description: Chlorine Dioxide. Paramagnetic yellow gas.
derivation:
Valence Electrons: $7 (Cl) + 2 \times 6 (O) = 19 e^-$.
Structure: Bent shape ($sp^2$ hybridized Cl).
Unpaired electron is delocalized, but ClO2 does not dimerize easily (unlike $NO_2$).
Bond Angle: $117^\circ$ (Repulsion between double bonds > single electron).

related_concepts.name: Bleaching Agent
related_concepts.definition: Used in paper industry; acts by oxidation.

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of I3-
description: Triiodide ion. Formed when $I_2$ dissolves in KI.
derivation:
Central Atom: Iodine.
Valence e-: 7 + 2 (bonding) + 1 (charge) = 10.
Electron Pairs: 5.
Hybridization: $sp^3d$.
Geometry: Trigonal Bipyramidal.
Lone Pairs: 3 (Equatorial positions to minimize repulsion).
Bond Pairs: 2 (Axial positions).
Shape: Linear ($180^\circ$).

related_concepts.name: Polyhalides
related_concepts.definition: Ions like $I_3^-$, $Br_3^-$, $ICl_2^-$ formed by halogens combining with halide ions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Cupellation
description: Refining of Silver containing Lead impurity.
derivation:
Principle: Lead is easily oxidized, Silver is not.
Process: Molten alloy is heated in a cupel (boat made of bone ash) with air blast.
Lead oxidizes to PbO (Litharge).
PbO either volatilizes or is absorbed by the porous cupel.
Pure silver remains behind.

related_concepts.name: Parting
related_concepts.definition: Separation of Gold from Silver using nitric acid (Silver dissolves, Gold does not).

subject: Chemistry
title: Poling
description: Refining of Blister Copper containing its own oxide ($Cu_2O$).
derivation:
Process: Molten metal is stirred with logs of green wood.
Mechanism:
Heat decomposes the green wood, releasing Hydrocarbon gases (Methane).
These gases act as reducing agents.
$3Cu_2O + CH_4 \rightarrow 6Cu + 2H_2O + CO$.
Reduces the oxide impurity back to metal.

related_concepts.name: Pyrometallurgy
related_concepts.definition: Branch of metallurgy involving high temperatures.

subject: Chemistry
title: Flame Photometry Colors
description: Qualitative detection of Alkali metals.
derivation:
Principle: Thermal Excitation.
1. Heat atomizes the salt.
2. Valence electron is excited to higher energy level.
3. Electron relaxes to ground state, emitting photon.
4. Energy gap corresponds to specific wavelength in visible region.
$Mg$ and $Be$ do not give flame test (High Ionization Energy, electron not excited by Bunsen flame).

related_concepts.name: Cobalt Glass
related_concepts.definition: Used to view Potassium flame (filters out yellow Na light).

subject: Chemistry
title: Mohr's Salt (Formula)
description: Ferrous Ammonium Sulfate. A Double Salt.
derivation:
Structure:
Contains $Fe^{2+}$, $NH_4^+$, and $SO_4^{2-}$ ions in equimolar ratio.
Stability: More stable towards aerial oxidation than pure Ferrous Sulfate.
Use: Primary standard in Redox titrations (titrated against $KMnO_4$).
Note: It is a double salt (dissociates fully), not a coordination complex.

related_concepts.name: Double Salt
related_concepts.definition: Addition compound stable in solid state but loses identity in solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Potash Alum (Formula)
description: Double salt of Potassium and Aluminium. General formula $M_2SO_4 \cdot M'_2(SO_4)_3 \cdot 24H_2O$.
derivation:
Geometry:
Both cations ($K^+$ and $Al^{3+}$) are surrounded by 6 water molecules (Octahedral).
Applications:
1. Coagulant in water purification (neutralizes negative charge on colloidal clay).
2. Antiseptic (Aftershave).
3. Mordant in dyeing.

related_concepts.name: Pseudo Alum
related_concepts.definition: Alums containing divalent ions instead of monovalent ones are not true alums.

subject: Chemistry
title: Antifreeze (Ethylene Glycol)
description: Application of Depression in Freezing Point.
derivation:
Purpose: Prevent water in car radiators from freezing in winter.
Mechanism:
Ethylene Glycol (solute) is added to water (solvent).
The solute particles disrupt the formation of the ice crystal lattice.
This lowers the vapor pressure of the solid-liquid equilibrium.
Result: Freezing point drops below $0^\circ C$ (e.g., -30 to -40 C).

related_concepts.name: De-icing
related_concepts.definition: Sprinkling NaCl/CaCl2 on roads lowers FP of water, melting ice.

subject: Chemistry
title: MPV Reduction
description: Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction. Selective reduction of Ketones to Secondary Alcohols.
derivation:
Mechanism: Hydride Transfer via Cyclic Transition State.
1. Coordination: Carbonyl oxygen binds to Aluminum of Aluminum Isopropoxide.
2. Hydride Shift: A hydride ion ($H^-$) transfers from the Isopropoxide group to the Ketone carbonyl carbon via a 6-membered cyclic transition state.
3. Result: Ketone becomes Alcohol (after hydrolysis); Isopropoxide becomes Acetone (oxidized).

related_concepts.name: Oppenauer Oxidation
related_concepts.definition: The reverse reaction. Uses Aluminum t-butoxide to oxidize alcohols to ketones.

subject: Chemistry
title: Claisen Rearrangement
description: [3,3]-Sigmatropic rearrangement. Intramolecular migration.
derivation:
Thermal Concerted Mechanism:
1. The $\pi$-bond of the allyl group attacks the benzene ring at the ortho position.
2. Simultaneously, the C-O bond breaks and the C-C bond forms (cyclic transition state).
3. Tautomerization: The intermediate ketone enolizes to restore aromaticity, yielding the Phenol.
Note: If ortho positions are blocked, migration occurs to para position.

related_concepts.name: Sigmatropic Shift
related_concepts.definition: Pericyclic reaction where a sigma bond migrates across a pi system.

subject: Chemistry
title: Benzilic Acid Rearrangement
description: Conversion of 1,2-Diketone (Benzil) to $\alpha$-Hydroxy Acid salt (Benzilate).
derivation:
1. Nucleophilic Attack: $OH^-$ attacks one carbonyl carbon.
2. 1,2-Phenyl Shift: The Phenyl group migrates to the adjacent carbonyl carbon (which is electron deficient).
   Driving Force: Formation of stable Carboxylate anion.
3. Proton Transfer: Rapid intramolecular proton transfer from -OH to alkoxide oxygen.

related_concepts.name: Intramolecular Redox
related_concepts.definition: One carbon is oxidized (to acid), the other reduced (to alcohol).

subject: Chemistry
title: Diels-Alder Reaction
description: [4+2] Cycloaddition reaction. Forms 6-membered rings.
derivation:
Concerted Pericyclic Mechanism:
1. Interaction between HOMO of Diene (electron rich, 4$\pi$) and LUMO of Dienophile (electron poor, 2$\pi$).
2. Three $\pi$-bonds break, two $\sigma$-bonds and one new $\pi$-bond form simultaneously.
3. Stereochemistry: Syn-addition. Retains stereochemistry of reactants.

related_concepts.name: Woodward-Hoffmann Rules
related_concepts.definition: Rules predicting stereochemistry of pericyclic reactions based on orbital symmetry.

subject: Chemistry
title: Cope Elimination
description: Thermal elimination of Amine Oxides to form Alkenes.
derivation:
Mechanism: Cyclic Syn-Elimination (Ei).
1. The Oxygen of the amine oxide acts as an internal base.
2. It abstracts a $\beta$-proton from the alkyl chain.
3. Simultaneous C-H bond breaking and C-N bond cleavage via a 5-membered transition state.
Result: Stereoselective formation of alkene (Syn product).

related_concepts.name: Pyrolysis of Esters
related_concepts.definition: Another syn-elimination reaction yielding alkenes/acids upon heating esters.

subject: Chemistry
title: Schotten-Baumann Reaction
description: Benzoylation of phenols or amines using Benzoyl Chloride in alkaline medium.
derivation:
1. Nucleophilic Attack: Amine/Phenol attacks carbonyl of Benzoyl Chloride.
2. Elimination: Chloride ion ($Cl^-$) leaves.
3. Role of Base ($NaOH$): Neutralizes the HCl produced.
   This shifts the equilibrium forward and prevents protonation of the amine reactant.

related_concepts.name: Benzoylation
related_concepts.definition: Introduction of a Benzoyl group ($Ph-CO-$) to protect -OH or -NH2 groups.

subject: Chemistry
title: Fries Rearrangement
description: Conversion of Phenolic Esters to Acyl Phenols.
derivation:
Mechanism involves Lewis Acid ($AlCl_3$).
1. Complexation: $AlCl_3$ coordinates with ester oxygen.
2. Cleavage: Acylium ion ($RCO^+$) is generated.
3. Electrophilic Attack: $RCO^+$ attacks the ring at Ortho/Para positions.
Temperature Effect: Low temp favors Para; High temp favors Ortho (Thermodynamic product, chelation stabilized).

related_concepts.name: Acylium Ion
related_concepts.definition: Resonance stabilized cation ($R-C^+=O \leftrightarrow R-C\equiv O^+$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Jahn-Teller Distortion
description: Removal of degeneracy in unsymmetrically filled d-orbitals (e.g., $Cu^{2+}$ $d^9$).
derivation:
Thermodynamic Driver: System lowers its energy by distorting geometry.
Case: $d^9$ ($e_g^3$). The single hole could be in $dx^2-y^2$ or $dz^2$.
To resolve this, the ligands along the Z-axis move away (Z-out elongation).
Result: $dz^2$ energy lowers, $dx^2-y^2$ energy raises.
Stabilization Energy > Distortion Energy.

related_concepts.name: Z-out Distortion
related_concepts.definition: Most common J-T distortion where axial bonds are longer than equatorial bonds.

subject: Chemistry
title: Trans Effect
visual_data: CN^- > CO > NO > Ph^- > PR_3 > ... > H_2O
description: Kinetic effect in Square Planar complexes (Pt). Ligand directs incoming group to trans position.
derivation:
Mechanism depends on transition state stability.
Strong trans-directing ligands (like $\pi$-bonders $CN^-, CO$) weaken the bond trans to themselves by withdrawing electron density (Trans Influence) or stabilizing the 5-coordinate intermediate.
Result: Substitution happens opposite to the strong ligand.

related_concepts.name: Cisplatin Synthesis
related_concepts.definition: Uses trans effect sequence to ensure Chlorides end up cis to each other.

subject: Chemistry
title: Wilkinson's Catalyst
description: Homogeneous catalyst for hydrogenation of alkenes.
derivation:
Mechanism Cycle:
1. Dissociation: Loss of one $PPh_3$ to open a site.
2. Oxidative Addition: $H_2$ adds to Rh ($Rh^{+1} \to Rh^{+3}$).
3. Coordination: Alkene binds to metal.
4. Insertion: Hydride moves to alkene (forms Alkyl-Rh).
5. Reductive Elimination: Alkane leaves, regenerating catalyst.

related_concepts.name: Homogeneous Catalysis
related_concepts.definition: Catalyst and reactants are in the same phase (usually liquid solution).

subject: Chemistry
title: Ziegler-Natta Catalyst
description: Used for coordination polymerization of ethene/propene.
derivation:
Action:
Produces **High Density Polyethylene (HDPE)**.
The catalyst provides a template for the monomer to add in a regular, stereospecific manner.
Result: Linear chains with no branching, allowing close packing and high density/strength.

related_concepts.name: Stereoregularity
related_concepts.definition: Isotactic or Syndiotactic polymers formed via stereospecific catalysis.

subject: Chemistry
title: Self-Reduction (Auto-reduction)
description: Extraction of less electropositive metals (Cu, Pb, Hg) from sulfide ores.
derivation:
Process: Partial Roasting.
1. Roasting: Sulfide ore is partially oxidized to Oxide.
   $2Cu_2S + 3O_2 \rightarrow 2Cu_2O + 2SO_2$.
2. Self-Reduction: Air supply is cut off. Remaining Sulfide reacts with formed Oxide.
   $Cu_2S + 2Cu_2O \rightarrow 6Cu + SO_2$.
No external reducing agent (C/CO) is needed.

related_concepts.name: Bessemerization
related_concepts.definition: The process carried out in a Bessemer converter for Copper extraction.

subject: Chemistry
title: F-Centers (Farbe Centers)
description: Point defect causing color in ionic crystals (e.g., NaCl turns Yellow).
derivation:
Mechanism:
1. Crystal (NaCl) heated in metal vapor (Na).
2. Na atoms deposit on surface, $Cl^-$ diffuses out to form NaCl.
3. Electron lost by Na ($Na \to Na^+ + e^-$) diffuses *into* the crystal to occupy the vacant anion site.
4. Excitation of this trapped electron by visible light causes color.

related_concepts.name: Non-stoichiometric Defect
related_concepts.definition: Defects that change the ratio of cations to anions (Metal Excess Defect).

subject: Chemistry
title: Fuel Cell (H2-O2)
description: Galvanic cell converting chemical energy directly to electricity.
derivation:
Electrolyte: Hot aqueous KOH.
Anode (Oxidation): $2H_2(g) + 4OH^-(aq) \rightarrow 4H_2O(l) + 4e^-$.
Cathode (Reduction): $O_2(g) + 2H_2O(l) + 4e^- \rightarrow 4OH^-(aq)$.
Net Reaction: $2H_2 + O_2 \rightarrow 2H_2O$.
Pollution free, high efficiency ($\\eta \approx 70\\%$).

related_concepts.name: Apollo Space Program
related_concepts.definition: Used H2-O2 fuel cells for power and drinking water supply.

subject: Chemistry
title: Dry Cell (Leclanché)
description: Primary battery (non-rechargeable).
derivation:
Anode: Zinc container ($Zn \to Zn^{2+} + 2e^-$).
Cathode: Graphite rod surrounded by $MnO_2 + C$.
Reaction: $MnO_2$ is reduced to $MnO(OH)$ (Manganese goes from +4 to +3).
Electrolyte: Paste of $NH_4Cl + ZnCl_2$.
Ammonia produced complexes with $Zn^{2+}$ ($[Zn(NH_3)_4]^{2+}$), preventing pressure buildup.

related_concepts.name: Primary Cell
related_concepts.definition: Cell where reaction occurs only once and cannot be reversed.

subject: Chemistry
title: Steady State Approximation
description: Assumption for reaction mechanisms involving unstable intermediates.
derivation:
Logic:
1. Intermediate (I) is very reactive.
2. Its concentration remains low and constant throughout the main reaction.
3. Rate of Formation of I = Rate of Consumption of I.
Used to derive Rate Laws for complex multi-step reactions.

related_concepts.name: Rate Determining Step (RDS)
related_concepts.definition: The slowest step in a reaction mechanism that governs the overall rate.

subject: Chemistry
title: Cobalt Nitrate Test
description: Charcoal cavity test for Zinc, Magnesium, Aluminum.
derivation:
1. Salt + $Na_2CO_3$ heated on charcoal $\rightarrow$ Oxide ($ZnO$).
2. Add Cobalt Nitrate ($Co(NO_3)_2$) and heat.
3. Formation of Mixed Oxides (Spinels).
   $ZnO + CoO \rightarrow CoZnO_2$ (Rinmann's Green).
   $Al_2O_3 + CoO \rightarrow CoAl_2O_4$ (Thenard's Blue).
   $MgO + CoO \rightarrow CoMgO_2$ (Pink).

related_concepts.name: Dry Test
related_concepts.definition: Preliminary test performed before dissolving salt in water.

subject: Chemistry
title: Calgon's Method
description: Water softening agent. Sequesters $Ca^{2+}$ ions.
derivation:
Dissociation: $Na_2[Na_4(PO_3)_6] \rightleftharpoons 2Na^+ + [Na_4P_6O_{18}]^{2-}$.
Action: Calcium ions from hard water displace Sodium ions in the complex anion.
$M^{2+} + [Na_4P_6O_{18}]^{2-} \rightarrow [Na_2MP_6O_{18}]^{2-} + 2Na^+$.
Calcium stays trapped in the complex and doesn't precipitate with soap.

related_concepts.name: Sequestration
related_concepts.definition: Process of forming a soluble complex with metal ions to prevent them from reacting.

subject: Chemistry
title: Bleaching Powder
description: Commercial formula. Active ingredient is Calcium Hypochlorite.
derivation:
Preparation: Action of Chlorine gas on Dry Slaked Lime.
$Ca(OH)_2 + Cl_2 \rightarrow CaOCl_2 + H_2O$.
Mechanism of Bleaching:
$CaOCl_2 + H_2SO_4 \text{ (dil)} \rightarrow CaSO_4 + CaCl_2 + 2HOCl$.
$HOCl \rightarrow HCl + [O]$ (Nascent Oxygen).
Nascent oxygen oxidizes colored matter to colorless.

related_concepts.name: Available Chlorine
related_concepts.definition: Measure of bleaching powder quality, determined by iodine liberation.

subject: Chemistry
title: Test for Fluoride
description: Etching of glass test or Water Drop test.
derivation:
1. Mix salt with Sand ($SiO_2$) and Conc $H_2SO_4$.
2. Heating releases $SiF_4$ gas.
   $CaF_2 + H_2SO_4 \rightarrow CaSO_4 + 2HF$
   $4HF + SiO_2 \rightarrow SiF_4 + 2H_2O$
3. Hold a drop of water in a loop over the gas.
   $3SiF_4 + 2H_2O \rightarrow SiO_2 \downarrow + 2H_2SiF_6$.
   Turbidity ($SiO_2$) appears in the water drop.

related_concepts.name: Etching
related_concepts.definition: Corrosive action of HF on glass (silicates).

subject: Chemistry
title: Wittig Reaction
description: Synthesis of Alkenes from Carbonyls using Phosphorus Ylide.
derivation:
Reagent: Phosphonium Ylide ($Ph_3P^+-C^-R_2$).
1. Nucleophilic Attack: Ylide carbon attacks Carbonyl carbon.
   Forms a Betaine intermediate (zwitterion).
2. Ring Closure: Oxygen bonds to Phosphorus forming a 4-membered Oxaphosphetane ring.
3. Elimination: Strong P=O bond formation drives the ring opening to yield Alkene and Triphenylphosphine Oxide.

related_concepts.name: Ylide
related_concepts.definition: A neutral molecule with positive and negative charges on adjacent atoms.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hofmann Elimination (Amine)
description: Elimination of Quaternary Ammonium Hydroxides. Gives Less Substituted Alkene (Hofmann Product).
derivation:
Mechanism: E2 (Concerted).
Leaving Group: Bulky Trialkylamine ($-NR_3$).
Base: Hydroxide ($OH^-$).
Logic:
Due to the steric bulk of the leaving group, the base abstracts the *least hindered* (acidic) $\beta$-proton (terminal methyl).
This leads to the less stable (less substituted) alkene as the major product.

related_concepts.name: Saytzeff Rule
related_concepts.definition: Opposite rule favoring the more substituted alkene (Thermodynamic product).

subject: Chemistry
title: Benzyne Mechanism
description: Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution via Elimination-Addition.
derivation:
1. Elimination: Strong base ($NH_2^-$) removes proton ortho to Chlorine.
   Loss of $Cl^-$ generates **Benzyne** intermediate (Triple bond in ring).
2. Addition: Nucleophile ($NH_2^-$) attacks the Benzyne triple bond.
   Since the triple bond is symmetric, attack can occur at either carbon (ipso or ortho).
   Protonation yields Aniline.

related_concepts.name: Cine Substitution
related_concepts.definition: When the incoming nucleophile occupies a position adjacent to the leaving group.

subject: Chemistry
title: SNAr Mechanism
description: Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution (Addition-Elimination). Requires EWG at o/p positions.
derivation:
Example: p-Nitrochlorobenzene + $OH^-$.
1. Addition (Slow/RDS): Nucleophile attacks carbon bonded to halogen.
   Resonance stabilized Carbanion intermediate (Meisenheimer Complex).
   The negative charge is delocalized onto the Nitro group.
2. Elimination (Fast): Loss of Halide ion restores aromaticity.
   Reactivity: $F \gg Cl > Br > I$ (Stronger C-F dipole favors step 1).

related_concepts.name: Meisenheimer Complex
related_concepts.definition: Stable anionic intermediate formed during SNAr reactions.

subject: Chemistry
title: MnO2 Oxidation
description: Selective oxidation of Allylic and Benzylic alcohols to Aldehydes/Ketones.
derivation:
Manganese Dioxide ($MnO_2$) acts as a mild oxidant.
Selectivity:
It oxidizes -OH groups activated by a double bond or benzene ring (Allylic/Benzylic).
It leaves ordinary primary/secondary alcohols and double bonds untouched at room temperature.

related_concepts.name: Chemo-selectivity
related_concepts.definition: Preferential reaction of a reagent with one functional group over another.

subject: Chemistry
title: Ester Hydrolysis (Saponification)
description: Base-catalyzed hydrolysis. Irreversible. $B_{AC}2$ mechanism.
derivation:
Mechanism: $B_{AC}2$ (Base catalyzed, Acyl cleavage, Bimolecular).
1. Attack: $OH^-$ attacks Carbonyl carbon (Tetrahedral intermediate).
2. Elimination: Alkoxide ($R'O^-$) leaves, forming Carboxylic Acid ($RCOOH$).
3. Acid-Base (Irreversible): Strong base $R'O^-$ deprotonates the acid instantly.
   Forms stable Carboxylate ion ($RCOO^-$) and Alcohol ($R'OH$).

related_concepts.name: Saponification Value
related_concepts.definition: Mg of KOH required to saponify 1g of fat/oil.

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of S8
description: Most stable allotrope of Sulfur (Rhombic/Monoclinic).
derivation:
Atomic Arrangement:
8 Sulfur atoms form a cyclic ring.
To minimize repulsion between lone pairs on adjacent Sulfurs, the ring adopts a non-planar 'Crown' conformation.
Bond Angle: $107^\circ$.
Dihedral Angle: $98^\circ$.
Note: $S_6$ (Chair form) is another allotrope.

related_concepts.name: Catenation
related_concepts.definition: Self-linking property. Sulfur shows strong catenation (second only to Carbon).

subject: Chemistry
title: Structure of Borax Anion
description: The structural unit in Borax ($Na_2[B_4O_5(OH)_4] \cdot 8H_2O$).
derivation:
Network of Boron and Oxygen:
1. Two Boron atoms are $sp^2$ (Triangular).
2. Two Boron atoms are $sp^3$ (Tetrahedral).
3. Five $B-O-B$ linkages form two 6-membered rings fused together.
4. Four $-OH$ groups are attached, one to each Boron.
Correct formula emphasizes it contains 8 water molecules of crystallization.

related_concepts.name: Buffer Action
related_concepts.definition: Borax solution acts as a buffer (pH ~9) due to formation of weak acid $H_3BO_3$ and $OH^-$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Silanes (General Formula)
description: Silicon hydrides. Homologous series similar to Alkanes but much more reactive.
derivation:
Stability:
Si-Si and Si-H bonds are weaker than C-C and C-H bonds.
Reactivity:
Spontaneously flammable in air: $SiH_4 + 2O_2 \rightarrow SiO_2 + 2H_2O$.
Hydrolysis: Reacts with water/alkali to release Hydrogen.
$SiH_4 + 2H_2O \rightarrow SiO_2 + 4H_2 \uparrow$.

related_concepts.name: Reducing Agent
related_concepts.definition: Silanes are strong reducing agents used in organic synthesis.

subject: Chemistry
title: Liquation
description: Refining method for low melting metals (Sn, Pb, Bi).
derivation:
Principle: Difference in Melting Points.
Process:
Impure metal is placed on the sloping hearth of a reverberatory furnace.
Temperature is kept just above the MP of the metal but below MP of impurity.
Pure metal melts and flows down, leaving solid dross (impurities) behind.

related_concepts.name: Zone Refining
related_concepts.definition: Purification based on solubility difference in molten vs solid state (for Si, Ge).

subject: Chemistry
title: Conductance vs Dilution
description: Effect of adding water on Specific ($\kappa$) and Molar ($\Lambda_m$) conductance.
derivation:
1. Specific Conductance ($\kappa$): Conductivity of 1 cm$^3$ solution.
   On dilution, number of ions per cm$^3$ decreases $\rightarrow$ $\kappa$ Decreases.
2. Molar Conductance ($\Lambda_m = \kappa \times V$):
   Although $\kappa$ decreases, Volume ($V$) containing 1 mole increases much more.
   For weak electrolytes, degree of dissociation also increases.
   Net effect $\rightarrow$ $\Lambda_m$ Increases.

related_concepts.name: Debye-Huckel
related_concepts.definition: Interionic attractions decrease on dilution, aiding mobility in strong electrolytes.

subject: Chemistry
title: Cell Constant
description: Geometric parameter of a conductivity cell.
derivation:
From resistance formula: $R = \rho \frac{l}{A}$.
Conductivity $\kappa = 1/\rho$.
$R = \frac{1}{\kappa} \left( \frac{l}{A} \right)$.
Rearrange: $\frac{l}{A} = \kappa \times R$.
The ratio $l/A$ is fixed for a given cell, called Cell Constant ($G^*$, unit $cm^{-1}$).

related_concepts.name: Wheatstone Bridge
related_concepts.definition: Circuit used to measure the resistance R of the electrolytic solution.

subject: Chemistry
title: Molisch's Test
description: General test for Carbohydrates.
derivation:
Reagent: $\alpha$-Naphthol in alcohol + Conc $H_2SO_4$.
Mechanism:
1. Acid dehydrates the sugar to form Furfural (from pentose) or Hydroxymethylfurfural (from hexose).
2. Furfural condenses with two molecules of $\alpha$-Naphthol.
3. Product: Violet/Purple ring at the junction of two liquids.

related_concepts.name: Dehydration
related_concepts.definition: Removal of water molecules by conc. sulfuric acid.

subject: Chemistry
title: Ninhydrin Test
description: General test for Amino Acids (Free -NH2 group).
derivation:
Reaction:
Amino acid + Ninhydrin $\rightarrow$ Aldehyde + $CO_2$ + Reduced Ninhydrin + $NH_3$.
Then, Reduced Ninhydrin + $NH_3$ + Ninhydrin $\rightarrow$ Purple Complex.
Note: Proline (secondary amine) gives a Yellow color.

related_concepts.name: Chromatography
related_concepts.definition: Ninhydrin is used as a locating agent to visualize amino acid spots.

subject: Chemistry
title: Beilstein Test
description: Detection of Halogens (Cl, Br, I) in organic compounds.
derivation:
Procedure: Heat Copper wire with compound in Bunsen flame.
Reaction: Halogen reacts with Copper to form volatile Copper Halide ($CuX_2$).
Observation: Copper halides impart a characteristic Green or Blue-Green color to the flame.
Limit: Does not distinguish between Cl, Br, I. Urea/Thiourea also give positive test (due to C-N).

related_concepts.name: Lassaigne's Test
related_concepts.definition: More reliable wet test for halogens involving Silver Nitrate.

subject: Chemistry
title: Vitamins (Fat Soluble)
description: Stored in liver/adipose tissue. Excess can be toxic (Hypervitaminosis).
derivation:
Functions/Deficiency:
- **A (Retinol):** Vision. Def: Night Blindness, Xerophthalmia.
- **D (Calciferol):** Calcium absorption. Def: Rickets (kids), Osteomalacia (adults).
- **E (Tocopherol):** Antioxidant. Def: Muscular weakness, sterility.
- **K (Phylloquinone):** Blood clotting. Def: Hemorrhage.

related_concepts.name: Water Soluble
related_concepts.definition: Vitamins B and C. Excreted in urine, must be supplied regularly.

subject: Chemistry
title: Antibiotics (Action)
description: Classification based on mode of action.
derivation:
1. Bactericidal (Kills): Penicillin, Ofloxacin, Aminoglycosides.
   - Targets cell wall synthesis or irreversible binding.
2. Bacteriostatic (Inhibits growth): Erythromycin, Tetracycline, Chloramphenicol.
   - Inhibits protein synthesis or metabolism, allowing immune system to clear infection.

related_concepts.name: Broad Spectrum
related_concepts.definition: Antibiotics effective against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Chloramphenicol).

subject: Chemistry
title: Blast Furnace Zones
description: Temperature zones in Iron extraction (Top to Bottom: Low to High T).
derivation:
1. Reduction (Top, 500-900K): $Fe_2O_3 + CO \rightarrow Fe$.
2. Slag Formation (Middle, 1000K): $CaCO_3 \to CaO + CO_2$; $CaO + SiO_2 \to CaSiO_3$.
3. Fusion (Lower, 1500K): Iron melts, dissolves Carbon.
4. Combustion (Base, 2200K): $C + O_2 \rightarrow CO_2$ (Exothermic heat source).

related_concepts.name: Pig Iron
related_concepts.definition: Iron obtained from blast furnace containing ~4% Carbon and impurities.

subject: Chemistry
title: Cyclotrimetaphosphoric Acid
description: Cyclic trimer of metaphosphoric acid.
derivation:
Structure:
Six-membered ring with alternating P and O atoms.
Each Phosphorus is bonded to:
- Two ring oxygens.
- One terminal oxygen ($P=O$).
- One hydroxyl group ($-OH$).
It is tribasic (3 ionizable protons).

related_concepts.name: Polyphosphates
related_concepts.definition: Linear or cyclic polymers containing P-O-P linkages.

subject: Chemistry
title: Isotonic Solutions
description: Solutions having the same Osmotic Pressure at the same temperature.
derivation:
Formula: $\pi = iCRT$.
If $\pi_1 = \pi_2$ and $T$ is constant:
$i_1 C_1 = i_2 C_2$.
For non-electrolytes ($i=1$): Molar concentrations must be equal.
Significance: 0.9% (w/v) NaCl is isotonic with human blood (RBCs).

related_concepts.name: Hemolysis
related_concepts.definition: Bursting of RBCs when placed in a hypotonic solution (water enters cell).

subject: Chemistry
title: Number of Stereoisomers
description: Formulas for calculating optical isomers. $n$: number of chiral centers.
derivation:
1. Unsymmetrical Molecule: No plane of symmetry. Total = $2^n$.
2. Symmetrical (Even n): Total = Active ($2^{n-1}$) + Meso ($2^{n/2-1}$).
3. Symmetrical (Odd n): Total = $2^{n-1}$. (Meso = $2^{(n-1)/2}$).

related_concepts.name: Meso Compound
related_concepts.definition: A molecule with chiral centers that is superimposable on its mirror image (optically inactive).

subject: Chemistry
title: Born-Haber Cycle
description: Cycle to calculate Lattice Energy (U) of an ionic solid.
derivation:
Hess's Law application for formation of $MX(s)$:
1. Sublimation of Metal: $M(s) \to M(g)$ ($S$).
2. Ionization: $M(g) \to M^+(g)$ ($IE$).
3. Dissociation of Non-metal: $\frac{1}{2}X_2(g) \to X(g)$ ($\frac{1}{2}D$).
4. Electron Gain: $X(g) \to X^-(g)$ ($-EA$).
5. Lattice Formation: $M^+ + X^- \to MX(s)$ ($-U$).
Sum equals Enthalpy of Formation $\Delta H_f$.

related_concepts.name: Lattice Energy
related_concepts.definition: Energy released when one mole of ionic solid is formed from gaseous ions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Solubility of Group 2 Sulfates
description: Solubility decreases down the group. $BeSO_4$ is soluble, $BaSO_4$ is insoluble.
derivation:
Solubility depends on $\Delta H_{sol} = \Delta H_{hyd} - U$.
Down the group, Lattice Energy ($U$) remains roughly constant (dominated by large Sulfate ion).
However, Hydration Energy ($\Delta H_{hyd}$) decreases significantly as cation size increases.
Result: $\Delta H_{sol}$ becomes less negative (less favorable) down the group.

related_concepts.name: Hydration Energy
related_concepts.definition: Energy released when ions are surrounded by water molecules ($HE \propto 1/r^+$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Inert Pair Effect
description: Reluctance of s-electrons to participate in bonding in heavy post-transition elements.
derivation:
Cause: Poor shielding by d and f orbitals.
Effect: The valence s-electrons ($ns^2$) are held tightly by the nucleus.
Trend: Stability of lower oxidation state ($Group No. - 2$) increases down the group.
Example: $Pb^{+2}$ is more stable than $Pb^{+4}$ (Lead storage battery works on this stability).

related_concepts.name: Oxidizing Agent
related_concepts.definition: $PbO_2$ and $Bi(V)$ are strong oxidizers because they want to revert to +2 and +3 states respectively.

subject: Chemistry
title: Back Bonding (p-pi - p-pi)
description: Donation of lone pair from substituent to empty orbital of central atom.
derivation:
Case $BF_3$: Boron has empty 2p orbital. Fluorine has filled 2p lone pair.
Overlap: $2p(B) - 2p(F)$ is effective due to similar size.
Electron density moves from F to B, satisfying B's electron deficiency.
This reduces Lewis Acid character.
In $BCl_3$, overlap is $2p(B) - 3p(Cl)$ (mismatched sizes), so back bonding is weak, acidity is higher.

related_concepts.name: Lewis Acid Strength
related_concepts.definition: $BF_3 < BCl_3 < BBr_3 < BI_3$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Bridge Bonding (Al2Cl6)
description: Dimer structure of Aluminum Chloride.
derivation:
Aluminum in $AlCl_3$ is electron deficient (6e).
To complete octet, it accepts a lone pair from Chlorine of another $AlCl_3$ molecule.
Geometry: Each Al is Tetrahedral.
Two types of Al-Cl bonds: Terminal (shorter) and Bridging (longer).
Unlike $B_2H_6$ (3c-2e), this bridge involves a full lone pair (3c-4e).

related_concepts.name: Dimerization
related_concepts.definition: Process where two identical molecules join. $Al_2Cl_6$ dissociates to monomer at high temp.

subject: Chemistry
title: Hydrolysis Mechanism (SiCl4 vs CCl4)
description: Role of d-orbitals in hydrolysis.
derivation:
1. $SiCl_4$: Silicon has vacant 3d orbitals.
   Water oxygen attacks Si, expanding its coordination number.
   $Cl^-$ leaves, OH replaces it.
2. $CCl_4$: Carbon has no d-orbitals (Period 2).
   Steric crowding prevents backside attack on Carbon.
   Result: $CCl_4$ is inert to hydrolysis.

related_concepts.name: Expansion of Octet
related_concepts.definition: Ability of elements from Period 3 onwards to accommodate more than 8 valence electrons.

subject: Chemistry
title: Silicate Types
description: Classification based on number of shared oxygen corners per tetrahedron.
derivation:
Basic Unit: $SiO_4^{4-}$.
- Ortho: 0 shared ($SiO_4^{4-}$).
- Pyro: 1 shared ($Si_2O_7^{6-}$).
- Cyclic/Chain: 2 shared ($(SiO_3)_n^{2n-}$).
- Sheet: 3 shared ($Si_2O_5^{2-}$).
- 3D Network: 4 shared ($SiO_2$).

related_concepts.name: Tectosilicates
related_concepts.definition: 3D network silicates like Quartz and Feldspars.

subject: Chemistry
title: Xenon Fluoride Hydrolysis
description: Redox hydrolysis for XeF2; Non-redox for XeF6.
derivation:
1. $XeF_2$: Unstable in water. Oxidizes water to $O_2$ and reduces itself to $Xe$ gas.
2. $XeF_4$: Disproportionation. Gives $Xe$, $XeO_3$, $HF$, $O_2$.
3. $XeF_6$: Complete hydrolysis yields explosive $XeO_3$ (Xenon Trioxide) + $HF$. No change in O.S. (+6).

related_concepts.name: Partial Hydrolysis
related_concepts.definition: $XeF_6 + H_2O \to XeOF_4 + 2HF$.

subject: Chemistry
title: Interhalogen Shapes
description: VSEPR structures of $XX'_n$.
derivation:
1. $ClF_3$: 7+21=28e. 3 Bond Pairs, 2 Lone Pairs. T-shape to put LPs equatorial.
2. $BrF_5$: 7+35=42e. 5 BPs, 1 LP. Square Pyramidal.
3. $IF_7$: 7+49=56e. 7 BPs, 0 LPs. Pentagonal Bipyramidal.

related_concepts.name: Berry Pseudorotation
related_concepts.definition: Mechanism allowing axial and equatorial ligands to swap in trigonal bipyramidal molecules.

subject: Chemistry
title: Corrosion (Rusting)
description: Electrochemical process occurring on iron surface.
derivation:
Anode (Iron surface): $Fe$ oxidizes to $Fe^{2+}$.
Electrons flow through metal to Cathode (Impurity/Stress point).
Cathode: Dissolved $O_2$ in water (with $H^+$ from $CO_2$) accepts electrons.
Product: $Fe^{2+}$ oxidizes further by air to $Fe_2O_3 \cdot xH_2O$ (Rust).

related_concepts.name: Sacrificial Protection
related_concepts.definition: Coating iron with a more active metal (Zn - Galvanization) to act as anode.

subject: Chemistry
title: Conductometric Titration (SA vs SB)
description: Conductance trend when NaOH is added to HCl.
derivation:
1. Initial: High conductance due to fast $H^+$.
2. Addition of NaOH: $H^+$ replaced by slower $Na^+$. Conductance decreases linearly.
3. Equivalence Point: Minimum conductance.
4. Excess NaOH: Conductance increases due to fast $OH^-$.
Result: V-shaped curve.

related_concepts.name: Ionic Mobility
related_concepts.definition: Velocity of ion per unit potential gradient. $H^+$ and $OH^-$ have exceptionally high mobility (Grotthuss mechanism).

subject: Chemistry
title: Corey-House Synthesis
description: Preparation of unsymmetrical alkanes using Gilman Reagent.
derivation:
1. Formation of Gilman Reagent: $2RLi + CuI \rightarrow R_2CuLi + LiI$.
2. Coupling: Reaction with Alkyl Halide $R'X$.
   Mechanism: Nucleophilic attack of $R$ from cuprate on $R'$.
   Constraint: $R'$ must be Methyl, Primary, or Secondary halide (SN2 type). $R$ can be any group.

related_concepts.name: Wurtz Limitation
related_concepts.definition: Wurtz reaction gives mixture of products for unsymmetrical alkanes ($R-R, R'-R', R-R'$).

subject: Chemistry
title: Ullmann Reaction
description: Coupling of Aryl Halides (especially Iodides) to form Biaryls.
derivation:
Reagent: Copper Powder at high temperature.
Mechanism: Radical anion intermediate.
Application: Synthesis of Biphenyls.
Note: Specific for Aryl halides, unlike Wurtz (Alkyl) or Fittig (Aryl+Alkyl).

related_concepts.name: Fittig Reaction
related_concepts.definition: Coupling of two aryl halides using Sodium metal.

subject: Chemistry
title: Frankland Reaction
description: Preparation of symmetrical alkanes using Zinc.
derivation:
Similar to Wurtz reaction but uses Zinc instead of Sodium.
Mechanism: Formation of Organozinc intermediate ($RZnX$).
Better control than Wurtz for laboratory synthesis.

related_concepts.name: Organozinc Compounds
related_concepts.definition: Less reactive than Grignard reagents, used in Reformatsky reaction.

subject: Chemistry
title: Schmidt Reaction
description: One-step conversion of Carboxylic Acid to Primary Amine.
derivation:
Reagent: Hydrazoic Acid ($HN_3$) in Conc $H_2SO_4$.
Mechanism:
1. Protonation of acid -> Loss of water -> Acylium ion.
2. Addition of $HN_3$ -> Rearrangement similar to Curtius.
3. Loss of $N_2$ leads to migration of R group.
4. Hydrolysis gives Amine.

related_concepts.name: Lossen Rearrangement
related_concepts.definition: Similar rearrangement starting from Hydroxamic Acid.

subject: Chemistry
title: Arndt-Eistert Synthesis
description: Homologation of carboxylic acid (adding one CH2 unit).
derivation:
1. Acid Chloride formation.
2. Diazomethane ($CH_2N_2$) addition forms Diazoketone.
3. Wolff Rearrangement ($Ag_2O, \Delta$): Loss of $N_2$ generates Ketene ($R-CH=C=O$).
4. Hydration: Ketene reacts with water to form higher Homologue Acid.

related_concepts.name: Wolff Rearrangement
related_concepts.definition: Key step converting alpha-diazoketones into ketenes.

subject: Chemistry
title: 1,2 vs 1,4 Addition (Dienes)
description: Kinetic vs Thermodynamic Control.
derivation:
Reaction: $CH_2=CH-CH=CH_2 + HBr$.
1. Low Temp (-80C): 1,2-addition product ($CH_3-CHBr-CH=CH_2$) dominates. **Kinetic Control** (Lower activation energy).
2. High Temp (40C): 1,4-addition product ($CH_3-CH=CH-CH_2Br$) dominates. **Thermodynamic Control** (More stable alkene due to hyperconjugation).

related_concepts.name: Resonance Stabilization
related_concepts.definition: The intermediate allyl carbocation has charge delocalized over C2 and C4.

subject: Chemistry
title: Free Radical Halogenation Selectivity
visual_data: Br^\bullet \text{ is selective, } Cl^\bullet \text{ is reactive}
description: Hammond's Postulate application.
derivation:
1. Chlorination: Exothermic. Transition state resembles reactants (early). Low activation energy difference between $1^\circ, 2^\circ, 3^\circ$ H abstraction. Low selectivity.
2. Bromination: Endothermic. Transition state resembles products (late). Radical character is developed in TS. Stability of radical ($3^\circ > 2^\circ > 1^\circ$) strongly influences rate. High selectivity.

related_concepts.name: Hammond Postulate
related_concepts.definition: The transition state structure resembles the species (reactant or product) to which it is closer in energy.

subject: Chemistry
title: Standard Hydrogen Electrode (SHE)
description: Primary reference electrode. Potential defined as 0.00 V at all temperatures.
derivation:
Components: Platinum foil coated with Platinum black, immersed in 1M $H^+$ solution, bubbled with pure $H_2$ gas.
Half Reaction: $2H^+ + 2e^- \rightleftharpoons H_2(g)$.
It acts as Anode or Cathode depending on the other half-cell.
Limitations: Difficult to maintain 1M conc and 1 bar pressure continuously; susceptible to poisoning.

related_concepts.name: Calomel Electrode
related_concepts.definition: Secondary reference electrode ($Hg/Hg_2Cl_2/KCl$) often used in labs due to stability.
